content:
Posted: March 4, 2012
												One of the best games you will ever play.  If you want a surprisingly believable story involving government and global conspiracies with a multitude of characters & a wide variety of skills to upgrade, buy this, you will not be let down.  The soundtrack  is phenomenal, the music matches exactly what the level and setting feels like.  There are lots of skills in which you can put skill points into to make yourself a deadlier close range fighter, a pinpoint sniper, a more proficient hacker, and more.  The augmentations are awesome, you can give yourself the ability to cloak, to see through walls, to run as quiet as amouse, and much more.  There's an abundance of weapons which you can upgrade to give it a laser, a scope, make it more accurate, and more.  There's really just more of everything.  You get to go to Hong Kong, Paris, and even Area 51, the places are very memorable, with the amazing soundtrack to accompany them.  One thing that people would argue as being a flaw of this game, is the voice acting, and while I do agree it's mediocre, it's that voice acting that gives the game even more charm to it.  Fighting with enemies isn't really that much fun though, it's a standard 'click until dead' combat system.  + Believable and gripping story with lots of twists+ Best video game soundtrack ever+ Many skills and augmentations+ Many weapons with modifications to boot+ Memorable levels and great level design+/- Mediocre voice acting- Battles could be done much betterWithout a doubt, the best single player game ever made.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												"Deus Ex is a game that brought Cyberpunk universe and the gameplay to the next level." Ya surely saw this quote somewhere on the internet, but how can this old game made in 2000 is so damn important? Is it enjoyable? Does it hold up to today's standards? You shall see these answers in this review!The game takes place in 2052 where the world is plagued with the Gray Death and some people are desperate to recieve a vaccine called "Ambrosia" with any dangerous means. You play as JC Denton, the agent of UNATCO which protects people from terrorist organizations, until your brother left and joined the terrorists, while the organization you work on wants him dead without giving any information you want to know why. Why your brother did that? What is UNATCO hiding? I cannot spoil further. But I can guarantee that you will meet many conspiracies related to it.When it comes to the graphics, in 2000 it was really amazing what you could do with Unreal Engine 1. Today it is pretty much outdated but there are still some modifications that lets you play on higher quality graphics such as DirectX 10 Deus Ex with New Vision and HD models installed. If you are really bothered with normal graphics then get em, if not then enjoy how Unreal Engine 1 did in 90s if used correctly.The gameplay is outstanding. Despite it is a FPS game, it also has some RPG elements on it and no ya dn't level up. Instead you recieve Skill points that you can spend to upgrade your skills. The Skill Points are recieved if you complete any main objectives along with side missions, yet there are also recieved as a bonus if you use a different route. Now we are talking about the 1st main thing...You have multiple choices in this game, if you want to concentrate more in getting past undetected, lockpick the lock, hack the terminal and use turrets to do your job? It is possible. Going gun-blazing and use any tricks you have at the disposal to deal with the enemies? CHECK. Also any action you take in a populated area may affect your progress as well!Now the 2nd main thing about this game are...augmentations. You can modify your body parts with the correct augmentation to gain more sweet stuff that can be used anywhere and change your gameplay style and upgrade them!. Be aware that there are limited slots for some body parts to modify. Wanna go invisible and jump really high and run fast at the same time like a ninja? YOU CAN. But be aware though that there is a limited energy for using augmentation so if you have multiple augs on, then deal with the fact that you may run out of them pretty fast.There is a lot of weapons in this game yet using them depends on your skill level and you can upgrade them with the correct kit for more interesting results, except these two some weapons can use different ammo which some enemies are weak against it. For example using the Sabot shells will allow you to deal more damage against robots than the Buckshot shells. Combining your weaponry with augs may give you great results like using Targeting aug at the level 2 with laser sight pistol lets you sniper your enemies without wasting any ammo for sniper rifle or use the Agressive Defense System with Balistic Protection augs and shotgun to become a tank which no missile or bombs won't hurt you.The music in the game fits perfectly for any situation and the world itself filled with cutting edge technology and the dialogues may be cheesy but funny while the weapons gives some oomph when you fire.If you consider getting this for a low price then DO IT! It is worth any money for not only how amazing this game is but as well as game mods that give even more dramatic changes in the gameplay to make it more fun such as The Nameless Mod and other.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												Deus Ex, despite being released in the summer of 2000, is still one of the greatest role-playing shooter hybrids available on PC. If you're a fan of futuristic settings or the cyberpunk science fiction genre as I am, Deus Ex's storyline and environments should be right up your alley.Set in 2052, you take on the role of JC Denton (JC supposedly refers to Jesus Christ) a rookie to an anti-terrorist organization called UNATCO. But things quickly get out of control and you are soon involved in a huge conspiracy involving various factions - including the Illuminati and the Hong Kong Triads, as you travel over the world to unravel this conspiracy.The game allows a great deal of freedom and various choices - you will also have a few multiple endings to achieve. Deus Ex is a branching game, meaning there are always multiple paths to choose from, you could even choose to not kill anyone at all through the entire game - which is a lot more complicated to do than it sounds, trust me!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												Deus Ex is one of those games that define what an RPG is; a game that allows you to build and progress your character throughout the game and make choices throughout the game's solid plot to build your own take on it. Throughout the game creative thinking is encouraged to reach some areas, surpass obstacles, or even defeat certain enemies. The stealth mechanics are crude, however, the enemies seemingly having tunnel vision alot of times making it easy to sneak past them, or peak around a corner at them, somehow without them seeing your head poke out from behind a wall. The difficulty can be pretty weak when it comes to the enemies, I recommend playing on Hard or Realistic for a decent challenge. For a game released in 2000 the graphics are pretty solid though by today's standards they're pretty primitive, but that doesn't matter, graphics mean nothing so long as you have fun. You have a couple of different skills for different methods for making your way past the game's enemies, security systems and some hazards, but skills only enhance your capabilities with the tools, weapons and items associated with them making them more efficient, but in some cases it is hardly needed, for instance, with Explosives you don't really need skill enhancement that much, explosive weapons already do enough damage to instantly kill the majority of enemies you encounter. (And in the case of grenades you can have plentiful amounts of them.) But skills definately help in getting a better aim faster with ranged weapons, and modding and enhancing said weapons is a nice touch when you can stick a "silencer*" on an Assault Rifle or a Sniper Rifle, turning a sniper into a quiet one-shot-kill weapon most of the time. (so long as you aim for the head) Ontop of that, slow reloads on your shotguns? There's a mod for that. Trouble with the gun's shots hitting your target? There's a mod (and skills) for that. Want to turn a pistol into a marksman weapon? There's a scope mod for that. Multiplayer I haven't played much of but I vaguely recall it being fun but also confusing, can't really comment on it, but I can certainly comment on the actual game itself: A classic that has stood the test of time.9/10*Unlike real life -suppressors- the silencer in the game actually makes weapons silent to enemies.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Real conspiracies. Severe consequences. Intense action role-playing.Writing this takes me back to pre-Steam times. I played this game for the first time back in year 2001 and later on made either a partial or full replay every 3-4 years. Everytime I was overwhelmed and impressed with immerse story that takes you all around the world, all these well written characters, movie-like screenplay and captivating sound environment. I would spend many hours looking in every corner, putting the pieces back together and digging the story and it's background, discovering secret areas, thinking about philosophical questions hidden between the lines - pretty much embracing Deus Ex. (A huge portion of this was successfully recreated and implemented in Human Revolution - which I would like to recommend as well). Deus Ex is among my few best games I have ever played, literally a diamond of a game. Everything about this game is exceptional: moral choices and it's consequences, elastic gameplay, the atmosphere, all the ambiance you can experience. Everything, in a way modern games try to achieve with mixed success.Did I mention replay value? Tremendous. Someone mentioned Deus Ex and I reinstalled deciding to not to give up and push on till I see the credits! Game from year 2000 won with growing line of brand new titles. To my amazement I managed to discover three new hidden areas and finding them after several replays was really rewarding. Has it aged well? For 2000 game, hell yes, only of you can handle near millennial style of boxy graphics and somewhat wooden animations, but really it doesn't matter and shouldn't bother you since backbone and writing of this game is really solid and presents still open and actual questions like: global government, NWO, infiltration, genetic enchancement and augmentations knocking to our door. "Trust no one. Question everything" - Play Deus Ex and soak in and embrace the night.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												There's not much I can say in my review that hasn't been said in the other positive reviews on here. Deus Ex is a first person shooter/RPG hybrid, regarded by many as the best game ever made. Is it? In my opinion, no, but it is still a great game. If you've played System Shock or Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines, you should feel right at home here.Let's get a few of the 'bad' things out of the way first, the things I've seen a lot of people ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about on here and on Metacritic. First off, yes the game is ugly. Look at the screenshots before you buy it. If you don't like how it looks, then don't buy it, simple. The graphics are bad, the character models are fairly wooden, and the voice acting is so bad it's good. Oh, and the default key bindings are pretty bad. But you know what? You can re-map the keys. So it's really a non-issue.Onto the good stuff. This game focuses a lot on inventory management. It's like an old RE title, or Diablo II, where you have only so much room in your inventory for items. So you'll constantly be wondering if it's worth it to carry around the huge flamethrower or keep a couple of pistols and a sword; personally I find this a great change in pace from some games that just let you carry around everything. The sheer level of character customization is crazy. You get skill points, but only at certain points; you gain nothing from defeating enemies, unlocking doors, etcetera. When you find a secret room or explore a certain area, you get skill points, and you get them from completing objectives. Then its up to you where to put them. Pistols, rifles, melee combat, explosives, pickings locks, swimming, healing, and more. You can't master them all (withoug exploting a bug late game) so you have to manage the skill points wisely. On top of that, you can find countless modifications for your guns, among them recoil, reload speed, range, scopes, and laser sights. Oh, and and on top of that, you have several slots for augmentations to your body to give you healing power, quicker speed, strength, defense, and more. But you only have so many slots, and the augmentation items you find carry two for one slot. So do you take health regeneration, or an energy shield? There are so many ways to customize the character to your playstyle it is really astounding.The levels themselves a huge and allow for a variety of routes. In the first mission, I was looking for the person I needed to speak to for my objective; he was to allow me to get into the building where my foes were. Instead I found a big stack of boxes and jumped up on them until I got to the roof, totally bypassing that part of the mission. Later on, if you're careful and look everywhere and make the right decisions, you can even find information to skip entire boss fights. The story can be a bit on the confusing side, but it's well written and takes into account a lot of different conspiracy theories from the real world. I can't say to much without spoiling it so I'll leave it to you to figure it out. So should you get this game? Yes, absolutely. For $6.99, it's practically stealing.

												If you are a fan of RPG, FPS, or stealth games you NEED to play this. Deus Ex is up there with Bethesda's games in terms of sheer freedom of play. Wanna be stealthy? Go for it. Wanna go balls to the wall guns blazing? No problemo. There's also hacking, lock picking, nano augmentation, hiding bodies, dialog options, multiple endings, you name it. This game was stupidly ahead of its time. Even the story is eerily conspiratorial and prophetic. A dystopian cyberpunk future where global governments use surveillance and engineered pandemics as population control. Did I mention the game predicted the destruction of the WTC at the hands of a terrorist organization? in the year 2000. Now with that being said, this is an old♥♥♥♥♥game with wonky shooting and dated graphics. Essential mods you will need to maximize your enjoyment of this undisputed classic include - BioMod, HDTP, and the New Vision Mod.

In both these aspects of story and gameplay, Deus Ex is unmatched and is a required at least one playthrough from anyone.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Anyone who has even a passing interest in conspiracy theories, world-altering conundra, or gravelly voices simply must play "Deus Ex." Set in a bleak future where the populace clamors for the treatment to an artificial disease and the FEMA director vies for absolute power, it's up to agent J.C. Denton to restore order. With great writing, an immersive world, and a very tough decision to make at the end, "Deus Ex" and its threequel "Human Revolution" should be on everyone's shortlist of games to play, like, right now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
												They don't make games like this anymore. It is exceptionally well-written in every single detail. At first it's funny how it manages to incorporate all the popular conspiracy theories, and it becomes frightening when they all turn out to be true. The way people are kept in line with constant terror alert, the shoot-on-sight cops, and the artificial plague is a very dark vision of the future, but the events since the release of the game suggest that it may be prophetic.The role-playing elements, and the non-linear and fully interactive environment provide lots of freedom to the player: in every playthrough one can find new ways to complete an objective and discover new details hidden in unexpected places. It is advised to talk to every NPC for several rounds, because almost all of them have something interesting and potentially useful thing to say. Mirrors are rarely found in games for some reason, but, interestingly, in this one they are abundant (check yourself in a mirror to see how bad the character animation is). If you can ignore the outdated graphics and the weak voice acting, you get the best PC gaming experience ever created.The music is also noteworthy, Straylight Productions composed another perfect soundtrack after their previous work in Unreal. It's interesting to compare the cover image of this game and its sequels: this one shows the moment of enlightenment, while the others show aggressive thugs.If you liked the game, check out The Nameless Mod as well.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												There's not much I can say in my review that hasn't been said in the other positive reviews on here. Deus Ex is a first person shooter/RPG hybrid, regarded by many as the best game ever made. Is it? In my opinion, no, but it is still a great game. If you've played System Shock or Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines, you should feel right at home here.Let's get a few of the 'bad' things out of the way first, the things I've seen a lot of people ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about on here and on Metacritic. First off, yes the game is ugly. Look at the screenshots before you buy it. If you don't like how it looks, then don't buy it, simple. The graphics are bad, the character models are fairly wooden, and the voice acting is so bad it's good. Oh, and the default key bindings are pretty bad. But you know what? You can re-map the keys. So it's really a non-issue.Onto the good stuff. This game focuses a lot on inventory management. It's like an old RE title, or Diablo II, where you have only so much room in your inventory for items. So you'll constantly be wondering if it's worth it to carry around the huge flamethrower or keep a couple of pistols and a sword; personally I find this a great change in pace from some games that just let you carry around everything. The sheer level of character customization is crazy. You get skill points, but only at certain points; you gain nothing from defeating enemies, unlocking doors, etcetera. When you find a secret room or explore a certain area, you get skill points, and you get them from completing objectives. Then its up to you where to put them. Pistols, rifles, melee combat, explosives, pickings locks, swimming, healing, and more. You can't master them all (withoug exploting a bug late game) so you have to manage the skill points wisely. On top of that, you can find countless modifications for your guns, among them recoil, reload speed, range, scopes, and laser sights. Oh, and and on top of that, you have several slots for augmentations to your body to give you healing power, quicker speed, strength, defense, and more. But you only have so many slots, and the augmentation items you find carry two for one slot. So do you take health regeneration, or an energy shield? There are so many ways to customize the character to your playstyle it is really astounding.The levels themselves a huge and allow for a variety of routes. In the first mission, I was looking for the person I needed to speak to for my objective; he was to allow me to get into the building where my foes were. Instead I found a big stack of boxes and jumped up on them until I got to the roof, totally bypassing that part of the mission. Later on, if you're careful and look everywhere and make the right decisions, you can even find information to skip entire boss fights. The story can be a bit on the confusing side, but it's well written and takes into account a lot of different conspiracy theories from the real world. I can't say to much without spoiling it so I'll leave it to you to figure it out. So should you get this game? Yes, absolutely. For $6.99, it's practically stealing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												There's a lot that's been said about Warren Spector's brainchild, that over-achieving cousin of Daikatana. What I'll say is this: it's dated, a bit janky with some bad (if heartfelt) voice acting and graphics that aren't exactly eye-pleasing.Yet...the very fact that all of those things are seen as lovable quirks by its fans are a testament to everything else Deus Ex did right, all the way back in 2000.And, as it turns out, there is such a thing as a free (graphical) lunch. The Deus Ex: Revision mod is a total aesthetic overhaul of the original game (including music) made over a period of 7+ years by dedicated fans. It's almost comparable to Black Mesa, except the Revision crew largely left the gameplay alone. The purists in the fan community still don't like it, of course, but they're friggin' nerds anyway.Suffice to say even without Revision, Deus Ex is a timeless classic and formed one of the cornerstones of video gaming's adolescent period; not to mention it's just a good stealth FPS/RPG in general for its age. The gameplay by itself could be partially considered a product of its time - the combat while satisfying enough for me is clunky like Bethesda's Fallout model, some of the augmentations are mostly useless and the aug activation buttons take up your entire F-key row. The presence of lean keys and an interactive item toolbar are welcome, at least.If you're not familiar with FPSes and can't manage to get a grip on the (reconfigurable) controls, you will have a hard time more often than not. Actual progression takes long enough that many people who play and replay the game, even veterans, stop after the first couple levels; it doesn't help that some of the lategame levels can be a slog at times. It's comparable to Half-Life 2 in this regard.Those are, however, the only criticisms I can think of. While I'd say there's too much that's been stuffed in to really call it elegant, when the good stuff clicks? It's really good. There's enough meaningful choice and emergent gameplay here to surprise you even after you read this review. Deus Ex rewards exploration and forethought, and while I'm not some jaded, entitled complainer, I'd like to see more of that in today's games. It was certainly innovative back when it was released. If you find the game slow going, I would advise you to simply stick with it. The amount of player choice and customization even in the vanilla game is also noteworthy for a title this old.As for JC Denton and his quest? While it's kind of corny, convoluted and obviously influenced by 1990s conspiracy theory culture, it ultimately grabs you by the collar with its twists, intricacies & personality - and doesn't let you forget it. It's reactive enough to the player's actions that I'd say it's also comparable to Undertale.And the music. It isn't to be missed; rarely do game soundtracks achieve so much harmony with a game as in Deus Ex.Now, this was still back in the Bad Old Days of Pentiums you needed to upgrade every year and action heroes who could be described as Gruff Man or Big Boobs, so while Deus Ex probably isn't the 2000s equivalent of The Talos Principle, it's still definitely a cut above the rest of its time.There is...was...multiplayer as well, but not only did it use the now-defunct Gamespy service and is very likely dead, it seemed largely perfunctory. It's still nice to see Deus Ex-style gameplay in a multiplayer environment, but if you somehow get it working you'd need to bring friends along for that particular diversion.In conclusion, if you are interested in gaming history and/or action RPGs and have a tolerance for old games, play this. You won't regret it.A word of advice, however: visit this guide, scroll down to "Installing Patches" and install the two listed there. Launcher/graphics stuff is up to you, but at least patch the game up.

content:
Posted: February 17
												Deus Ex is one of the most influential games ever made. No genre describes this game as it seamlessly blends action, stealth, RPG and story elements into one unique game. It's safe to say that this is the best game in the Deus Ex series, with Human Revolution taking second place in my opinion.Firstly, I will talk about the gameplay. The game has three difficulty settings, and I prefer to play on normal. It isn't ridiculously difficult, but first-time players will be challenged and may find the game rather punishing. You really have to explore every inch of the game because if you run out of lockpicks or multitools, things are going to take a turn for the worse. But I think that this encouragement to explore really enhances the experience. This game makes you think. You can't just run gung-ho into combat because you WILL die. Instead, it makes more sense to creep around in the shadows with a melee weapon or sniper rifle, picking off unaware foes and dragging their bodies into a dark corner where nobody can see them. However, the stealth is often very inconsistent. There was one time when I sniped off a guard from afar and his comrades didn't even notice, but there was another time when I did the same thing and everybody was immediately aware of my exact position. Thankfully, there's always another way around an objective, and this open-ended level design is a hallmark of this series. The game has RPG elements such as skills that let you specialise your character, and a wide range of augmentations that allow you to regenerate health, see through walls, go invisible and even detonate rockets as soon as an enemy fires them. These elements force you to choose a playstyle that suits you well, and caters to any player's needs. Want to go in charging like a living tank? The ballistic sub-dermal armour will let you take more damage without dying. Want to sneak in the shadows like a ghost? The cloak aug will stop enemies from seeing you. I found the most useful aug was regenerating health, because you will frequently take damage from hazards littered liberally around the environments. Choices matter a lot in this game. For example, if you tell Jaime Reyes to stay in UNATCO, he meets you later in Paris and gives you a killphrase that allows you to bypass the fight with Gunther Hermann. This brings me to my next point: this game has the BEST BOSS BATTLES OF ANY OTHER GAME EVER. You don't even have to do them. You can just run right past. You can even kill bosses in earlier levels so you won't have to do them later on. I wish other games used this mechanic!         Not everything is perfect, though. This game has plenty of issues. I have encountered many bugs, from getting stuck in doors, to characters transmitting me the same message ten times, to using my jumping aug to jump through the ceiling of the 'Ton hotel and then landing on an invisible floor 3 feet above the ground. But to be honest, this doesn't detract from the experience and in some cases even enhances it. I mean, it would be fairly logical for me to be able to get stuck inside a repair bot, wouldn't it?  Maybe not. In any case, this is a fun game to play.       Now I will talk about the presentation. This game is 17 years old, and graphically it really shows its age. Character models look blocky, textures look blurry, and the environments are so ridiculously dark that I couldn't see things a metre in front of me in some cases. But the game is still really immersive, and although some sci-fi elements are REALLY far-fetched, the game still feels real. The political themes of the game mirror real life and in some cases, the game even feels like a social commentary. This results in a game that is still immersive despite its laughable graphics, and is probably the number one example of "graphics aren't everything".

												Its storyline is gripping, the environment rich, a lot of people to talk to, many sidequests to solve.You can choose how to complete a level (melée, infiltration, sniping etc.) and combine all of those.The development of Your capabities is three-fold: You can level up Your skills, aquire augmentations (special powers) and get weapon modifications - some of these You can combine to some degree (e.g. You can get temporary weapon skill increase by using an aug instead of increasing the weapon skill), so combining them intelligently definitely will give You an edge on the field.The setting itself is futuristic cyberpunk world, full of conspiracies, where the protagonist have to try his best to staly alive and further the agenda of one group or another - because in Deus Ex Your choices have consequences, and these may not be readily apparent.A 1000 Kudos to the creators, May Your BioEnergy Never Deplete!

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I want to tell you a story. It has spoilers, so consider yourself warned.My JC Denton was a good agent. In the field, he was an intelligent, efficient snipe-happy hacker, with a pistol for emergencies. (Side note: Silenced sniper rifle + laser-sight pistol, both at Advanced skill level =OP.)However, when he infiltrated the building Paul Denton told him to to show him that UNATCO was corrupt, my JC mixed up his objectives and went to the roof, where the satellite dish he was supposed to change if Paul was correct was located, instead of the basement, where the proof was. This was a bit of a dilemma.Then my JC Denton had an epiphany.He realized that he would work for whichever side allowed him to shoot, loot, and hack as much as possible. So right then and there, my JC hacked the satellite dish and looted what was inside, betraying his country for some immediate cheap thrills. Don't get me wrong, he wasn't psychotic; my JC was just extremely vindictive, self-righteous, and challenge-seeking, and he had a lot of guns.He then went through the rest of the game, shooting and looting and hacking all over the place, and when the time came, he took the only sensible option and merged with Helios.Deus Ex has a lot of problems. It looks awful, there aren't enough character options for the action-oriented player, the voice acting is atrocious, and some enemies have way too much health (lookin' at you, greasels). However, any game with this amount of player choice and understanding of the player (one time, when lost and trying to leave a cathedral, I walked up to a French chef and JC promptly asked how the hell to get out of there) deserves whatever recommendations it can get.Seriously though, f*ck all the transgenics.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Deus Ex is truly a masterpiece. Despite the name there is no Deus Ex Machina effect whatsoever - everything is logical and consequential and every detail is a piece of whole - user's password can tell you about his life more than you can hear from anyone, organisation name contains a key to it's entrance, and internet adresses hint major plot twist. The world of demolished Lady Liberty is surprisingly and eerily real both in it's behaviour and as a very possible future of ours. It also one of the most stylish worlds out there. Without overusing design cliches and descending into self repetition it keeps cold, metallic demanaur faintly lit by distant LED lights and blue ROM module colloids from the start to the end. And the wonderful tracker soundtrack by Alexander Brandon and Michel van de Bos is making perfect - transcendent.As for the gameplay. On the first glimpse arsenal is quite poor - less than ten types of firearms, couple of throwables, few melee choices and array of tools - but what this game about is you, as a player, as a character. Main tool in your arsenal is your head - numerous ways to approach the objective are only multiplied by your skills and the most useful tool in game - augmentations, which allow you to perform superhumane tasks such as invisibility, wind speed combined with impossible jump height or even projectile-stopping nanite shield - everything is in your hands. But beware that you are limited not only by supply of bioelectricity, but also with finite augmentation possibilities. The brighter you burn the faster you expire and one possibilities take take place of anothers. So at the end your head - is your main tool and weapon, not even the GEP gun.Don't be scared off by strange and old look of unreal engine or somewhat obsolete (i'd say more outmoded though) futurology - game holds it's mark to this day and is, and never cease to be a truly amazing and unique experience. Give it a shot. And don't play it like game - feel it, live in it. Because it's how it's meant to be. Because it's worth it. And remember - trust nobody, question everything.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
 A measly review wouldn't do this game justice. I've had this game outside of Steam for quite a while now:For years, games come out one after another in a specific genre with the sole intention of being better than the last in many fields, or being unique in a multitude of ways. The genre of "RPG" or "shooter" is one that is often explored to the very end of it's capabilities - the introduction of new technology in games like Fallout 4 and The Witcher 3 are games that were and are very easily promised Game of the Year time and time again. But through the embers of blazing releases and trailers, there is a game that pioneered a variety of things in undue time.And a measly review wouldn't do it justice.Deus Ex is most likely one of the best games I've ever played. It's old, unoptimized, and sluggish nature is something I can very easily ignore and regard as setbacks of the age it was released in. Though it's time deteoriorated the mechanics and features, it also gave it an advantage - it shook the medium, and the seismic shock can still be felt to this day. The story is something that draws you in and immerses you into a world of conspiracy. The music is a lovely additive, and you can feel every synth, piano key, and guitar riff even for the time it was composed. The set pieces are convincing, well-made, and lovingly crafted with attention given all the way down to the back bowels of a New York City borough. Deus Ex is a marvel of engineering for the year 1999, and it's accomplishments can be appreciated in the present time.Buy this game and play it through if you haven't already. DO IT.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												It's not easy to review Deus Ex. So much can be said about it, but then, so much already has. There is a good chance you have already played and completed it - but if not, allow me to suggest why you should. Deus Ex is an FPS/RPG sci-fi masterpiece, packed with action, stealth, conspiracies and philosophy. You will often find it referred to as 'greatest game ever' or at least in many people's Top 10 list, and you might wonder what the appeal is. Even fans can agree that it’s not the best looking game out there. The enemy AI isn't great and the voice acting... well, the less said, the better. These flaws aren’t very subtle either, they are quite blatant - so if the game has these problems, how can so many people find it so amazing? What defines a great game is not an absence of flaws, but an experience so rich and rewarding that any flaws - no matter how obvious - are happily ignored because they do not detract from the game overall.Nevertheless - do people claim Deus Ex is great just because of nostalgia goggles? Yes and no. Deus Ex pioneered a number of things that have become standard practice since, and so someone coming to it completely fresh won't find it as innovative as someone who played it when it was first released. Despite that, it still shines when it comes the most important part of the game - the story. If you are the sort of gamer who cares more about the polygon count, or skip through all the text so you can get back to the shooting, this might not be the game for you. For everyone else, prepare for a wonderfully rich and detailed world with secrets around every corner. Prepare for characters that will assist you with vital information, only to find out later that they were lying through their teeth to manipulate you into furthering their own plans. Prepare for hidden agendas, dangerous enemies, international conspiracies and difficult choices.Deus Ex is designed so well that despite being very linear, if feels like an open world game. Every level has different methods of approach that can completely change your game experience. Most importantly - your actions have consequences. It's not usually as blatant as 'go this way to save this character or this way to save this character' but far more subtle, with different ideas and philosophies introduced to you for you to decide which one you think should be the right choice.It's my favourite game. Many others say the same. This review, as well as all others, is attempting to put into words something better left unsaid - something far better experienced. It's Deus Ex. What more can you say?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2012
												Deus Ex's bland graphics, questionable AI and somewhat clumsy gameplay can't hide its age, but its unique mix of first-person action, puzzle and RPG elements with a bold, groundbreaking focus on story and characters changed the landscape, and would signifcantly influence developers for the decade to come, demonstrating that a game can share qualities of film or literature and still be successfull. It's exploration of human nature is still valid now, more than a decade later. If only Ion Storm had replayed this game before making Invisible War... If you're not a graphics aficionado, and don't require the latest in tessellation, filtering, or ambient occlusion to have an engaging experience, Deus Ex may be worth your time. If you don't know what any of those are, this is even more likely the case. Being a prequel with some of the same characters, Human Revolution also draws many call-backs (or "forwards") to this game.

												Deus Ex, or "God within" if you wish, is one of those games which defined what a good game should be.  It brings you into a world where every conspiracy you've ever heard of is true.  The Illuminatti, the Majestic 12, the myths about Area 51, every one of them.  Then they ask you, what kind of person are you?  Every choice you make has reprecussions.  Every person you kill has their blood on your hands.  Every door that is opened shuts another.  What kind of world will there be when your journey is done?Notes:  This game is UGLY and requires internet patches to get working on Modern computers, however once you enter the world you won't want to leave without seeing everything through to the bitter end.  The gameplay is solid.  The storyline is great, even by modern standards.  And the world feels amazingly real once you get past the bad graphics.  Don't miss out on this masterpiece.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
DEUS EX - Every time you mention it, someone will reinstall it.Three years after I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution and enjoyed it immensely, it was finally time for its big brother. I tried the original Deus Ex a few years ago, but I just couldn't get passed its outdated visuals (including New Vision) and especially its awful animations. Which I think is probably typical for the Deus Ex series, since Human Revolution also wasn't a looker to begin with. But I suppose I kinda matured in terms of gaming in the last two years, because when I started Deus Ex again a few months ago, the visuals didn't bother me.But enough about me. Besides the convincing dystopia future with its own share of society problems dripping with atmosphere, I needed some time to adjust to the gameplay. Because it has been quite some time that a game didn't spoon-fed me how to play the game or which way to go with a huge pointer on-screen. Overwhelming at first, but the level of player freedom makes you comfortable very quickly. You get a relatively big area each level where you can go where ever you please, do whatever you want in a manner you find appropriate. The excellent level designs makes sure of that. Later on, based on the augmentations you choose, you get even more options that suit your play style. No wrongs or rights.+ Excellent level design, a lot of player freedom, all roads lead to Rome.+ Not a single moment of holding hands, just good ol' fashioned exploration and finding the way on your own.+ Dystopia cyberpunk future and its problems are represented very well and convincing. + A great story to boot that rarely to never loses its grip.+ A lot of choices and consequences that can make your life later on easier or harder.+ Great atmosphere and an even better soundtrack.- Ugly face animations, probably even for 2000 standards.- Mediocre/static voice acting, except Bob Page whom I thought sounded excellent.- Stupid AI, though understandable considering it's 15 years old now.I still prefer Human Revolution (first love and all that), but now I can understand where most of its brilliance comes from. If the next Deus Ex, Mankind Divided, can combine the strengths from both Deus Ex 1 and Human Revolution, and somehow iron out their respective little flaws, Mankind Divided will be a very, very unforgettable experience. The hype is real.9/10

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												This game is one of the best I've played. Before I got into sandbox games like The Elder Scrolls and Fallout series of games I played Deus Ex. This plays differently than both of those titles, but it does sanbox play in its own way very well. The game can be advanced in any way you desire, be it stealth gameplay, run&gun, smash things with a crowbar, hacking terminals, killing everything you see, non-lethal takedowns, etc...You also have access to a rudimentary skill system that allows you to focus your expertise in whichever areas you so choose. You can be extremely skilled with handguns or relatively skilled with rifles, heavy wepons and melee weapons. You can increase the effectiveness of your medkits to heal you for more or focus on avoiding combat by getting more usefulness out of your lockpicks and multitools (high tech lockpicks for security doors and cameras).You will gain access to augmentations for your character as well. These are upgrades that have an active effect when you need it most at the cost of bio-electrical energy (basically a secondary resource like mana). These augs can be chosen from one of two per body part. You can augment your arms to deal tremendous melee damage or give you the strength to move heavy objects. You can augment your legs to give you faster movement speed or increase the height you can jump as well as ruduce falling damage. You can augment your lungs to allow you to hold your breath for longer periods underwater or to filter harmful substances from poisoned or irradiated areas. You can augment your skin to reduce damage from projectile wepons or from energy/fire weapons. There are many different combinations you can choose from, and each will help a particular style of gameplay. The choices are left entirely to you.Then there's the story. I won't give away spoilers, but know that nothing is what it seems nor is anyone who they really seem. There are many great twists and turns beofre you reach the end, and there are several different endings depending on your actions throughout the game. You can advance the story any way you want through your actions and dialogue choices. Deus Ex does this very well by allowing you to decide for yourself what actions you want to take in any given situation. Did that guy betray you? You can trust that he won't do it again, not trust him and never deal with him again or kill him for screwing you over. For every choice you make there will be some sort of effect on some aspect of the game, be it causing you to switch alliances or just a quirky dialogue change. Due to this there is a great deal of replayability that will keep you playing through over and over to see what would happen if you did things differently.Remember that this game was released in 2000, so don't expect hyper-realistic visuals and sound effects or nop-notch voice acting. What this game does best is to deliver a fun, memorable gaming experiece that sets it apart from your average yearly installment of CoD.BE FOREWARNED: To those who come from playing games like The Elder Scrolls and Fallout you will have to leave items on the ground never to be seen again. There is no storage nor are there vendors. The game revolves around you only taking what you inetend to use. It kills me coming back to this game after playing Skyrim. I hate leaving rocket launchers and flamethrowers behind due to my compulsive desire to take everything, but after a little while you get accustomed to it. As you increase your skills in certain areas you will find weapons you don't specialize in are less desirable due to their ineffectiveness and lack of monetary value. I specialize in handguns, and in leveling my skills in that area the usage of handguns becomes more fluid. I become more accurate, can use them more effectively while running, deal more damage with them, etc.., while with a sniper rifle I would have to stand still for a good ten seconds to get a good bead on my target, have a hard time aiming and deal less damage. It gets to the point where when I see a rocket launcher lying on the ground I don't even want to pick it up.I would highly recommend Deus Ex to anyone who enjoys a game with a good mix of story, solid gameplay, freedom of choice, decision making and consequence. 10/10 a classic.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												For those of us who remember the N64, Goldeneye 007 was up there with Ocarina of Time, and Super Mario 64 as one of the most popular games of the system. Deus Ex reminds me in many ways of Goldeneye.The gameplay is unmatched. Every level presents new scenery and new challenges. Just like in Goldeneye, you have various objectives that must be completed. And to complete the objectives, you have to deal with enemies as well as many other hazards, There are multiple ways to get to the objectives; do you clear the resistance or do you use your tools to get through the securely locked doors? This game features level ups in the form of augmentations and skill points. Skill points are gained by finding secrets and clearing objectives and can be used to better your skills, while augmentations are enhancements that can enable you to do things like healing, causing enemies to blow themselves up with rockets, or seeing through walls! You find these in canisters; found throughout certain areas. It's a fun game and for all you diehard Goldeneye fans (and even if you aren't), you'll love this game. Quite frankly, I don't know why anyone wouldn't. So go and get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												In the opinion of many professional (and unprofessional) video game reviewers and commentators, Deus Ex is hailed as one of the singular greatest arguement for the greatest game of all time. The in-depth story is as long as it is captivating, taking the player on a global journey from New York City, to Shanghai, to Paris and California and a rather surprising ending location. The story is unparralled in it's depth and creativity, despite broaching a genre which has been entrenched in many fictional works. The gameplay is superb, and serves as a model for close to every FPS/RPG succeading it. Ultimately, the excellence of this work is somewhat inhibited due to the aged graphics which it holds, the faces being a notable point of contention. But this minimially detracts from the experiance, and the atmosphere is unparalled despite this. However, Deus Ex belonged to a generation of games helmed by Warren Spector and other early PC innovators. This collection of programmers and coders worked on some of the most renowned games of all time, System Shock 2 (1999), Thief (1998), and other celebrated classics. They run in tandem with a more focused RPG genre, led by the Fallout games, Elder Scrolls games and other Dungeons and Dragons isometric games largely held as the culmination of masterpieces for the PC. In a sense, Deus Ex is sort of the harbinger of a new age for PC games, one which sort of loses a touch which System Shock 2, Thief and Deus Ex had, and this is inherent within the sequel, which abandons many of the tropes which made Deus Ex a masterpiece. Morrowind serves a similar function albeit for the RPG side, with Oblivion and Skyrim notably streamlining many RPG aspects within that particular game. That is not to say the sequels for Deus Ex are bad. On the contrary, Invisible War is good - but strange. Human Revolution however is noteworthy and worth a playthrough, if only for the grandiose set-up it leaves for this game. Overall this series is one of the innovators within gaming, and thus should be worth consideration.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Solid Game.Although it was made in 2000 and some of the controls are a little messy. Using the 10 or so augmentations or powers requires pressing the F1, F2, ..., F12 keys, but they can be re-mapped in the options menu. Thank God.The game does a good job at letting you play to your own playstyle. Going loud or stealthy both work. I personally tried a non-lethal stealth approach the beginning of the game, until I realized that tranquilizer darts take a few seconds to kick in. That's when I decided to make the switch to lethal, but silenced weapons. Something I wish I knew earlier. The story can also change depending on what decisions you make in the game. Become allies with certain people, and you might get better stuff. I haven't flushed out this system for myself yet, however.Also, think hardly about what augmentations you want. They're permanent. While a spy drone may sound cool, a defense augmentation can go a long way when you need it.This game reminds me a lot of the Half Life. Great level design and story. I only wish we had a sequel with JC Denton in it, instead of what we have in Deus Ex: Invisible War. He seems like a cool guy. RIP.Mind you, I did apply some mods to up texture resolutions, and to fix some game-breaking bugs that apparently existed. With a 750ti, the game runs at a smooth 144 FPS. It's an old game, what do you expect?I'd rate this sucker a 8.5/10. I'd give it an extra point if it had a better UI and augmentation controls.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												I want to tell you a story. It has spoilers, so consider yourself warned.My JC Denton was a good agent. In the field, he was an intelligent, efficient snipe-happy hacker, with a pistol for emergencies. (Side note: Silenced sniper rifle + laser-sight pistol, both at Advanced skill level =OP.)However, when he infiltrated the building Paul Denton told him to to show him that UNATCO was corrupt, my JC mixed up his objectives and went to the roof, where the satellite dish he was supposed to change if Paul was correct was located, instead of the basement, where the proof was. This was a bit of a dilemma.Then my JC Denton had an epiphany.He realized that he would work for whichever side allowed him to shoot, loot, and hack as much as possible. So right then and there, my JC hacked the satellite dish and looted what was inside, betraying his country for some immediate cheap thrills. Don't get me wrong, he wasn't psychotic; my JC was just extremely vindictive, self-righteous, and challenge-seeking, and he had a lot of guns.He then went through the rest of the game, shooting and looting and hacking all over the place, and when the time came, he took the only sensible option and merged with Helios.Deus Ex has a lot of problems. It looks awful, there aren't enough character options for the action-oriented player, the voice acting is atrocious, and some enemies have way too much health (lookin' at you, greasels). However, any game with this amount of player choice and understanding of the player (one time, when lost and trying to leave a cathedral, I walked up to a French chef and JC promptly asked how the hell to get out of there) deserves whatever recommendations it can get.Seriously though, f*ck all the transgenics.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Deus Ex is set in a dystopian middle of the 21st century, filled with religious extremists and powerful organizations, and stricken by a devastating new plague. The main character is JC Denton, a nano-augmented agent working for an international counter-terrorist organization. But as the plot unfolds, we realize that the situation is much more complex that what we expected.Released around the year 2000, Deus Ex provides outdated graphics and sound effects (even for its time, it was not the state-of-the-art). The musics are simple, and the AI is not very clever. Yet, the game has two major qualities.First, its complex and deep storyline. Various organisations are involved (terrorists, Illuminatis, Chinese triads, corrupt military forces, rogue artificial intelligence, political plotters, etc.) and all are related to each others. So, many 	unforeseen developments will occur, JC Denton will have to find out everyone's true motives, and where to put his trust. All of this allows for an extremely long single-player campaign, with many different levels and chapters. And if that was not enough, the game is full of philosophical and political cyberpunk-themed reflections (freedom of the people vs efficency of the state, the foreseen dependance of our modern society on connectivity...).Then, its extremely well designed gameplay. Deux Ex is a mix of RPG and FPS. The RPG part provides secondary quests, hidden objectives, useful and talkative NPCs, and choices to make that will influence the storyline (several endings are possible). There is also a system of skills and nano-augmentations, that you will have to manage in order to build up your character the way you want. This strongly influences the FPS part, which can be either infiltration or action-oriented, depending on how you upgraded JC Denton, or managed your items inventory. There are also many ways to complete the game, as Deux Ex will almost always provides several solutions to solve an issue.Thus, Deux Ex is a very intelligent game, with a great plot and a very interesting gameplay. It's not surprising some call it a masterpiece, and if you've never tried it before, you should.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												This is one of the best games I've played, and I've played and finished it in 2016, 16 years after its release. I first played Human Revolution. Whilst the hacking system is better in HR, this original game is also fantastic. There are multiple ways of playing this game, but you'll find you get more satisfaction from playing stealthy. Don't worry if you don't, you won't be penalised for it. You can play it as an action shooter if you like. The reason I clocked up 40 hours on one play through is mainly because I'd reloaded if I wasn't happy with my play style, or if I messed up my stealth.The augmentations are a blast! The Ai's pretty funny as well.I'd recommended this game to fans of Metal Gear Solid, Splinter Cell, and BioShock. Even Half-Life fans would enjoy this because of it's story. The RPG elements are simply that, you don't need to go around grinding to level up or anything.The lore and the story of this game are spot on. The world isn't thrown in your face, it's yours to explore, and the story is enough. I get irritated with a lot of games now trying to be action movies. This game doesn't do that, it's a good honest title.TAKE NOTE:Make sure you safe frequently and often -- don't rely on binding quick saves. Mine corrupted, and it seems a common issue. Make manual saves, I'm afraid e.g. <level name> suffixed with 'after guards', 'before aug', etc. I had gigabytes worth -- they take up a lot of space!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												The best video game of all time, bar none; the sequels Invisible War (horrible game) and Human Revolution don't even come close. The game takes place in the year 2052 where the world has become a ghetto ravaged by war, terrorism, and disease. A new plague, known as the Gray Death, is spreading rapidly with no cure; only a vaccine known as Ambrosia can prevent infection, and only if you can keep taking it. Worst of all, production is extremely limited and most of it is rationed out to key government and utility workers. You play as UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) agent J.C. Denton, fresh out of the academy, on his first mission to reacquire a supply of Amrbosia that has been stolen by the terrorist group NSF (National Secessionist Forces). But it doesn't take long to figure out that something much more sinister is going on.Deus Ex features incorporates conspiracy theries (Illuminati, Trilateral Commission, Knights Templar, Majestic 12, etc) into a well-integrated cyberpunk storyline. It is the most cerebral game I've ever played, which focuses on the ideas of liberty and authority with very intelligent dialogue.The gameplay is incredible as well. Deus Ex is a FPS/RPG hybrid and the best I've seen in it's genre. You gain skill points that you can invest into different skills, such as Heavy Weaponry, Lockpicking, or Medicine. You also receive nano-augmentations throughout the game that can be toggled on or off at the expense of bioelectrical enegry, such as Quiet Movement or Invisibility.The only downside to this game, if you want to call it that, is that the graphics are outdated as the game came out in 2000. However, there are lots of mods that improve things like texture quality which make the game more visually pleasing. If you were a PC gamer around the time though (Half Life, Unreal, Tribes, etc) then it shouldn't phase in you the least bit.Play this game NOW. You're not a real PC gamer if you haven't. 10/10. Such fun. Much wow.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2011
												Deus Ex is often claimed to be the best game in computer game history. Personally I agree but it's not without it's problems. Join me while I take a look at this critically praised title.The StoryDeus Ex begins in the docks of the island where the statue of liberty is located at. The island is under lockdown because of a terrorist attack by an organization called "NSF" that has managed to overtake the entire island. You are "JC" Denton, a nano augmented super agent working for the security agency UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) and your task is to infiltrate the statue of liberty and capture the leader of the terrorist attack alive. You meet up with your brother: Paul Denton which gives you a weapon and the location of a contact that can help JC into the statue. JC is later tasked with working under the supervision of his machine augmented collegue Anna Navarre in several tasks related to attacks against the NSF. The story has no problem introducing new characters to you. All the major characters you meets are colorful and memorable but most of all they feel real.Level DesignWhen you exit the docks you come across patrolling terrorists pretty much instantly. How you prefer to go up to the tower of liberty is entirely up to you as there are a number of ways to do so. The level design in this very first level is optimized to be as open as possible with plenty of secrets so it makes newcomers confused as to where to start and how to approach the problem. If you search around you will find to be able to get the Sniper rifle and the Crossbow on the very first level of the game.The other levels in the game varies with open areas and enclosed areas but they're never entirely linear. They are more often than not full of branching paths but of course there are a few linear levels which JC has to venture though but even those can be progressed through in different ways, making for a truly varied experience. Almost all levels in the game allows for a subtle approach (or even several) but a direct assault approach is never out of the question either. However, the game rewards subtle approaches more than lethal ones which is apparent even in the first few levels of the game.There is however one level that I want to bring up, directly before you arrive in Hong Kong - where you need to rescue your helicopter from a hangar of some sort: While not being a bad level in it's own right - this level did not add anything to the game and felt entirely unnecessary to me.RPG ElementsJC Denton starts out with a couple of skill points which he invests in different skills. These are in several different areas ranging from very useful to merely a convenience. The developers are aware of the convenience skills and they cost a lot less than the more essential skills that you can invest in. So if you want to be able to be a great swimmer it will not cost as much as being a good hacker or a good shooter but it will still cost something. Even if you don't have any skills in the different areas you will still be able to do these tasks - albeit at a higher cost of the resources to carry out the tasks. For example you might come across a locked door. If you are untrained in lockpicking you will only be able to unlock 10 points (of a universal maximum of 100) from the lock per lockpick. As the tools of these trades are relatively difficult to acquire large numbers of and locked doors being plentiful this skill easily turns out to be one of the most useful ones. So if you're untrained you will merely have to be more selective in the doors you want to try and unlock. If you run out you can also sometimes just blow up the door with explosives but the explosives in this game is even more rare than lockpicks. Unlike lockpicks though - explosives mostly only need 1 charge to succeed.Deus Ex also features an "augmentation" system where you get to choose between different buffs and abilities JC will permanently be outfitted with during the game. JC can choose between being better at smashing peoples skulls in with melee weapons or lifting heavy boxes and crates. One allows JC to take people down in one hit and the other allows him to bring cover or trap people. You also get other kinds of abilities like being able to either be invisible to people or to cameras or being able to see details of your target (like health and weapons) or have night & heat vision. You always have to choose between two augmentations that works in similar ways but they also need to be upgraded and upgrading is something I think the game could have done without; because without the need to upgrade, augmentations could have been playing a larger role (especially in the early parts of the game) instead of being a bonus on top of JC's more useful Skills system.Combat and StealthBecause this is an RPG - Deus Ex's combat changes according to the skills JC acquires during the game. The game favors silent takedowns as the game isn't afraid of pitting you against several enemies at once, but in a way it is possible to try and engage the enemy with lethal weapons as well but perhaps not as rewarding. Eventually though JC pretty much needs to equip himself with some form of lethal weapons due to the increase of armored enemies during the later stages of the game. This oddly enough gives a sense of progression and a strange dynamic to the fights where you have to use the less lethal weapons against human grunts and the lethal ones against the tougher ones.There is one strange thing with Deus Ex's aiming system where you have to crouch in order to get maximum accuracy. It's mainly a way to allow players who doesn't have good fighting skills to still be able to defeat someone with a gun. The games has some other, more desirable options open for such players such as throwing grenades and using pepper spray.Of course sneaking is the greatest asset to JC and you don't have to skill up in order to be a great ninja in this game. In fact: JC starts as a pretty good ninja right from the start. As long as the player sticks to the shadows or behind the enemy he's not going to be able to see JC coming and be entirely in the mercy of the players whims.ConclusionDeus Ex does have it's problems, just like every single other game but somehow what Deus Ex tries really works. The story, despite it's weaknesses is ultimately very good. The pacing is brisk and you're never without any goals. The level design ranks as one of the best in games up to this point. And unlike so many other games from 2000 this game actually looks really good. Much of what isn't done very good or great is at least solid and the game has very few apparent weaknesses.Most games I play have quirks that makes the experience playing them somewhat worse by being central mechanics. Deus Ex's problems are very minor in comparison of it's qualities. The augmentation system that I mentioned earlier is after all "a bonus" since JC's power really comes from his skills system. That's why I believe Deus Ex is as great as gaming has ever gotten and deserve a 6 out of 6.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												A true gem, even by modern-day standards, Deus Ex took me a while to get in to. It wasn't until a few missions/hours in that I was really hooked, but as the story became more understandable and the levels more varied (and there are a lot), I got to look past the dated graphics and A.I., and found a really deep, enthralling title with lots of rewarding exploration and true varied playstyles: you can complete any level how you want and there are a number of ways to do it. I would recommend Deus Ex to any fan of shooters, as it can fit almost all shooter playstyles: run and gun, stealth and snipe, superhuman abilities, melee, etc. The story and voice acting is great, and a long, content-filled adventure of conspiracy and tension. Great endings. 9/10

Posted: September 11, 2015
												Well what can I say... This game needs a rework.It really was one of the best games of its time. Nowadays it lacks some of the simple things like changing music, more kinds of different npc looks, and overall a better.Nothing of that was bad, but after about 2 hours per level listening to the same music my head started to hurt.This game got some things even current games lack: - Full voice cast- Manymany items, not only useful ones.- Big world with many places you actually don't have to visit- A choice between good or bad (kill or sneak in this case)- A complex story.Too bad after 14 hours (with at least 6 hours to go) the game crashed at a certain point, no matter which savegame I used or which of the multiple ways I went. Would have loved to reach the end.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Alot of people spam this game when you ask them what they consider the best game ever made is, but is it true? Ill toss my opinion in the sea of maymay reviews and BOMBs etc etcIll start off with the badThe gameplay is clunkyThe graphics are♥♥♥♥♥♥br>The game will most likely run like♥♥♥♥♥♥without a fanmade patch or fix like DEUSEXEThe voice acting is bad and can have some very bad actors here and thereNow for the goodThe voice acting is bad and can have some very bad actors here and there (its one of those wierd quirks in the game that makes it enjoyable and unique, not just a bunch of british people making everything sound dramatic)The graphics, while bad, have a style to them that I havent seen matched in any other game, not even the subsequent Deus Exes... its very dirty and cool temperant with all the blues and greys, with vibrant colors sprinkled across the levels to keep it just interesting enough to the eyeThe gameplay is indeed garbage, but it has a charm to it as well, it hard to explain and very subjective, but you might find yourself laughing your♥♥♥♥♥off after you smack a guard in  the back of the head with a baton and he falls flat on his faceThe real gem of the game is the story and writting as well as characters and twists in the plot. Its one of those games where you never want to really finish it because its so good, you dont want to see the ending come just yet. Ive reinstalled 3 times already and still havent seen the endingThe level design is very open and large for its time, Im always impressed at how many paths are crammed into the level without being to obvious. This is a short review, Its my favorite game of all time, it has flaws, but those flaws give it some character. I highly suggest you hop into it if you ever have a weekend to get ingulfed in a game. The first 2 levels arent top tier by any means, so dont let  them drive you off like they made me for awhile. I played this in 2014, and loved it. So dont believe the very few haters of this game when they say only people who played it when it came out like the game.

content:
Posted: March 5
												I've just beaten the game yesterday--first playthrough--and I've had a bit of time to reflect. I wish that I hadn't read a ton of reviews of people building this game up to be the best game ever. So if you haven't played yet, my advice is to go into it expecting that it'll be above average for its time (also assuming you're old enough to know what to expect from that era :P ). I think you'll enjoy it a lot more.I went in with VERY high expectations on the storyline becuase of all the reviews on here and wound up underwhelmed. Not only at the end of the game, but throughout as well. Just always wondering when it was gonna get really good. While the storyline was ok, I was never drawn in by it, and my reaction at some plot twists was more "huh...didn't expect that," than actual surprise.One main reason I never got pulled into the story was the absolutely horrible voice acting. They had 1 real person doing voices for like 15 different characters. With the lack of facial variation in the game, I was often confused if it was a new or old character I'd just met up with. The reason the individual voice acting was so bad is there was a complete lack of emotion in the voices. Impressively lacking I'd say. Like they grabbed people off the street. At first I thought it was about concerns for the size for the game fitting on disks back then, but the voices actually have acceptable bandwidth, just no change in pitch or volume. Finally in the last hours of the game ONE of the characters was emotive, raising their voice and changing the stress in the voice. Who knows, maybe it WAS a disk space thing, I'm not an expert.As you may have noticed, I do recommend the game. It's pretty good, and I hope I can relect on its backstory for when I play the later games (I know to skip Invisible War). But I think that there are a LOT of people who view it through star-struck eyes because they played it when it came out or it was the first game of this type that they played. Just as the original Halo has a special place in my heart, I realize I probably wouldn't think so highly of it if I started with the latest FPS games and THEN played Halo for the first time. But aside from Golden Eye, that was the first game of that sort I ever played--and right when it came out--so it left a huge impression on me.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Minor spoilers below.One of the most beloved classics, Deus Ex's gameplay hasn't aged too well (although Deus Ex: Revision helps) but I still recommend it to anyone who loves Human Revolution, Mankind Divided, or games with similar themes (Metal Gear Solid franchise).It was one of the earliest hybrid FPS/RPG games, taking after the System Shock games but being far less linear and more ambitious.  Overall I'd say it has a slightly more "choice and consequence" than Human Revolution, with unforeseen consequences happening much later in the game resulting from not so obvious choices unlike today's games.  Both this and Human Revolution have a "button press" style ending although it isn't literally just a button press like Human Revolution is.One of the major distinguishing factors between Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Human Revolution is the overall style the games go for.  Deus Ex has a sort of 80s action style, evident in the soundtrack and protagonist dialogue (man of few words who tends to deliver one liners).  Human Revolution and Mankind Divided on the other hand have a more serious and grim tonality.  Despite this different in style, both games end up feeling quite similar.  Vaguely similar gameplay, similar emphasis on exploration (improved in Human Revolution courtesy of more detailed levels and even bigger, content heavy hubs contrary to popular belief, at the cost of less total levels), similar environments and similar story themes.As far as story goes, Deus Ex is undoubtedly more complex than Human Revolution and most other games in existence.  It has so many plot elements going on at once, yet it never burdens itself or becomes confusing.  The dialogue isn't excellent, and it does have numerous moments of absurdity but not any worse than most films (e.g., we're supposed to believe that Denton easily bribes is way into a top secret facility, or how you travel to Area 51 right after nuking it and there's no radiation anywhere).  If this game were to be remade with largely revised dialogue and without the things I just described, it would be one of the best video game stories ever, but as it stands it is still well above average.  One of the reasons this game was named "Deus Ex" was because it tries to make it a point to not rely on Deus Ex Machina.As most would expect by now, Deus Ex does make use of environmental storytelling, although Human Revolution actually does a better job at this thanks to even greater levels of detail.  There is so much interaction in all levels of both games, and so much exploration.  When exploring and interacting you will find lots of reading material, whether it's newspapers (or Human Revolution's oddly more advanced equivalent), computers, datacubes, excerpts from books with thematic similarities, etc.There are often debates about whether or not this game is better than Human Revolution.  Truthfully, both games are so good that everyone who likes one game should try the other.  Human Revolution has slightly better character development and dialogue, it has one of the best persuasion systems ever made, it has much better stealth gameplay primarily due to the AI (in Deus Ex, if one person sees you or is wounded without even seeing you, every enemy in the vicinity knows your precise location for the next 20 seconds or so).  Many like to praise Deus Ex's level design (the openness and interactivity) but Human Revolution is not only more detailed, but its hubs (Detroit and most of all Hengsha) are MUCH larger with far more content (side quests). Both games showcase lots of dynamic physics effects to boost environmental interaction.  Deus Ex does not have a cover system like Human Revolution does.  It has first-person shooter mechanics with leaning.  Compared to Human Revolution it has more activated/hotkeyed augmentations which is nice.  You are certainly more powerful and advanced in this game than in Human Revolution, which makes sense considering Deus Ex takes place over 20 years later.  Denton has nano-augmentations rather than mechanical.The AI can really take a lot of enjoyment out of both stealth and combat, and so does the primitive clunky aiming/crosshair system.  Also it's terrible that cameras are invulnerable in Deus Ex... one of few synthetic limitations it has.  Furthermore this game's balance is off; harder difficulties simply make the player more vulnerable but not so much the other way around, although this is fixed by Deus Ex: Revision which is another reason to play that instead of just this.  The mini-crossbow is worthless because it only grants an instant knockout if you hit the enemy in the back of the neck; if they aren't knocked out, then they along with all nearby enemies know your precise location for the next 20 seconds and rush you.  Deus Ex lacks in effective non-lethal stealth weaponry unlike Human Revolution.  The riot prod is really good, that's it.If you can deal with the terrible AI and clunky combat, then install this game and then install Deus Ex: Revision over it.  Play Deus Ex: Revision exclusively.  Read my review of that if you want to know more about it.

												Welcome to the world of tomorrow, where old men rule the world and jock pilots are fully trained to dismantle bombs with ease.You play as bent cop JC Denton, who bet it all on Duke and now has nothing to lose except his virginity. On your journey you will encounter many amazing characters such as Agent Orange: an old, retired cop who has been dragged back onto the force due to recent terrorist acts, El Ray the software pirate and a top agent who refers to himself as "The Bomb".Armed with a mobile phone that can break any security device and the spirit of a true American patriot you take on the world, one country at a time. Your first stop finds you in Hong Kong, here you must defeat the evil Miyamoto from releasing his latest anime that will brainwash millions of glorious American youths into believing America isn't number one.Will you become America's next president? It's up to you to find out!Buy now and receive an exclusive American flag for JC to hold as he cleans up earth!
