content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
 Introduction Deus Ex is a first-person shooter published and developed by Ion Storm Houston in June 26, 2000. Directed by Warren Spector, Deus Ex is about one man’s destiny of becoming the God in the Machine to make a truly fair autonomous world government that appeals to the minds of the living – though this is only the first of many choices to take.Deus Ex is an incredibly influential game of it's time known for level design and scripting which has been designed towards various players actions that a player may take to complete an objective, a breakthrough in “emergent” gameplay and through experimentation secret dialogues and other rewards unlock through the exploration and reward.  Deus Ex’s setting is that of a futuristic cyberpunk world shrouded in ambiguity and fear as a nanite-virus known as the Grey Death spreads across the American continent and rural areas committing to the genocide of millions of people! The working classes, now cower in constant fear and terror of their government’s policies. It’s dark ambience and semi-realistic representation of 21st century world in turmoil coupled with the scale of its maps, intelligent design and humor help deliver an intense, conspiracy-themed world with high re-playability. Gameplay Deus Ex is a hybrid of First Person Shooter and Role Playing elements. Though semi-linear, there is many quests to do in the game which offers a challenge and reward of skill points or weapons/upgrades. There is a total of 10 skills in the game; Computer, Rifle, Low-Tech, Pistol, Heavy, Environmental Training, Swimming, Medicine, Electronics and Lockpicking.  These Skill upgrades improve Denton's ability to hack, swim (rarely used), shoot certain types of weapons without movement or accuracy penalties, regenerate more health, deactivate security restrictions such as a locked door to an armory or shop, gain access to robots interfaces and drones.4 difficulties are Easy, Medium, Hard and Realistic, all 3 increase NPC health and damage dealt but Realistic Realistic deals heavy damage on different body parts for both parties depending on what weapon is used to kill a target. Recommendations Lore-heavy with elements of interwoven themes concerning the socioeconomical abuse of a nation, the results of a corruptive government and the dangers of indiscriminate survillence giving the game a great sense of scale, depth, and mystery compared to games of its time.Modification friendly. Deus Ex uses Unreal engine to run so many SDK tools can be used to create new content. My recommended ones would be Deus Ex GMDX, Revision, Shifter and the tons at MODDB; http://www.moddb.com/games/deus-ex/mods Criticisms; Minor Requires Kentie’s Direct3D 10 renderer for extended options and playability.Deus Ex is very clunky gameplay wise with a considerable amount of skill bloat. To briefly explain this, a lot of augmentations overlap the Skills in the game such as Swimming and Environmental Training which are notorious for being the least useful skills to train in the game because they can be replaced with items or biological modification that do the same thing and better.Graphically poor, even for it’s time. Designs of certain weaposn are bland and nonsensical (such as the Stealth Pistol being a bullpup pistol) Animations are varied but stilted and wooden looking.Deus Ex's level design can be very confusing and maze-like at the end-game. The best thing to do is  is to explore and find new things. Gunplay The gunplay has a great selection of combat tools and different ammunition but is extremely clunky and spread is random until you gain the Targetting augmentation or use Gun Modifications to upgrade Accuracy of the selected weapon. You can use everything from Crowbars, Tasers to Rocket Launchers and Turrets (with the help of a Computer Skill) to take down enemies or you can use stealth and toss a throwing knife into the throat of a weary enemy. The game takes heavy considerations for what body parts are hit - for example, hitting a crowbar at the base of the spine will instantly knock or kill a target or a gunshot of a large rifle to the torso or head will terminate their life and in opposing manner you as well on Realistic Difficulty.  Music Deus Ex music was composed by Alexander Brandon, who is known for focusing heavily upon electronic and classical hybrids similar to Vangelis’ works. It is dynamic, peppy and very beat heavy - influenced in a unique way by the players actions. Assaulting enemies and friendlies will cause the music to be suddenly rough, choatic classic electronica hybrid ochestra (yes, it is THAT good) to a calm, placid ambient drone that heals the ears when visiting the bustling cities when walking around or sneaking. You should have a listen to Alexander Brandon's works as they are very sublime for their time. Graphics The Unreal 1 engine was updated in Deus Ex to allow for coloured lightmaps, textured shading, mipmapping, skeletal animation (to include more advanced animations). Though Deus Ex paled in graphics in comparison to other games, the world is still believable and large for it's time. Due to the expandability, the source code and SDK's packaged with Deus Ex, this produced many modifications from graphical, gameplay and to minor changes such as changes to HUD. Mechanics Deus Ex uses a 'Skill Point' design to allocated a fixed price of skill points which are earned by doing quests, use of dialogue, clever exploration or by experimenting with certain actions in the game's environment.Deus Ex awards exploration, inquistiveness and theres tons of hidden content, including story, items, mini-quests and lets you play as if it were an open-world and it gets better from there! Many, many guns to choose from, many ways to play stealthy or violently.Deus Ex makes much use of emergent gameplay, meaning your actions can take serious consequences and changes to rewards and storyline. The very first level can be played in many different ways - some that you would think the developer would miss! Storyline The introduction begins with two mysterious figures amongst a large statue of a hand palming the globe, explaining their plans for a new augmentation project and the virus known as Grey Death.Meanwhile… J.C Denton, a rookie officer at UNATCO is briefed to take action and arrest an NSF commander by his brother Paul Denton. UNATCO is an anti-terrorist organisation founded after the Statue of Liberty was blown up by Northwest/Nationalist Secessionist Forces, a “terrorist” group. J.C Denton is sent with his brother Paul Denton to find the source of the deadly plague that haunts American civilizations with an atmosphere of death and secret control. The player as JC finds out more and more about the sinister plague and the lack of Ambrosia, its cure. This leads you, the player (and by extension JC) into finding out much more than what meets the eye as you find leads all round the world leading you to the ultimate conspiracy.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Deus Ex! A Nanopunk/Cyberpunk themed action role playing game, combining first person shooter, stealth and role playing elements.Developed by ION Storm and Published by Eidos Interactive/SQUARE ENIX and designed by Warren Spector and Harvey Smith.Set in a dystopian world druing the year 2052 the plot follows UNATCO Agent JC Denton to combat terrorist forces. As the plot thickens Denton becomes entangled in a dark and deep ancient conspiracy.A game that has received universal acclaim and recieved multiple awards!The games storyline is unmatched by any other, the blending of genres: Role-playing, FPS, Adventure and Immersive Simulation makes this game the greatest of all time. Touches a lot on world affairs and it really takes a hold of you throwing you into dark and deep government conspiraciesGood:-The story is truly amazing it will overpower you!-The gameplay incoporates four genres and it blends together perfectly-Expansive environments with a lot of exploration.-Dialogue and back story improves the overall experience and there are some funny and cheesy one liners from NPCs.-RPG Elements are designed very well-The soundtrack of Deus Ex is flawless! The music really adds to the experience and the atmosphere, with subtle ambient street music to blasting bass/electronic tracks in combat.-Highly replayable I have played through at least 10 times.-The games graphics although not amazing really add to the atmosphere of a dark world which really puts Deus Ex into context.Bad:-Nothing, this game is flawless.There will never be a game in my heart that will replace this masterpiece of a game!Worth the experience, worth the penny, worth playing at least ten times!10 Foxes out of 10 Foxes :D

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Fifteen years and some forty save files later I'm STILL finding new things almost every time I open this game. It's amazing that Deus Ex managed to pack enough worthwhile content to make every playthrough feel unique, and not just in the game's scenarios themselves, but how you handle them. Every single weapon and aug has potential to do great things depending on how you build your character, with the exception of extremely situational, one use items like the P2000, or gimmicky augs like the Spybot. Deus Ex is a game that's hard to compare to others, because of how neatly the package is tied together. It's the way the atmospheric elements like music or even something as simple as lighting combine with the meandering you'll end up doing in the game's hub-worlds, and the hubs are where Deus Ex becomes a completely different expirience. Sure it's fun to play one of the good ol' linear levels with fairly straightforward objectives, but the sprawling, open areas are where the game goes from an explosive action flick to a gritty neo-noir with hours worth of sidequests and aimless exploring. For me, this is what makes Deus Ex so great. It plays off of the best characteristics or all the pieces that put it together. The soundtrack can easily switch from a fast-paced electronic beat to a faint ambiance to fit each level specifically. which perfectly coincides with combat. In one level you'll be mowing down every NSF soldier you see with a Sawed-Off, and the next you'll be methodically weaving between buildings, hiding from cameras and deciding to silently take down that group of enemies or avoid them all together. The game reinforces this shift between styles with the limited amount of items you can find. Instead of holding you back from entering an area in the game meant for later, it'll slightly nudge you away by guarding it with really tough enemies, or locking the door with a numpad that takes 4 tools to open. It's the small elements that were taken account with the level design in mind, especially with the hubs that elevate the game so much. While the story starts to sound like the focus group were a bunch of tinfoil-hatted conspiracy theorists, it's all explained so well and in great detail that makes it seem more "realistic". There's constantly data being thrown at you that it can be hard to absorb, but it creates a scale that really isn't realized until you pay more attention to it. Reading datacubes on tables or emails on a computer will give more insight into what's going on around you, and more importantly the people involved. Characters you liked early on might become more despicable, or vice-versa depending on how much you know about them from those optional little bits of character development that are placed throughout the game. Hell, this review is just another paper thrown into a file cabinet, but it's more of a personal love letter to the expirience I've had with Deus Ex over the course of my life. It seems every 3 or so years after I haven't played it in a while I'll reinstall it and sink another 50 hours into, and those little things I find that I didn't notice when I was a kid 10 years ago will put a huge smile on my face. It's by no means a perfect game, and it's not the first game to mix different genres in a very similar way (see System Shock), but it's a game that has to be expirienced first hand to know just how great it is.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												   This game...playing this game, I can see why it earned the title "Game of the Year". After playing this game from start to finish (40 Freakin Hours mind you), I can say that I was surprised and interested at the story, the cast of characters, the gameplay, and the music. Deus Ex is one of those games that allows you to do whatever you want. You can either play the game as John Rambo and kill every single enemy in your way, or you can play the game as Snake and take out enemies stealthily. It craves for you to get immersed into the complex story and make some pretty story-altering decisions. This game is an FPS game but there is an RPG element to it as well since you can upgrade your abilities or "augmentations" as the game calls it. The atmosphere of the game is apparent as you hear the music and face multiple adversaries. Overall, this game caught me off guard with the amount of content that it has in store for you, the player.    Let's get into the positives of the game first. Even though this is a 2000 game and the graphics may not look appealing, the positives of the game overcompensate it. In this cyberpunk and futuristic world of Deus Ex, you play a new agent of an organization (called UNATCO) named JC Denton. You will find that JC and the various people throughout this universe are "augmented", meaning that they are combined by the powers of nanotechnology. He has a brother named Paul Denton, and both of you are taught that you are a part of UNATCO, the organization that brings peace to the world of 2050! Even though JC and Paul are trained in combat and have massive amounts of knowledge on the world of Deus Ex, they do not know one thing: their past. Without spoiling the game, the truth hits them right in the face and they are forced to trust their instincts and make some risky decisions. The story of the game is complex, for there are many characters, many organizations to explore, and many twists to understand. The game gives you options that can make you make your own story in the game and this becomes extremely critical when you have to decide between three different resolutions for the end of the game.   The gameplay of Deus Ex is a lot of combinations. Like I said, you can play the game as Snake and stealthily kill people with your silenced weapons. Or you can play the game as John Rambo and explode people with your GEP gun (You'll know what that is later when you play this amazing game!). NOT ONLY that, but also there are other features such as the ability to hack terminals and computers. Since this is a highly technological world, JC can hack in order to bypass security, obtain key iinformation, and use the turrets and robots to his advantage (If you have the upgrade for it!). There's also a lockpicking mechanism, where JC can automatically open a locked box or chest with one or more lockpicks. You can get essential items by doing this. You can also use melee weapons, assult rifles, shotguns, explosives, pistols and so on! One unique thing is that you can use your augmented powers that you gained. For example, you can super-sprint or you can soak bullet damage! Be careful not to rely on this too much because this uses your energy!!! So as you can see, the gameplay has a lot of factors into it.    The atmosphere of the game is apparent and unqiue. The music is pretty catchy with its electronica influences and it fits with the different and various locals the game has to offer. The developers actually took the time to simulate realisitic email discussions that you can read if you hack or login to a computer. Also, there are "datacubes" that you can read if you find them. Although these seem like minor things, it adds a lot to the information-seeking mentality of the game. The characters you meet throughout the stages add to the atmosphere of the game as well. Hell, you get to chat with augmented people, people who are busy clubbin', gang members, and AIs for crying out loud. The developers definitely did a great job establishing the futuristic atmosphere of the game.   Now that I pretty much said the positives, let's go into the negatives. For one thing, Deus Ex has a weird way of saving data. If you don't know how Deus Ex works, YOU WILL lose hours of content. I'm not even exaggerating.  In this game, DO NOT EXPECT AUTOMATIC CHECKPOINTS, YOU MAKE YOUR OWN CHECKPOINTS!  There is none of the typical checkpoint system we see in most games. For this game, you can save anytime you want and you can make multiple save files if you want. This took time for me to get used to but this is still considered a bit of a negative in my book. Another negative is the inventory system of the game. There are times where I wanted a specific gun but it couldn't fit in my inventory. Deus Ex's inventory system is similar to the Resident Evil 4 inventory system, where everything is based on block space. So if you don't have any more blocks, you don't have service. I don't know but it feels like inventory space fills pretty quickly, especially when you get more than 4 guns or more. The explosive guns take up way too much inventory space and I rarely use them as a result. One last negative is that the AI (I'm talking about the enemy AI not the AIs featured in the game!) are stupid at times. Sometimes they run past you and sometimes, they kill themselves.   Overall, Deus Ex is amazing when it comes to the complex and immersing story, the multiple-sided gameplay, and the unique atmosphere. Some negatives include a weird way to save the game, inventory space problems, and derpy enemy AI. I'm glad I bought this game when it was on sale and this game is definitely worth more than the $4 I paid. If you're looking for a challenge, if you are looking for a unique premise, if you are looking for freedom of choices, then this game is worth trying out.

Posted: October 20, 2012
												It seems kind of unfair to review a living legend. Imagine if someone asked you to critique Tetris. What would say? It would be hard not to look at things through rose colored glasses. Luckily, I had only heard that Deus Ex was great when I first picked it up. I wasn't a fanboy, I didn't really care, even though I had played and enjoyed Human Revolution. And when I got my hands on it, oh boy. Everyone was right.Deus Ex is fantastic. Like, the type of fantastic that doesn't exist anymore. Imagine a game that accounts for everything the player can do. Deus Ex is just short of that, and only fails to be utterly perfect because it hasn't aged well. There are no autosaves even though there really should be. The voice acting can be horrid. An automatic inventory sort would've been nice. Deus Ex has tiny problems that are really only caused by being a product of a different time. All in all, unlike I a lot of people, I still don't think Deus Ex is the greatest game ever.....(read comments)

content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I've been meaning to play DE1 for the past few years, given that I have heard so many good things about it, but I was too busy playing other games. Regardless, given the fact that this game is available on Steam (and was only about $5 when I bought it, can't beat such a deal), I decided that it's finally time to give it a try. And so I did, being extremely impressed with the game. My knowledge of older (2000 and prior) game titles is limited to MS-DOS games like Wolfenstein 3D, Commander Keen, Doom, Quake, Blake Stone, etc., and as such I didn't play anything like Deus Ex or System Shock, or other important games of this time. I am stating this because I am making it clear that I have absolutely nothing to compare DE1 to. With that said, this really is a phenomenal game. As plenty of other people have said already, the amount of ways to get past a certain mission, being able to do things at your own pace instead of being forced into a linear storyline type of game is quite refreshing. It's not quite an open-world game, but that's completely understandable. The lore of DE1 is unparalleled in video game history, in my opinion. It's the kind of game that comes along once in a lifetime, blows everyone and their mother away in sheer disbelief, and is never matched in overall quality (at least in its genre, though one can argue that it has its own genre, again making it unsuitable for comparison to other games).The bottom line is that I really can't find anything wrong with this game. I waited way too long to play it, but it's better late than never. Others have claimed that it would probably be more enjoyable to have played DE1 in its prime (the year 2000 where there was little or no competition in that regard), but as I've already said, this game hasn't quite been surpassed by anything. Therefore, I don't believe that it makes a difference whether you play this game in its heyday or (almost) 15 years later. This is a highly excellent game that I'll recommend to anyone, and the fact that it runs on very much any computer made in the last ten years (even netbooks), makes it even more accessible. 5 out of 5 stars for this game.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												An exquisite, futuristic,  sci-fi masterpiece. So many titles that fall by the wayside never standing the test of time, yet Deus Ex remains over the ash heap of long forgotten games.To me what made this game so appealing is the universe in which it exists. A future that could easily be our own with the technology, conspiracy theories and similar named global powers that have had an effect on the real world we experience today.  Often if you took the time within the game to read information about current events happening and the parallels between our worlds it often seemed prophetic. That makes this game all the more intriguing and a satisfying experience. Character interactions also shaped the way you approach the game throughout. Do I try to talk my way out? Do I try to sneak in to accomplish my objective or go in guns blazing? Depending on the type of playstyle you want, you could distibute your skills and augmentations in specific ways so that your enemies would barely know you were there and if they did, it would be too late.Such an awesome game..I would definitely recommend this game to fans who love a futuristic, dystopian, and cyberpunk universe. You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												For as dated as a game this is, BUY. IT. NOW.Firstly, the combat is not very good. But who even goes out and releases fire in a game like this? If you want to do that, then play DOOM. (My all time favorite game.) It's even more fun to play it stealthily. Yes, the AI is dumb and will do the whole "HUH? I HEARD SOMETHING." thing. But at least when one guy detects you, it's only them and not every other person in the room, their wives, their children, their pets, the grandchildren, Kermit the Frog, etc. (Unless he presses that dang alarm.)Also, the RPG elements play a good role in the game. When you learn how to use a pistol better, you don't get crap like just plain higher damage. You actually get stuff that would make sense, like faster reloading and quicker aiming down.The story is great. I won't leave any spoilers, but it left me leaning forward in my chair.For the graphics, you can fix them with the HD mods and such. Also, make sure to fix the framerate issues in those mods by putting on VSync and such.But the one thing that I will say is somewhat critical to this game, is the voice acting. "MISTAH JAY SEAH DENTAWN. IN DA FRESH. AS DAHK AND SEWIOUS AS ID BRUDDAH."So, I'd say it's a 9/10, despite how aged and flawed it is. Just buy it. BUY IT. It's one of my favorites. Deus Ex is Deus Excellent.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Exceptionally great game. When the first level of the game has like 5 different ways to approach it, is filled with multiple secrets and npc dialogue, you know you got a great game. The variety of how you want to do each level is astounding. You can go loud and lethal and kill everything in site (including your allies), or you can do what I did and take the stealth/non-lethal approach and just knock everyone out. You can literally beat the entire game without killing a single person. Hell, some levels you can avoid interaction with other units entirely. You can just stealth your way through. Weapon variety is good, but what makes it unique is that some weapons have multiple ammo types allowing for interesting diversity. Really fun stuff. Just all around awesome game with tons of replay value and a plethora of content for the price. Still holds up today and is generally better than most games out right now. And just for the record, to those saying that the voice acting can be racist. That's not true. Accents are based on nationality, not race. Chinese, German and Russian are not races, they are nationalities. So saying it's racist to have someone with a crappy, stereotypical German or Chinese accent is just plain wrong.  It's like saying someone doing a New York accent is racist, when New Yorkers aren't a race. :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
There's a reason this game's called the best game ever created15 years ago, this game came out. (Happy birthday Deus Ex)It's heeded as the best game ever for a reason. It's not because the gunplay is fantastic or because it's "The Next Big CoD Rival"CoD was this game's rival and still is.The story's foundation are actual conspiracies from the 90's and 2000's, which is part of what made it amazing. To tell the other parts would spoil it.The characters, while having bad voice acting, were some of the most alive characters in any videogame. The characters displayed real emotion, and their characteristics affected how they acted and how they viewed your actions.The levels are pretty expansive, and offer multiple solutions to a problem that aren't obvious. From the streets of NYC to underground laboratories and military airfields, this game has plenty of environments of all shapes and sizes.The music is a part of what makes the game legendary. The game has set music for each level/area of the game, and all the music sets the mood extremely well. Each track has different scores based on what's happening in-game.The gameplay itself is also amazing, but clunky. The stealth is pretty nice, and the weapons and tools you have at disposal offer many different ways to approach and deal with a problem. Inventory management is big too, and makes you decide whether you want to dedicate yourself to big weapons with little room for more, or small weapons with multiple tools to use. When you navigate a level, you aren't told what to do. There is no waypoint or minimap. You're given, usually, a map of the area you're in, markers on that map, a compass, and you set off exploring the world yourself, getting clues and information on your objective as you explore.The skills and augmentations also play a big role in gameplay. Before you start a game, you are shown a skills screen. You can upgrade or downgrade skills at the start to fir the playstyle you want to start building on, whether it be based around stealth, gunplay, or both, it's possible. Augmentations are gained through the collection of Augmentation Canisters. You can find these throughout the game, and each canister has 2 different augmentations. Once you install an augmentation for each body part, you cannot remove it. Through the use of Augmentation Upgrade Canisters, these can be improved, and some body parts have more than one slot (2 or 3), so you can have plenty of different augmentations to choose from and use.TL;DRPros:Amazing musicAmazing level designsCharacters full of lifeHuge range of character customizationGreat storyLarge amount of world interactivityCons:Clunky gameplayMessy graphics (Although fairly good for a game from 2000)Voice acting isn't exactly good, pretty bad at some pointsUnoptimized for modern machines (Not heavily, but some things can fix the little things wrong with the game. Get Deus Exe to fix some of these: http://kentie.net/article/dxguide/)Just buy the game already.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Deus Ex! A Nanopunk/Cyberpunk themed action role playing game, combining first person shooter, stealth and role playing elements.Developed by ION Storm and Published by Eidos Interactive/SQUARE ENIX and designed by Warren Spector and Harvey Smith.Set in a dystopian world druing the year 2052 the plot follows UNATCO Agent JC Denton to combat terrorist forces. As the plot thickens Denton becomes entangled in a dark and deep ancient conspiracy.A game that has received universal acclaim and recieved multiple awards!The games storyline is unmatched by any other, the blending of genres: Role-playing, FPS, Adventure and Immersive Simulation makes this game the greatest of all time. Touches a lot on world affairs and it really takes a hold of you throwing you into dark and deep government conspiraciesGood:-The story is truly amazing it will overpower you!-The gameplay incoporates four genres and it blends together perfectly-Expansive environments with a lot of exploration.-Dialogue and back story improves the overall experience and there are some funny and cheesy one liners from NPCs.-RPG Elements are designed very well-The soundtrack of Deus Ex is flawless! The music really adds to the experience and the atmosphere, with subtle ambient street music to blasting bass/electronic tracks in combat.-Highly replayable I have played through at least 10 times.-The games graphics although not amazing really add to the atmosphere of a dark world which really puts Deus Ex into context.Bad:-Nothing, this game is flawless.There will never be a game in my heart that will replace this masterpiece of a game!Worth the experience, worth the penny, worth playing at least ten times!10 Foxes out of 10 Foxes :D

content:
Posted: December 27, 2010
												This is probably the best FPS of all time. The story is fantastic, and the game plays almost like an RPG with how you level up your character's skills and abilities. The game is also extremely long. It will probably take you 20 hours just to get through it once. The levels are all large and almost sandbox like, with tons of places to explore outside just the mission you are trying to do. The people in the world can also converse with you and give you interesting information. The game supports multiple play styles (Stealth, run and gun, melee), making each experience and playthrough different. It also has several choices that affect what happens, and three different endings. It's simply a masterpiece. Buy it if you don't have it already. If you do have it, play it right now.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2012
												Hands done one of the greatest FPS/RPG mixes of all time, as well as one of the best overall games of all time. Two things make this game especially good: the story and the gameplay. The augmentations that you use to add new abilites really drastically change the ways you can approach situations instead of just adding passive bonuses like most perk-like systems in so many other RPGs. Each problem you encounter has a dozen ways of solving it and can be solved by any type of character build, so each player can play through the game in their own unique style. Combat has this aspect as well, as you level up your skills with different weapon types, so you can play as a sharpshooting sniper or a rocket-launcher weilding maniac. Without having to explain every game mechanic, all you need to know is that the gameplay is deep, complex, and can be enjoyed basically however you want.While the actual plot line isn't the best, it's the underlying themes that really make it stand out. Not a lot of games ask the types of questions that Deus Ex asks. How much control should the government have on the people? If people were left to govern themselves, would the good side of humanity win over the evil side, or is man's hunger for power and control too great? What does it mean to be human? Are machines more perfect than man? It's a very philosophical game, and it's great to see different, distinct endings that aren't black-and-white in their morality, they all present different governing philosophies, and it's up to the player to decide which they think is the best as they play through the game.The only drawbacks to the game are the awful voice acting, dodgy engine and the shoddy graphics. However, if you're going to prevent yourself from playing this game because of the poor graphics (even for 2000) and the engine hiccups, your really shouldn't. Particularly with this game as it's rightfully a classic and should be played by anybody who enjoys RPG's, FPS's, or both.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												   This game...playing this game, I can see why it earned the title "Game of the Year". After playing this game from start to finish (40 Freakin Hours mind you), I can say that I was surprised and interested at the story, the cast of characters, the gameplay, and the music. Deus Ex is one of those games that allows you to do whatever you want. You can either play the game as John Rambo and kill every single enemy in your way, or you can play the game as Snake and take out enemies stealthily. It craves for you to get immersed into the complex story and make some pretty story-altering decisions. This game is an FPS game but there is an RPG element to it as well since you can upgrade your abilities or "augmentations" as the game calls it. The atmosphere of the game is apparent as you hear the music and face multiple adversaries. Overall, this game caught me off guard with the amount of content that it has in store for you, the player.    Let's get into the positives of the game first. Even though this is a 2000 game and the graphics may not look appealing, the positives of the game overcompensate it. In this cyberpunk and futuristic world of Deus Ex, you play a new agent of an organization (called UNATCO) named JC Denton. You will find that JC and the various people throughout this universe are "augmented", meaning that they are combined by the powers of nanotechnology. He has a brother named Paul Denton, and both of you are taught that you are a part of UNATCO, the organization that brings peace to the world of 2050! Even though JC and Paul are trained in combat and have massive amounts of knowledge on the world of Deus Ex, they do not know one thing: their past. Without spoiling the game, the truth hits them right in the face and they are forced to trust their instincts and make some risky decisions. The story of the game is complex, for there are many characters, many organizations to explore, and many twists to understand. The game gives you options that can make you make your own story in the game and this becomes extremely critical when you have to decide between three different resolutions for the end of the game.   The gameplay of Deus Ex is a lot of combinations. Like I said, you can play the game as Snake and stealthily kill people with your silenced weapons. Or you can play the game as John Rambo and explode people with your GEP gun (You'll know what that is later when you play this amazing game!). NOT ONLY that, but also there are other features such as the ability to hack terminals and computers. Since this is a highly technological world, JC can hack in order to bypass security, obtain key iinformation, and use the turrets and robots to his advantage (If you have the upgrade for it!). There's also a lockpicking mechanism, where JC can automatically open a locked box or chest with one or more lockpicks. You can get essential items by doing this. You can also use melee weapons, assult rifles, shotguns, explosives, pistols and so on! One unique thing is that you can use your augmented powers that you gained. For example, you can super-sprint or you can soak bullet damage! Be careful not to rely on this too much because this uses your energy!!! So as you can see, the gameplay has a lot of factors into it.    The atmosphere of the game is apparent and unqiue. The music is pretty catchy with its electronica influences and it fits with the different and various locals the game has to offer. The developers actually took the time to simulate realisitic email discussions that you can read if you hack or login to a computer. Also, there are "datacubes" that you can read if you find them. Although these seem like minor things, it adds a lot to the information-seeking mentality of the game. The characters you meet throughout the stages add to the atmosphere of the game as well. Hell, you get to chat with augmented people, people who are busy clubbin', gang members, and AIs for crying out loud. The developers definitely did a great job establishing the futuristic atmosphere of the game.   Now that I pretty much said the positives, let's go into the negatives. For one thing, Deus Ex has a weird way of saving data. If you don't know how Deus Ex works, YOU WILL lose hours of content. I'm not even exaggerating.  In this game, DO NOT EXPECT AUTOMATIC CHECKPOINTS, YOU MAKE YOUR OWN CHECKPOINTS!  There is none of the typical checkpoint system we see in most games. For this game, you can save anytime you want and you can make multiple save files if you want. This took time for me to get used to but this is still considered a bit of a negative in my book. Another negative is the inventory system of the game. There are times where I wanted a specific gun but it couldn't fit in my inventory. Deus Ex's inventory system is similar to the Resident Evil 4 inventory system, where everything is based on block space. So if you don't have any more blocks, you don't have service. I don't know but it feels like inventory space fills pretty quickly, especially when you get more than 4 guns or more. The explosive guns take up way too much inventory space and I rarely use them as a result. One last negative is that the AI (I'm talking about the enemy AI not the AIs featured in the game!) are stupid at times. Sometimes they run past you and sometimes, they kill themselves.   Overall, Deus Ex is amazing when it comes to the complex and immersing story, the multiple-sided gameplay, and the unique atmosphere. Some negatives include a weird way to save the game, inventory space problems, and derpy enemy AI. I'm glad I bought this game when it was on sale and this game is definitely worth more than the $4 I paid. If you're looking for a challenge, if you are looking for a unique premise, if you are looking for freedom of choices, then this game is worth trying out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												If you've never played this game before, I really don't know what to say, because it is extremely old as of this writing (2015) and for that matter, it was technically quite outdated already when it came out in the year 2000 (which the reviews at the time noted with gusto). People who wouldn't have liked it back then most probably wouldn't like it now.But if you can get into old games just fine without having played them when they were new(ish), there really is no other game I can recommend as much as this one - assuming that you have an affinity for FPS/RPG hybrids. It still remains my absolute favorite computer game of all time, but I'll spare you the "FGR loves Deus Ex" backstory this time.When it comes to gameplay mods, there are gems like GMDX that make the gameplay feel more modern and competent. Mods like Deus Ex: New Vision and Deus Ex: HDTP enhance the graphics (to ultra-high resolutions in the case of the former), which might make the game more pleasing to some people. And don't forget Deus Ex: Revision, which enhances the map architecture to the limits of Unreal Engine 1.5.Yet for me, while playing the game with ultra-res textures and high-res models is extremely fun, it is only when I play the original game with its outdated graphics and exploitable gameplay functions when I feel right at home.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I first played Deus Ex when it was released on retail way back in the 2000s. I finished it 3 times and now that I can't find the CD any more, I insist on having Deus Ex in my Steam library. Why the fascination?Because Deus Ex was one of those games that really broke the mold. Along with Thief, this game showed that, hey, maybe an FPS doesn't really have to be about shooting. Maybe an FPS can also be an RPG.Deus Ex gives you guns but lets you sneak around enemies instead. It presents you targets to kill but also lets you pacify them diplomatically. It gives you a dozen options and rewards you for taking any one of them. It's a game that gives you an awesome futuristic world and tells you and, instead of telling you to blow it up, the game lets you immerse yourself in it.During a time where many games were mere mortal shooters, Deus Ex stood out as something divine.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												My first exposure to Deus Ex came with the PS2 port back in high school, and I am happy to say, after a few hours of playing the PC version (with the graphics fix that is very, very necessary if you're planning on playing anything other than a slideshow whenever water's around), that my fondness for the game is not due entirely to my nostalgia goggles. The game is by no means a good-looking piece of software, but the atmosphere is brilliantly realized, and the overall feel of the world is absolutely masterfully done. You will certainly want to rebind the controls (especially F12 (which is your flashlight by default) unless you've already changed the Steam screenshot keybind), and it might take a bit of time to get back into the turn-of-the-century control scheme, but this game is well worth revisiting, or visiting for the first time.Rarely does a game feel this cohesive. Glory be, glory be...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												So, I finally decided to play this highly critically and publicly acclaimed game. I´ve installed the high-res mod ( very important IMHO) and started playing.  I was surprised how the game and mechanics are well driven and executed (vs the animation - horrible, but hey, this game is 14 years old!), but what is the most incredible thing on this game are your decisions and their affection on the whole story and gameplay. You can do basically what you can think of, you can do everything very stealthy or rambo style, you can talk your way through and shoot every single madafaka in the head. Now I see why all the fans of the original Deus Ex loved  Human Revolution, because Human Revolution is a very good sequel and it respects it´s predecessor in every way. Now it all makes sense.  I love the story, I love the gameplay (it´s pretty hard though) and I love to search every single bit of each location. There is a good "skilltree", augmentations (that one I screwed up, I´ve chosen some augmentations that I won´t use much) and inventory that doesn´t sucks. I have no idea where I am in the story ( maybe one fourth?), but so far it is very, very good RPG FPS, and I am sure when I will finish it, it will be one of my favorites game of all time, despite the fact that I´ve played it 14 years after it was released :)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2010
												This is probably the best FPS of all time. The story is fantastic, and the game plays almost like an RPG with how you level up your character's skills and abilities. The game is also extremely long. It will probably take you 20 hours just to get through it once. The levels are all large and almost sandbox like, with tons of places to explore outside just the mission you are trying to do. The people in the world can also converse with you and give you interesting information. The game supports multiple play styles (Stealth, run and gun, melee), making each experience and playthrough different. It also has several choices that affect what happens, and three different endings. It's simply a masterpiece. Buy it if you don't have it already. If you do have it, play it right now.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I cannot recommend a game more highly than this one. The adage that whenever anyones mentions Deus Ex you have to re-install it is true, and there is a reason for it. The argument that it is simply nostalgia that keeps people playing holds no ground.While the graphics and AI haven't exactly stood the test of time the rest of the game does not pull any punches or treat the player as if they are anything but smart. The story is deep and long and worth telling. The gameplay is RPG told through the first person perspective, and it refelcts accordingly. Your abilities are limited but progress to your desires.The dystopian cyberpunk vibe is both exhilerating and creepy at the same time. The feeling of 'Oh man I hope the future is this cool' is balanced with, 'Could it really get this bad?' This is the best PC game ever.

												Old but gold. Especially for a game that is over 15 years old.Definitely buy this.  For 7 bucks, you get one hell of a ride as an international cop in a globe-trekking adventure in a mid-21st century world where millions die from an unknown plague and active civil war in 'stable' Western countries push society closer and closer to the brink. Although certain gameplay elements, in particular AI behavior ('Duh, my buddy five feet away just started yelling about cops and started shooting, let me continue my patrol - oh wait it's that cop!') and graphics date the game somewhat, the story and atmosphere/level design rivals that of more celebrated franchises today.

												A true classic that no one should miss out on, especially if you're a fan of the shooter-RPG type element games. This is one of the few games that I beat repeatedly, probably 10 times, since it's release. I always enjoy going back once a year or two to play it again, and it always seems like there's something new or something I've missed in each playthrough. This is definitely on my list of top best PC games out there, and truthfully.. this game did more for me than Half-Life did back in the day (although I enjoyed it as well of course). While the graphics may not look great, those who can look past it will find an amazing game with an addictive RPG-shooter style set-up that can be replayed over and over. This is a TRUE classic, and one that shouldn't be missed. And with such a low price (especially considering how big the game is and how much replay value there is), there's just no way to go wrong. So wait no longer, and play Deus Ex. You won't regret it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2011
												Deus Ex really surprised me, in a good way. I underrated this phenomenal stealth-shooter-RPG hybrid at first, because of the terrible graphics and sound.You play as a cyborg in the future that gets wrapped up in the shadow government when agencies try to seize all government power. The story is built from conspiracy theories. It's ultimately pretty simple, but it works and gives the world an interesting feel.For each problem in Deus Ex, there are many ways to solve it, and many ways to build your character to take advantage of them. You can gun down enemy bases soldier by soldier, or use non-lethal force to sneak in and out with no casualties. There are many viable options, and this is where the game really shines.However, the graphics are horrible (even for its time), most of the music isn't very good, and the voice acting is hilariously bad.I got this really cheap, and I've loved it. I've probably spent a good 40 hours on it, and I can definitely recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												This game, guys. This game. Those screenshots up there? Yeah, that's how dated the graphics are. It was released in 2000. The gameplay, on the other hand, is a standard-setter for the RPGFPS genre. Never played Deus Ex? This is your chance. Get ready to be tactical about your entrances. Plan it out a little before you fire off a shot, or don't shoot at all. You can be stealthy! You can hack that door! You can bash that other one down and shoot people! The Deus Ex series' level design alone sets a standard. Sure, you have exact goals to get to. You have about a dozen ways to get to each one, however, and the harder you have to look, the better it generally is for your health bar.The weapon spread is realistic. Didn't put any points into using that kind of gun? You're going to have to stand there for a while to be able to land your shot, or you'll miss the broad side of a barn in broad daylight. Put ALL of your points into using that kind of gun? Give it about one second. Yep, headshot. I will admit. There is no recharge for your augments' energy supply, nor is there any health regen. You have to find items to recharge your energy, and medkits for your health. But that's part of the charm of these old shooters. You don't just sit there patiently and undo all of your mistakes. You play through it right. Not all that hard to do so, though, they do have some pretty darned easy difficulty settings and a quicksave button. The dialogue is not this game's strong point. Oh well. The story itself is good regardless. The optional objectives, as is the norm for Deus Ex, are highly rewarding to carry out. <spoiler redacted> to complete the optional objective in the first mission and you'll see how lucrative it can be. On a scale of six to potato, this game is... Y2K Standards Raiser. And at the time I'm writing this, it's seven dollars. The campaign will take you a lot longer to beat than I've put into it. It's worth the seven dollars. Did I mention there's an incredible number of mods for it? No? Damn. Best part. There's mods for it.

												This game feels like playing a cyberified Thief: The Dark Project (which is the best video game ever, in case you didn't know).It has similarly expansive levels, where you can choose your own routes and there are plenty of neat things to discover.It has the same open-ended gameplay: you can sneak around and take moments to take down a guard unnoticed, or you can go in guns blazing when your careful plan of infiltration gets foiled.Yes, it also has the same stupid AI and ugly graphics, but the creative level design and the sheer 'immersiveness' of the game makes you forget about them in a few hours.There are some rpg elements thrown into the mix as well (like dialogue trees, different skills to learn or customisable cyberware), which are always fun to play around with.So what are you waiting for? PUT ON A TRENCHCOAT AND FIGHT SOME CONSPIRACIES.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Ignore the cheesy cutscene at the start. Ignore the awful graphics, the dodgy AI, the bugs - just bear with it for the first hour. The first few missions are basically tutorials; a prologue establishing the atmosphere, the sense that you're merely a pawn in a larger conflict, and how you want to play the game. Then, the twist comes and your thrust into a world of conspiracy, corruption, and moral ambiguity. The huge levels and the amount of choices available makes 'Deus Ex' exceptionally replayable also. You may be surprised to find that there are many sandbox elements. There are many areas with large volumes of NPC's who can be toyed with, as well as many hidden nooks and crannies. Exploration will usually reward you with additional story, rare items, or both. Regrettably, these areas only show up after the first mission. Once you get used to the combat, you'll find it smooth. The abundance of open areas means sniping is possibly the most rewarding option of the game. But there are also flamethrowers, rocket-launchers, grenades that can be turned into mines, plasma-rifles, assault-rifles that can also throw bombs, and a LIGHTSABER (well, it's not called that...but it totally is) Plus you can apply upgrades that turn you invisible, regenerate your health, lift heavy objects, see though walls, deploy a remote-controlled missile, and can make you jump like your in 'The Matrix.' Of course, 'Deus Ex' is at heart a roleplaying game - even though it has plenty of FPS and stealth elements. Unlike 'System Shock 2,' you can pick up any weapon and use it...but you'll be terrible. You'll move like a drunkard if you pick up a rocket launcher untrained, you'll aim like a drunkard if you try sniping, and you'll hit like a drunkard if you try melee. But you can still pick them up in an emergency. (The only thing you can't do untrained is hack computers.)'Deus Ex' is bugged, but whilst it may sound odd, it's bugged in a quirky way that only breaks the immersion if you want it to. You can use mines to climb up buildings to reach places your not supposed to get to until later - which often causes NPC's to completely freak out. You can cheat during boss-battles by setting mine-traps, throwing TNT at them mid-conversation, or just running past them. Enemies won't attack you whilst  in the shower out of politeness, and Paris nightclub guards won't care if you murder someone before their very eyes. Finally, you can get the entire Anti-Terrorism squad to attack a vaccum-cleaner. My advice is play the game straight first time, then spend every playthrough afterwards trying to see how you can turn 'Deus Ex' from serious cyberpunk-thriller into hilarious funland. The recent 'Deus Ex: Human Revolution' is worth your time, but it can't hold a candle to it's grandfather. Whilst it might seem uninuitive and difficult to begin with: stay with it. You will be rewarded with one of the best games ever made.

However, let me try.Deus Ex is full of wonderful dialouge, multiple approaches to combat, and situations that literally left me short of breath. The pacing is perfect, with the more political segments unraveling at just the right moments to make you question everything, and the fights making your heart race. I played this game first on the PS2, where it was called Deus Ex: Conspiracy Theory, and it was one of the first games to make me think about my beliefs. I questioned a lot of things after playing certain parts of this game. And I love it for that. It's not just a shooter. It's not just an action game. It's beyond that.I highly recommend this game if you want a fun, tricky, compelling game that will not just stay in the background. It jumps out at you and grabs your brain. Be prepared.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2012
												If you haven't played Deus Ex, don't play the new one. I mean, play the new one. Just play this first. You can skip part dieux.DX is an RPFPS, and really pretty much the best one there is, even to this day. The controls are good, the voice acting is really quite good for the time, and the graphics are still passable (at the time they were so good that this game came with my 3D Prophet 2 Ultra).As far as gameplay, I have no complaints. This game is so open-ended that you can figure things out accidentally without finding the clues that are meant to help you solve the puzzles. Don't know the access code? Go ahead and brute force that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥; You'll hit it eventually.That made me remember my one complaint: no journal. You need a notebook with you to write down clues and access codes. Or an eidetic memory. That could also work.Anyway. Deus Ex gets a solid A from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2013
												The game that made me question my country and government. (lol)If you can get past the old graphics (Which I frankly love), I'd say give this a shot.The game is set up around real-world governement conspiracy theories, which makes it all the more interesting, about groups like MJ-12, the Illuminati, etc and how the play their "secret hand" in the decisons that are ultimately made by all governments. It even goes deep with rumors as to what is actually happening at Area 51 based off of what has been found so far by the populace and leaked.The combat style is old school (Game is from like 2000, don't expect stuff from Metro etc.) and the AI can be pretty funny at times, not to mention the voice acting on some of the forign charecters will make you laugh to no extent, but thats since they used who produced it to do the voice acting since they didn't have enough to hire etc. And it does take some getting use to, you have your skills. (Heavy Weps, Small Arms, Knives, Hacking/Computers, Swimming etc) and you level them up by spending points you get for progression through the games storyline and by completing side missions and finding little secret areas in game. accuracy is debated by how long you let the reticle focus in on your crosshair, if its far from it, you will likely miss, as to the oppisite, you'll hit directly where you're looking at. Higher your skill with that said wep, faster it closes in for that accurate shot.You can mod your weapons, and this has the oh so great augmentation of your char. (Such as cloak, spybot, Aqualung, Ballistic Shield etc) to make you be able to play this silent in the shadows, or the brute who goes out blasting (If you try to be the brute against bots.. Well, I'll let you learn yourself. Same with commandos :)  )This game is linear, to a point. But the enviroments are huge, with lots of hidden secrets. What you do drastically changes others views on you, and how the story progresses. Some events happen no matter what, but most can be changed and affected by you.My opinion? A must play. The story in this is comparable to none in terms of depth, immersion, and wanting you to re-play to see what would've happened if you chose a different solution. I can't tell you how many times I've replayed this since honestly I lost count. This game never ceases to bore me, I somehow always get sucked in to it because of the amazing stories in it. The combat though not sounding exciting, fits this game very well. It takes getting use to, but it is very damn fun.Oh, fun fact. Example of some of the insane weapons in this game: A grenade that turns robots AI against their opponents. This effect persist throughout that whole level, HR it did not. You can also hack terminals and turn turrets onto your side as well. Very, very fun for setting up traps or making a group of people just go cray from their turret randomly opening fire on them. xDOh, also. This beats Human Revolution by far.. I enjoyed it, but this is soo much better. You may not think so, but the story and gameplay in this (FOR ITS TIME) was too damn good to ignore. HR's is predictable and not really dependent on choice, instead of the illusion that you have an impact on the actual ending.. this doesn't have the illusion, it impacts.Must try, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Possibly my favourite game of all time. An incredibly deep, immersive FPS/RPG with a rich story, memorable characters and an amazing variation on playstyles. I have completed this game so many times I have lost count, yet each time I discover something new that I hadn't seen before. The games dialogue reacts to everything you do, whether you kill people on sight or simply knock them out, whether you remain hidden or run out in plain view, obey orders or find your own way, how much exploring you do, how much you interact with others. Each time changing the dialogue and story in subtle ways. It's stealth system was one of the most robust for it's day, very much focussing on sticking to the shadows and staying low behind cover. However you may decide to become a literally bulletproof death machine, wielding rifles, swords, rocket launchers and more with equal ferocity.Definitely worth the purchase. A classic game with a mature, well researched story on the possible future.

												TL;DR~  Look past the dated graphics and play it like an RPG.  GET IT.This is a game that I've owned several times since 2001, but I could never get into it. I decided to play this after getting it in a Deus Ex bundle,  and holy crap I was surprised.  The game I remembered was a clunky shooter with crappy guns... ( Honestly, I felt the same way about Mass Effect when it first came out.  )  I see now that it's an inteligent rpg with an action mask.   I was rewarded for being cautious, investing skill points in non-combat abilities, and using non-lethal approaches.  Also, the story is actually good~

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												An absolute classic, and far superior to its sequels.Brilliantly realised future with a fantastic level of detail and actual choice.Well realised and belivable characters make progressing through the story a real joy.This is really hammered home when compared to the generic and non-fleshed out bad guys of the more recent DE3.DE also does a good job of not patronising the player. Compare DE's blueprints and compass with DE3's great big *%£$ destination arrow. The fact everything isn't over simplified and handed to you on a plate makes success in DE a far more satisfying affair than it's more pretty but shallow and obnoxious sequels.The graphics are old and the game can be glitchy, but this does not take away from this real masterpiece of a computer game. I long for a modern iteration that follows the spirit of DE and not just lip service!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												This game feels like playing a cyberified Thief: The Dark Project (which is the best video game ever, in case you didn't know).It has similarly expansive levels, where you can choose your own routes and there are plenty of neat things to discover.It has the same open-ended gameplay: you can sneak around and take moments to take down a guard unnoticed, or you can go in guns blazing when your careful plan of infiltration gets foiled.Yes, it also has the same stupid AI and ugly graphics, but the creative level design and the sheer 'immersiveness' of the game makes you forget about them in a few hours.There are some rpg elements thrown into the mix as well (like dialogue trees, different skills to learn or customisable cyberware), which are always fun to play around with.So what are you waiting for? PUT ON A TRENCHCOAT AND FIGHT SOME CONSPIRACIES.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2012
												+Great Story+Good Voice Acting+Awesome Atmosphere+Good Level Design (multiple options of attack and traverse)+Great Varied Gameplay (stealth/action/conversation)+Great RPG Elements (skills, augmentations, items, side missions)+Lengthy-Weak GunplayI consider this the best game to date with no nostalgia clouding my judgement as I play it often.  New players will find the graphics dated and the gunpay horrendous, but everyone should really give this game a chance as the game sucks you in to its story, world, and missions with ease. content:
Posted: October 30, 2013
												The original great immersive rpg game with a fantastic story. The entire world is dangerous. Its easy to die, but easy to live to. And the range of interactions with the world, simply fantastic. Choices are also less linear than most present day rpgs. I remember being shocked when i realised that some characters did not "have" to die if you manged to save them (often a difficult task), or you did not "have" to kill them, and whether they did or not changed the future plotting (and to a decent degree by todays standards).To date, only Witcher II offers greater plot choice pathing than Deus Ex. And to date only Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines managed to improve on the social interaction aspect and character development. Sure some of you are going to say bioware, blah blah, and they do do a good job, but its not quite the same when its characters in your own party that are falling all over themselves with development, and yet that development often has little or no impact on the overall plot. I prefer the NPC's (who are the obstacles or aid to the plot) to be the developed ones. And you will find this in Deus Ex.This game still remains one of the best, despite the dated graphics and dated 1st person persepctive (We all know the camera from just behind is the best view so you can actually see all the cool gear, and cool moves that your character does :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Deus Ex is both my favorite game and arguably the greatest PC game of all time. It appears frequently at or near the top of best ever lists by both journalists and the gaming public. It was ranked #1 of the top 100 PC games of all time by PC Gamer, PC gaming's most widely respected publication.These accolades are no surprise when one sees how brilliantly the game succeeds on so many levels. The story is a masterfully crafted, globe-hopping cyberpunk adventure through which the player's character navigates a dystopian future world on a mission to unravel a Gordian Knot of conspiracies, secrets and lies. Both the player's character and the world he inhabits are shaped by nanotechnology, the former for better, the latter for worse. The player assumes the role of JC Denton, an agent of UNATCO, an international anti-terrorism organization. The terror he combats is largely attributable to the Gray Death, a nanomechanical virus that has ravaged the planet. Denton, however, is immune to the virus thanks to nano-augmentation, a cutting-edge technology available only to elite government agents. Nano-augmentation endows Denton with an array of superhuman powers such as infrared vision and invisibility. Augmentations may be customized to suit a particular playing style, for example stealth artists may opt for the footstep-silencing lower body augmentation while aggressive circle-strafing gunners can choose increased speed. The game's augmentations perfectly complement the open-ended design that is its greatest feature of all. Every level features secret areas for circumventing enemies, gathering intel or finding resources. These avenues might be accessible only with certain abilities, for example a fence might be surmountable only to players with the speed-boosting aug that allows them to leap it or the strength-boosting aug that allows them to stack enough heavy crates to climb it. Every mission can be approached in multiple ways using stealth, force, diplomacy or a combination of the three. The story itself actually adapts to the ramifications of the player's approach to the missions. The game is so open-ended, in fact, that there are only two required neutralizations. It can played as a straight-up run-and-gun shooter, a sneak-through-the-shadows stealth adventure or anywhere in between. Further complementing the open-ended gameplay is the RPG-style stat system in which players can develop proficiency in certain weapons or skills such as hacking, lockpicking, or even swimming. This level of freedom was unprecedented in shooters at the time of the game's release. Before, such games would tell the player  "Go here, do this." Deus Ex, through the very end, asks: "What do you want to do?"Deus Ex is superb in other areas as well: There is a great arsenal of weapons both lethal and non-lethal, familiar and futuristic. A favorite of many is the nano-edged sword, which when combined with footstep silencing aug, is immensely fun to assassinate enemies with. The weaponry is so well-integrated with the augmentation and skill systems that by the end of the game the player feels like a techno-deity. Although the story veers rather outlandish at times, the game never stops encouraging players to think skeptically. The graphics, from an artistic standpoint, convey the game world's bleakness very effectively. The game is set entirely during dusk and nighttime; blues, blacks and grays feature predominantly in its palette. The soundtrack never feels incongruous with its setting and the theme music is one of the most memorable in gaming history.Deus Ex is not a technically perfect game. Its graphics were somewhat dated at the time of release, the foreign accents are hilariously bad and the boss fights are a drag (though all but two are optional). These flaws do not detract, however, from what a monumental achievement this game is. Deus Ex may not be the most technically polished game of all time, but it is among the most influential. Doom and Wolfenstein 3D established the first-person shooter as a genre, but Deus Ex elevated it to an art form. This was accomplished through its ingenious fusion of role-playing elements with familiar shooter conventions, giving birth to a new genre: the action RPG. The action-RPG has become one of today's most popular genres; echoes of Deus Ex can be seen everywhere, from the decision-trees of the Mass Effect trilogy to the plasmids of BioShock.Any game as influential as Deus Ex must be considered a classic, but to call this game a classic is almost an understatement. The defining aspect of video games as a medium is interactivity, and interactivity is maximized when the player is granted as much freedom to shape their role within a game as possible. Deus Ex fostered this freedom to the utmost degree. Deus Ex was not only the instantiation of a new genre, it was and remains to this day, the highest instantiation of what a game can be.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Deus Ex! A Nanopunk/Cyberpunk themed action role playing game, combining first person shooter, stealth and role playing elements.Developed by ION Storm and Published by Eidos Interactive/SQUARE ENIX and designed by Warren Spector and Harvey Smith.Set in a dystopian world druing the year 2052 the plot follows UNATCO Agent JC Denton to combat terrorist forces. As the plot thickens Denton becomes entangled in a dark and deep ancient conspiracy.A game that has received universal acclaim and recieved multiple awards!The games storyline is unmatched by any other, the blending of genres: Role-playing, FPS, Adventure and Immersive Simulation makes this game the greatest of all time. Touches a lot on world affairs and it really takes a hold of you throwing you into dark and deep government conspiraciesGood:-The story is truly amazing it will overpower you!-The gameplay incoporates four genres and it blends together perfectly-Expansive environments with a lot of exploration.-Dialogue and back story improves the overall experience and there are some funny and cheesy one liners from NPCs.-RPG Elements are designed very well-The soundtrack of Deus Ex is flawless! The music really adds to the experience and the atmosphere, with subtle ambient street music to blasting bass/electronic tracks in combat.-Highly replayable I have played through at least 10 times.-The games graphics although not amazing really add to the atmosphere of a dark world which really puts Deus Ex into context.Bad:-Nothing, this game is flawless.There will never be a game in my heart that will replace this masterpiece of a game!Worth the experience, worth the penny, worth playing at least ten times!10 Foxes out of 10 Foxes :D

Posted: May 13, 2015
												For as dated as a game this is, BUY. IT. NOW.Firstly, the combat is not very good. But who even goes out and releases fire in a game like this? If you want to do that, then play DOOM. (My all time favorite game.) It's even more fun to play it stealthily. Yes, the AI is dumb and will do the whole "HUH? I HEARD SOMETHING." thing. But at least when one guy detects you, it's only them and not every other person in the room, their wives, their children, their pets, the grandchildren, Kermit the Frog, etc. (Unless he presses that dang alarm.)Also, the RPG elements play a good role in the game. When you learn how to use a pistol better, you don't get crap like just plain higher damage. You actually get stuff that would make sense, like faster reloading and quicker aiming down.The story is great. I won't leave any spoilers, but it left me leaning forward in my chair.For the graphics, you can fix them with the HD mods and such. Also, make sure to fix the framerate issues in those mods by putting on VSync and such.But the one thing that I will say is somewhat critical to this game, is the voice acting. "MISTAH JAY SEAH DENTAWN. IN DA FRESH. AS DAHK AND SEWIOUS AS ID BRUDDAH."So, I'd say it's a 9/10, despite how aged and flawed it is. Just buy it. BUY IT. It's one of my favorites. Deus Ex is Deus Excellent.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2012
												Hands done one of the greatest FPS/RPG mixes of all time, as well as one of the best overall games of all time. Two things make this game especially good: the story and the gameplay. The augmentations that you use to add new abilites really drastically change the ways you can approach situations instead of just adding passive bonuses like most perk-like systems in so many other RPGs. Each problem you encounter has a dozen ways of solving it and can be solved by any type of character build, so each player can play through the game in their own unique style. Combat has this aspect as well, as you level up your skills with different weapon types, so you can play as a sharpshooting sniper or a rocket-launcher weilding maniac. Without having to explain every game mechanic, all you need to know is that the gameplay is deep, complex, and can be enjoyed basically however you want.While the actual plot line isn't the best, it's the underlying themes that really make it stand out. Not a lot of games ask the types of questions that Deus Ex asks. How much control should the government have on the people? If people were left to govern themselves, would the good side of humanity win over the evil side, or is man's hunger for power and control too great? What does it mean to be human? Are machines more perfect than man? It's a very philosophical game, and it's great to see different, distinct endings that aren't black-and-white in their morality, they all present different governing philosophies, and it's up to the player to decide which they think is the best as they play through the game.The only drawbacks to the game are the awful voice acting, dodgy engine and the shoddy graphics. However, if you're going to prevent yourself from playing this game because of the poor graphics (even for 2000) and the engine hiccups, your really shouldn't. Particularly with this game as it's rightfully a classic and should be played by anybody who enjoys RPG's, FPS's, or both.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2013
												The game that made me question my country and government. (lol)If you can get past the old graphics (Which I frankly love), I'd say give this a shot.The game is set up around real-world governement conspiracy theories, which makes it all the more interesting, about groups like MJ-12, the Illuminati, etc and how the play their "secret hand" in the decisons that are ultimately made by all governments. It even goes deep with rumors as to what is actually happening at Area 51 based off of what has been found so far by the populace and leaked.The combat style is old school (Game is from like 2000, don't expect stuff from Metro etc.) and the AI can be pretty funny at times, not to mention the voice acting on some of the forign charecters will make you laugh to no extent, but thats since they used who produced it to do the voice acting since they didn't have enough to hire etc. And it does take some getting use to, you have your skills. (Heavy Weps, Small Arms, Knives, Hacking/Computers, Swimming etc) and you level them up by spending points you get for progression through the games storyline and by completing side missions and finding little secret areas in game. accuracy is debated by how long you let the reticle focus in on your crosshair, if its far from it, you will likely miss, as to the oppisite, you'll hit directly where you're looking at. Higher your skill with that said wep, faster it closes in for that accurate shot.You can mod your weapons, and this has the oh so great augmentation of your char. (Such as cloak, spybot, Aqualung, Ballistic Shield etc) to make you be able to play this silent in the shadows, or the brute who goes out blasting (If you try to be the brute against bots.. Well, I'll let you learn yourself. Same with commandos :)  )This game is linear, to a point. But the enviroments are huge, with lots of hidden secrets. What you do drastically changes others views on you, and how the story progresses. Some events happen no matter what, but most can be changed and affected by you.My opinion? A must play. The story in this is comparable to none in terms of depth, immersion, and wanting you to re-play to see what would've happened if you chose a different solution. I can't tell you how many times I've replayed this since honestly I lost count. This game never ceases to bore me, I somehow always get sucked in to it because of the amazing stories in it. The combat though not sounding exciting, fits this game very well. It takes getting use to, but it is very damn fun.Oh, fun fact. Example of some of the insane weapons in this game: A grenade that turns robots AI against their opponents. This effect persist throughout that whole level, HR it did not. You can also hack terminals and turn turrets onto your side as well. Very, very fun for setting up traps or making a group of people just go cray from their turret randomly opening fire on them. xDOh, also. This beats Human Revolution by far.. I enjoyed it, but this is soo much better. You may not think so, but the story and gameplay in this (FOR ITS TIME) was too damn good to ignore. HR's is predictable and not really dependent on choice, instead of the illusion that you have an impact on the actual ending.. this doesn't have the illusion, it impacts.Must try, you won't regret it.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												This game is a thumbs up. The various locations build a great cyberpunk world. Despite being 15 years old, I'd still say the game looks great. Many of the buildings you come across will be burned into your memory. The music is very, very good and only adds to the already top notch cyberpunk atmosphere. The amount of freedom you're given in your choices and paths you take is staggering for a game so old.It's not without some flaws though. The story gets borderline silly with the amount of conspiracy mumbo jumbo thrown in seemingly just for the sake of being conspiracy mumbo jumbo, the voice acting is downright horrid, and the final boss fight is a bit of a let down. Despite the story shortcomings, it still manages to ask some tough questions about ourselves. Eventually you'll have to come to your own conclusions, and it's there where this game truly shines.
