number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												A lot can be said about Deus Ex. One could mention its fantastic soundtrack or its incredible atmosphere/worldbuilding, but that would barely be scratching the surface. Deus Ex's story, in my mind, delivers a powerful message which actually puts itself forward well, and without using the incredibly flawed comparison of augmented individuals to represent oppressed groups which later games in the series tried. It is truly a story of conspiracy, class division and espionage at the highest level of government that really isn't to be missed.Deus Ex is the definition of cyberpunk, and to this day I've never seen a game pull that theme off with such grace and faithfulness to the originators of the genre (namely William Gibson's excellent novel Neuromancer, which I would reccomend to any fan of Deus Ex). I'm not here to write an in-depth pros and cons list about this game, just to sing its praises along with so many others really. Looking past its semi-wonky gameplay and the incredibly dated graphics, Deus Ex is a classic which everybody deserves to experience at least once. If you've ever even passingly considered yourself a fan of cyberpunk, be it from Shadowrun, the Matrix or anything else, play Deus Ex. If you've ever seen somebody playing it and thought to yourself that you might enjoy it, play Deus Ex. No matter who you are, there are very few circumstances under which I would not advise you to play Deus Ex. One of the most deep, interesting, complex stories I've ever experienced in a video game, and all for £5, even when it's not on sale. Icarus!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												The 1990's culminated in three monumental titles that undeniably would shape the FPS adventure genre for years to come: Half Life (1998), System Shock 2 (1999), and Deus Ex (2000).Deus Ex was doubtlessly ahead of its time and shares a great deal of the qualities that made Half Life and System Shock 2 superb. Deus Ex's story is about the choices individuals make concerncing technology, and how those technological choices alter the future in positive and negative ways.Everything I want in an FPS adventure is present in Deus Ex: The story is intriguing, the gameplay has depth, and the soundtrack is phenomenal. If you are looking for an old school FPS adventure, Deux Ex is definitely a top choice. There is an easy to use mod that updates the graphics and smoothes them out significantly - highly recommended!9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I cannot express how much I absolutely love this game. This game is a classic it was ahead of its time, I love the gameplay and the mechanics. This game also has a interesting story to it and it is the FPS I have ever played. This game kinda reminds me of Batman Arkham Asylum in some aspects. You can sneak and hide in the vents and stealthly pick off your enemies one by one. You can distract enemies by making noise and throwing objects. You can also hack computers, use lock picks on doors, and blow up doors. Deus Ex gives you lots of choices to accomplish an objective. The way you kill is also a factor. You can use melee weapons, pistols, heavy guns, and sniper weapons. You can actually increase you effectiveness with using these weapons by raising your experience level in them. I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a very good classic game.

												Literally one of the best video games I've ever played. It combines stealth, RPG, cyberpunk, and action so perfectly. Simply running around and talking to strangers is a lot of fun, let alone sneaking through facilities, hacking into computers, and reading nearby databooks. Only problems is that the voice acting is a little cheesy and I can sometimes get really lost. Also, I know you're suppose to use stealth, but my God, it'll take you twenty rounds of assault rifle ammo to his skull to even dent an enemy's health bar. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												One of the best games I have ever played. Solid 10/10.As a person who finds it hard to get into dated games that I don't already have a nostalgic attachment to, I found I had no problem with Deus Ex. The dated combat and graphics become endearing after a while and it doesn't really bother me. The areas still look visually pleasing despite the graphics, especially Hong Kong, which is probably my favourite area. The  actual gameplay brought me some of the most fun I'd ever had in a video game - it's quite challenging, depending on how lethal you want JC to be, and it makes you think, not just gun people down (although it's quite tempting to just throw grenades at everyone and go crazy). As for the story, it's well written and interesting, full of great characters and unexpected twists, and it presents you with a tough choice at the end. The Deus Ex soundtrack is also absolutely gorgeous - it's definitely one of my favourite game soundtracks.I cannot recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												An absolute classic, and far superior to its sequels.Brilliantly realised future with a fantastic level of detail and actual choice.Well realised and belivable characters make progressing through the story a real joy.This is really hammered home when compared to the generic and non-fleshed out bad guys of the more recent DE3.DE also does a good job of not patronising the player. Compare DE's blueprints and compass with DE3's great big *%£$ destination arrow. The fact everything isn't over simplified and handed to you on a plate makes success in DE a far more satisfying affair than it's more pretty but shallow and obnoxious sequels.The graphics are old and the game can be glitchy, but this does not take away from this real masterpiece of a computer game. I long for a modern iteration that follows the spirit of DE and not just lip service!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2010
												This is probably the best FPS of all time. The story is fantastic, and the game plays almost like an RPG with how you level up your character's skills and abilities. The game is also extremely long. It will probably take you 20 hours just to get through it once. The levels are all large and almost sandbox like, with tons of places to explore outside just the mission you are trying to do. The people in the world can also converse with you and give you interesting information. The game supports multiple play styles (Stealth, run and gun, melee), making each experience and playthrough different. It also has several choices that affect what happens, and three different endings. It's simply a masterpiece. Buy it if you don't have it already. If you do have it, play it right now.

												There are plenty of genres where you could lament the absence of good games and the FPS genre is certainly not one of them. There are however few games much like Deus Ex and this is a real shame. Deus Ex not only makes an excellent and lengthy FPS, it makes for an excellent and deep story driven RPG experience too. content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Old but gold. Especially for a game that is over 15 years old.Definitely buy this.  For 7 bucks, you get one hell of a ride as an international cop in a globe-trekking adventure in a mid-21st century world where millions die from an unknown plague and active civil war in 'stable' Western countries push society closer and closer to the brink. Although certain gameplay elements, in particular AI behavior ('Duh, my buddy five feet away just started yelling about cops and started shooting, let me continue my patrol - oh wait it's that cop!') and graphics date the game somewhat, the story and atmosphere/level design rivals that of more celebrated franchises today.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Exceptionally great game. When the first level of the game has like 5 different ways to approach it, is filled with multiple secrets and npc dialogue, you know you got a great game. The variety of how you want to do each level is astounding. You can go loud and lethal and kill everything in site (including your allies), or you can do what I did and take the stealth/non-lethal approach and just knock everyone out. You can literally beat the entire game without killing a single person. Hell, some levels you can avoid interaction with other units entirely. You can just stealth your way through. Weapon variety is good, but what makes it unique is that some weapons have multiple ammo types allowing for interesting diversity. Really fun stuff. Just all around awesome game with tons of replay value and a plethora of content for the price. Still holds up today and is generally better than most games out right now. And just for the record, to those saying that the voice acting can be racist. That's not true. Accents are based on nationality, not race. Chinese, German and Russian are not races, they are nationalities. So saying it's racist to have someone with a crappy, stereotypical German or Chinese accent is just plain wrong.  It's like saying someone doing a New York accent is racist, when New Yorkers aren't a race. :P

content:

The best experience of your lifeThat`s right there the best game ever for PC forever. You can`t go wrong with Deus Ex. No sequel, prequel, clone, inspiration, spiritual successor and whatnot could ever dream to match its supremacy. That is indeed the GOD of games, including every known category and platform.That said, don't ever mod this game. Do not tamper with its currently perfect state. It shall never be rebooted, remastered or re-imagined. Because even those people who did it could ever reproduce the same level of success afterwards. It's like their hands were guided by something else. It is ideal the way it is. Even it's "flaws" were imperative in keeping the cohesion of this piece of artwork.I was blessed with the godsend honor and infinite landscapes of joy by playing this game right on its launch date. Had many playthroughs throughout my life since them. And once I start, I cannot focus in anything else until its conclusion.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2012
												Hands done one of the greatest FPS/RPG mixes of all time, as well as one of the best overall games of all time. Two things make this game especially good: the story and the gameplay. The augmentations that you use to add new abilites really drastically change the ways you can approach situations instead of just adding passive bonuses like most perk-like systems in so many other RPGs. Each problem you encounter has a dozen ways of solving it and can be solved by any type of character build, so each player can play through the game in their own unique style. Combat has this aspect as well, as you level up your skills with different weapon types, so you can play as a sharpshooting sniper or a rocket-launcher weilding maniac. Without having to explain every game mechanic, all you need to know is that the gameplay is deep, complex, and can be enjoyed basically however you want.While the actual plot line isn't the best, it's the underlying themes that really make it stand out. Not a lot of games ask the types of questions that Deus Ex asks. How much control should the government have on the people? If people were left to govern themselves, would the good side of humanity win over the evil side, or is man's hunger for power and control too great? What does it mean to be human? Are machines more perfect than man? It's a very philosophical game, and it's great to see different, distinct endings that aren't black-and-white in their morality, they all present different governing philosophies, and it's up to the player to decide which they think is the best as they play through the game.The only drawbacks to the game are the awful voice acting, dodgy engine and the shoddy graphics. However, if you're going to prevent yourself from playing this game because of the poor graphics (even for 2000) and the engine hiccups, your really shouldn't. Particularly with this game as it's rightfully a classic and should be played by anybody who enjoys RPG's, FPS's, or both.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												What can I say, you'll never find another singleplayer game on steam with as much replayability as Deus Ex.  You'll never find another game with writing on par with Deus Ex.  And you definitely won't find another game that gives you as many options to complete it the way you want, as Deus Ex.  And yet so few of you have it.  Don't let the Unreal Engine 1 graphics scare you, there's more details in this game then 2-3 modern games put together. Kinda sad really, in the 11 years since nobody has managed to come close to its artistry, forget matching or surpassing. The new DXHR will be good in the modern sense, but it won't be able to stand up to this classic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Despite ancient graphics, ancient controls, and simple and by now basically cliché mechanics it somehow stands the test of time. 16 years after its release it is still a fantastic game with an engaging and well-told story, with well-designed levels, and with just the perfect difficulty to both feel challenging to get through just right, yet not impossible to do so.Deus Ex offers a lot of choices. You can play through the game ten times and still approach most of the game's challenges in a different way. Its level design does in that regard surpass most games ever made, and I have to say that the game just does everything... right. There is no level in the game that feels unnecessary, like it doesn't contribute to the story, like it doesn't offer a new kind of puzzle to beat, be it with guns blazing or with trickery.It is a bit of a hurdle to get it to run on modern computers and with today's resolutions, but once past that anyone trying this is in for a glorious ride, and one that anyone enjoying first-person, story-centric stealth (or action) games shouldn't pass on.One doesn't have to play the older Deus Ex games to enjoy the new ones, but they are so good there's just no reason not to. It is digital art.

												Bob Page: Your appointment to FEMA should be finalized within the week. I've already discussed the matter with the Senator.Walton Simons: I take it he was agreeable?Bob Page: He didn't really have a choice.Walton Simons: Has he been infected?Bob Page: Oh yes, most certainly. When I mentioned we could put him on the priority list for the Ambrosia vaccine, he was so willing it was almost pathetic.Walton Simons: This plague -- the rioting is intensifying to the point where we may not be able to contain it.Bob Page: Why contain it? Let it spill over into the schools and churches, let the bodies pile up in the streets. In the end, they'll beg us to save them.Walton Simons: I've received reports of armed attacks on shipments. There's not enough vaccine to go around, and the underclasses are starting to get desperate.Bob Page: Of course they're desperate. They can smell their deaths, and the sound they'll make rattling their cages will serve as a warning to the rest.Walton Simons: Mmm. I hope you're not underestimating the problem. The others may not go as quietly as you think -- intelligence indicates they're behind the problems in Paris.Bob Page: A bunch of pretentious old men playing at running the world. But the world left them behind long ago. We are the future.Walton Simons: We have other problems.Bob Page: UNATCO?Walton Simons: Formed by executive order after the terrorist strike on the Statue. I have someone in place though. I'm more concerned about Savage -- he's relocated to Vandenberg.Bob Page: Our biochem corpus is far in advance of theirs, as is our electronic sentience, and their... ethical inflexibility has allowed us to make progress in areas they refuse to consider.Walton Simons: The augmentation project?Bob Page: Among other things -- but I must admit that I've been somewhat disappointed with the performance of the primary unit.Walton Simons: The secondary unit should be online soon. He's currently undergoing preparations and should be operational within six months. My people will continue to report on his progress. If necessary, the primary will be terminated.Bob Page: We've had to endure much, you and I, but soon there will be order again, a new age. Aquinas spoke of the mythical City on the Hill. Soon that city will be a reality, and we will be crowned its kings. Or better than kings. Gods.10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												“Without leaps of imagination or dreaming, we lose the excitement of possibilities.” (Gloria Steinem)Nowadays, most games are well-polished updates of old games: Beautiful or retro graphics, good stories, new environments, well-rounded gameplay - but without new ideas, without invention, without creating anything of their own.Deus Ex was different.Its developers created something never seen before, something fresh, giving players a degree of freedom and choice in accomplishing their objectives that was unprecedented. They got the graphics, sound, story, and other elements on a par with or better than others at the time, but they did more than just that. The game did not fit into an existing genre, it defined its own, took that evolutionary leap into the unknown that has become so rare in the industry. By now, many other games have followed in its path. But Deus Ex was a groundbreaking title, it was the first of its kind. +1 for taking that leap:  11/10

												**Deus Ex is my top #1 Favorite game of all time. **It wasn't the amazing ambient soundtrack, the well developed characters you meet and interact with, the game breaking RPG elements in the game, the kick♥♥♥♥♥weapons and items you may find, or the fact that you travel around the world in pursuit of your goal....., it was the well written STORY that kept me coming back! 												The _only_ deus ex game, in my opinion. Sure, invisible war has a few fun parts and ideas, and Human Revolution looks shiny and is modernized, but this game is where the series both begins and ends. Fun first person adventury-shooty game that has complex mechanics if you want to use them, but you don't specifically need to use them if you don't want to. I reccomend getting kenties dx10 renderer, new vision, and biomod to play the original campaign. When you're done, get "The Nameless Mod", which is a shining example of HOW TO make a game, and make it GOOD. Human revolution only wishes it could be as good as The Nameless Mod, seriously.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												"If god did not exist, it would be necessary to invent him" Judging by the fact that you are reading this, you have most likely glanced at the game of which this review is about. And you may have noticed the fact the title is partnered with the ostentatious declaration of "game of the year edition". One of my biggest problems with this game is that it does not deserve such a title. A more appropriate accolade would probably have to simply be "Deus Ex: Game of century edition".Yes, that's right, I found a game that's better than Half-life 2, deal with it 2012 me!This is the part where one usually describes what the game is and a bit about the gameplay, but Deus ex has an exception. But, as a rule of thumb, most people classify it under the simple and undeserving title of "FPS", a name unworthy of such a masterpiece. This is due to the seamless blend of RPG elements, Stealth and, of course, First person gameplay of the shooting variety (and no, Fallout 3 is not a "better example" because Bethesda never quite grasped what the words "role-playing" mean, and give out skill points in as plentiful quantities as the loading time in their games due to the excessive consolization that plagues this industry like the Grey death). Of course, the game is much more complex than this, as you are not necessarily limited to sneaking around urban dystopia and secret laboratories. One can simply go in guns blazing (but this usually results in immediate death) or, in contrast, can complete the entire game without killing a SINGLE person whatsoever. The amount of choice and the way it reacts to your decisions is frightenly high.But, nothing is perfect. The gunplay is fairly weak and the graphics and animations are fairly dodgy, due to it running of the already fairly dated unreal engine. The levels, whilst very expansive and well designed, are a bit boxy and bland, even within the context of a ruined 2052 cyberpunk setting. Its true strength, however, lies within its story. Without spoiling too much it revolves around the player, a "nano-augmented" agent (don't worry, it is kind of explained in-game) called JC Denton, who works for UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition), a group formed by the united nations in response to increasing global tensions, including a terrorist strike on the statue of liberty (the game was made in 2000, so it was still perfectly fine to discuss terrorist attacks on New York). But as the player fights the various organizations, he starts to realise there is something very wrong with his overlords, and finds himself a player in a secret war for world dominance. The themes, factions and events in the game are likely from a conspiracy theorist's nutty dream, but simply keeping up to date wiht the state of the world simply provides foreshadowing for the dystopia presented in this game! Whilst most of the exposition and dialogue is extremely well written, its delivery and voice acting is not as refined, simply watch any play through of Hong Kong or Paris to get the idea. But, I suppose there is some charm to hearing Asian triads debate about philosophy in silly accents!On the subject of sound, it is quite obvious that the music does an excellent job of making up for the questionable voice acting. When you first boot up a game and simply get chills from the title screen, you know you've got a gem in your hands! All the the levels have an apprpaite soundtrack that suits them, with seperate themes for ambient, combat, conversations and death. Ah Hong Kong, never again will I be able to go anywhere remotely Asian without feeling like stepping into Wan Chai market for the first time...My final word is that you should absolutely buy this game. It is very cheap ($1.74 in a sale!) and there is simply no excuse for not playing this. There is a well-known phrase that "Every time you mention Deus Ex, someone will reinstall it", but this is complete bullocks because no one in their right mind would ever uninstall it; it is the best 700mb on their hard drive! The point being, this is easily the best PC game, if not the best overall game, ever made. It is really quite sad how no game has ever been able to match it after 14 years in terms of complexity and competency.What a shame...

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												'Deus Ex' is easily amongst the top five RPG games I've ever played. Ancient PC and backwards-compatibility *cough* is a match made in heaven. I'm a bit late to the party but glad I ended this absolute classic. Coming to the game, the environments were expansive, open, involved a lot of running around and backtracking. This was in contrast to Human Revolution which proved to be fairly linear in comparison. Voice-overs were monotonous and emotionless. But I didn't mind it too much as it suits the entire grim cyberpunk-themed setting of the game. HR was no different in this regard either. Mission structures were very well done. Lots of alternative routes to complete objectives. Many games have a broken system but Deus Ex was flexible enough to cater to both playing styles. I liked how you could go full stealth, all guns blazing or settle with a mixture of the two.Exploration rewarded bonus points which were redeemable in the form of skill upgrades. It was virtually impossible to fully upgrade all skills early in the game so my protagonist never felt over-powered at any point. My main gripe was with the augmentations. Apart from a few augs, I never really found any utility for the others and I tried a variety of playing styles. The story was excellent! It was rich but not too convoluted or branched-out as is the norm in RPGs these days. The plot was focused and almost all side missions had relevance to the main storyline. And the story characters were largely interesting, in a peculiar sort of way. Some observations about its prequel, Human Revolution. I like how it stuck to its roots and also fixed many of the original's shortcomings. Hacking, for instance, was a much improved feature and augs were better utilized.In terms of similarities, playing style was appointed at the very start. You get to choose between a knife (if you like hand-to-hand combat) or a crossbow (if long-range is your preferred method). Some unforeseen choices determine the fate of your friends and allies. Boss fights were, again, laughably easy. And not to forget, multiple endings right at the final juncture. I loved this game. Had the option to apply mods to improve the textures and lighting but I chose to play it in its original glory. Even after more than a decade, this game not only holds but has also aged very well.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Finally got around to playing this game, after a couple of false starts. I really found it difficult to get in to initially. I failed to make it through the first level every time I played it. Admittedly the game does start with a challenge, and it continues to be challenging throughout. You really have to embrace stealth until you get some decent weapons and skill points. I recommend the mini crossbow and tranq darts! The game really gathers pace after the first level, the soundtrack is excellent, and somehow the graphics stop being so terrible. Use the light aug in tunnels/airducts and dark areas. Save your game often because you can die really easily and there are no automatic save points - you can save the game at any point you want though. It's really great, I have played it non stop for two weeks and just finished it. I think it will have replay value as well because you are offered so many choices during the game.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												Deus Ex is a cyberpunk FPS aRPG and is largely regarded as one of the best games of all time. Says something about how just how good a game is when the main argument isn't that this was one of the best games ever made, just whether or not it's aged well over time. That Deus Ex is superb, or at least was superb, is completely uncontested.One of the biggest talking points about Deus Ex is that "the graphics have aged". When games like Jet Set Radio, Vagrant Story and Resident Evil Code: Veronica were released in the same year and still hold up to contemporary standards, the argument doesn't hold. Simply that the standards have risen, and so Deus Ex's mediocre art design, and that their environmental modellers clearly bit off much more than they could chew, can no longer ride on the novelty of 3D graphics. They simply did not have the capabilities to bring their vision to life, and instead of making compromises chose to march forward anyway - and that shows.Likewise, that Deus Ex's mechanics have aged into something clunky, doesn't hold weight when mechanically beautiful and smooth games like Rayman 2, Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 and Banjo Tooie were released the same year and are still incredibly fun to this day. System Shock 2, another FPS aRPG, was released a year prior and controls smooth as butter. Deus Ex's mechanics didn't suddenly become clunky, they just always were. Regardless of contemporary comparisons, though, the game still has is fair share of problems. After Hong Kong the game easily starts wearing out its welcome and starts dragging on - even though the story itself goes on a rollercoaster ride. It doesn't help that by the end of Hong Kong, they have introduced and established every single mechanic, weapon, augment, tool, and all bar one of the very limited enemy types, and never elaborate or experiment on them beyond that. For all intents and purposes you just largely do the same thing until the end of the game.Clunky mechanics mean that while the game touts supporting multiple playstyles, a pure Stealth/Pacifist run will outright put you to sleep. Inching along with the world's slowest crawl and using the very limited selection of stealth takedown weapons just isn't fun, it's monotonous and awful. The idea of supporting multiple playstyles that take you through completely different paths through the game also falls apart, because after the first mission or two you'll be outright ransacking every corner of levels -  and are largely expected to, to account for JC Denton's vulnerability and lack of resources.Despite all of this, Deus Ex is rightfully regarded as an incredibly good game that has earned the right to your time.It's Blade Runner, bereft of the emotional dialogue, with equal parts near-future Ship of Theseus-induced existentialism, a timeless narrative of class warfare, and a massive dose of utterly ridiculous conspiracy theories treated as fact. The dramatic voice-acting doesn't hold up ("JC, A BOMB") but the usual cool delivery and rapid-fire discussion of the themes delivers on the premise expertly, with Jay Franke doing a fantastic job as JC Denton. JC Denton is a fantastic example of being a blank slate without actually being a blank slate. The perfect fit for a sounding board for the various political ideologies and conspiracy theories throughout the game, he serves to question and debate the various factions without ever noticeably projecting his own agenda beyond trying to do the right thing.Deus Ex doesn't need perfect graphics, or even fully realized mechanics to be an excellent game - it has managed to cement itself at the higher end of the Wall of Fame with its expertly-directed dialogue, pleasing mechanical complexity and utterly brilliant and satisfying level design that easily remains just as good to this day.And this is why you should buy it and play it right through to the ridiculous end.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2012
												i had just beaten the game. it was amazing, there is (with an exception of a few games) NOTHING that comes close to what this game has achieved. even with its faults, this is one of, if not the greatest games i have ever played. this game proves that even with faults, you can still achieve something so stellar.i am currently undergoing my second playthrough of the game on realistic difficulty with the mods New Vision (makes the games' environments look pretty) and Shifter (adds things that should have been in the game in the first place and fixes allot of bad things in the game), and by god, it is even better. i have currently already poured about 8 hours into the game on my second playthrough, and i am only on the THIRD MAIN MISSION. this game has so much to offer if you go looking for it.on top of that, every decision you make changes the game, from the big things, even to the tiniest detail. for example you can go into the girls bathroom and then get yelled at, and when you go meet up with your boss later on, he will tell you to be careful and stay out of the girls bathroom. but big things can even change what you will do in the next mission. every pretty much playstyle is available in this game. for example so far i haven't killed anyone, and i have mostly relied on melee weapons, but i also have a minicrossbow tranq gun with me. you can be the ruthless killer who kills with nothing but the objects in his hands, or you can be the guy with the silent gun. but you can also be the guy who just wants to go in guns blazing (but it wont be easy), or the guy who picks off enemies from a distance. be who ever you want, where ever you want, whenever you want. mind you, this is not an easy game.so go. go and buy this game. you will not regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												You probably already know why you should buy this game.The branching story.The endless gameplay choice, allowing players to leap between genres from stealth to FPS to hacking simulator and so much more, as well as allowing you to merge these together.The size (this game is huge!).It's cheap and everyone loves it, so the thing preventing you from buying it is probably the barrier to entry that old games often have. I was cautious about this too but, too my surprise, it's not that bad.I would reccommend installing Kentie's Deusexe alternative launcher as it fixes pretty much every problem with modern PCs.Now.Because it's based on player choice, it's usually quite easy to find at least one way to do an objective, so it's not that traditional old game thing of "what the hell am I supposed to do". The game has a handy journal which keeps all important information (codes, usernames etc.) which you find in the levels, so you don't need to remember any of these things. Your objectives and sidequest objectives are also stored here. Sidequests can be found in each individual level, usually off NPCs. Completion of these sidequests gives you Exp, items or tips on ways to complete the main objective.                  Each level is like a mini open-world, with people to interact with, paths to discover and sidequests to find/complete. The paths are mainly straightforward and the levels are designed to cater to any playstyle. I enjoy how NPC interactions, particularly debriefings, change depending on what you do. This is to be expected from this type of game, but not to this level. For example, I shot a barkeep to get some free beer (no, you have an alcohol problem) and I was rebuked for it afterwards, with the boss-man even referring specifically to the bar. It extends beyond even this level. At one point I was rebuked for visiting the ladies' toilet. Now that's attention to detail.               Also, becuase of the fact that the main character is voiced by a dev not a voice actor, the lines are very montone and there is a kind of sarcastic humor (I'm not sure it's intentional) which I just find wonderful.Important tips:Don't go non-lethal on your first run, as I tend to in stealth games. It's much more difficult than in most.Don't do a ghost run on your first runThink before you apply weapon modsThere is a ctrl + c, ctrl + v function that works in the journal so you can copy/paste info.I know this isn't the best review, but I thought I'd give it from the perspective of someone who only started playing this year as most of the ones that I saw were from people who played it back in 2000 and have immense nostalgia.Also, the trenchcoat's pretty good.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Deus Ex is probably best described as a first-person RPG. Set in the near future, you take the role of JC Denton, a nanomachine-enhanced agent working for UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorism Coalition), and set out to foil terrorists and terrorism plots.  I'm not going to spoil the story, but I think in general it's compelling.The gameplay is sublime in that it offers you a variety of ways to approach your objectives, coupled with some of the best level design I've seen in any game. One way of breaking down the game is that you'll receive mission objectives: find this, kill this person, get into this building and so on, but you usually have multiple approaches as to how you tackle them. Deus Ex has you find and use the weapons and tools you find in the environment. In that respect it is familiar ground if you're used to old-school Doom/Quake/Duke Nukem-style first-person shooters. However, unlike those, that primarily focus on the shooting (of course), in Deus Ex it's generally an equally viable option to use stealth and incapacitation to acheive your goals  Or, you can be sneaky in an alternative way and take the cyber warfare route- hack computers to open doors for you if you don't want to look around for the door code, or if you don't have a lockpick to use on it. Your inventory has limited space (think of your items as shapes on a grid that you have to try and slot together as best you can), and the skill points system means that you'll place different emphases on different items. Some will be more useful to some players than others. The skills system is the most prominent RPG element. As you explore places and complete goals, you will earn skill points that can be invested into different skills in order to level them up. Do you want to upgrade your skill with rifles, so it's easier to kill them with a sniper or assault rifle, for instance? Maybe you could use the points to upgrade your hacking abilities instead. Maybe you can use them so that you can heal more health with medkits? Your choice, and in general, neither option is 'wrong'. There's a nice tradeoff between "Do I drop my rebreather so I can pick up the knife?", for instance, and "I've found an underwater passage- I wish I didn't drop my rebreather", if that makes sense. The level design is great, and complements the wide variety of options. For instance, you'll usually find a door code written down somewhere if you aren't able to hack it open. You can usually disable alarms that would attract enemies... Or you can shoot your way through them if you're feeling confident. There's a wide variety of options to access areas in most instances- it is pleasingly complex. Regarding shooting... it's a double-edged sword. Deus Ex has combat in it. It's certainly permissible to upgrade the different weapon types and kill enemies that way, but it's.... I'm trying to think of how to put it.... It's not that it's not a shooter, or you can't play it like a shooter, but it really is not like Doom, for instance, where it's not an option to avoid your enemies, really.The way the weapons work is that you keep your aim on the enemy for a few seconds in order to make the shot accurate. You can find in-game weapon mods that increase clip size, accuracy, add scopes and silencers for instance, but in general it means that if the game becomes a firefight with you and a bunch of terrorists, you will be likely to miss a lot if you keep moving around. This is in contrast to the likes of Doom, that relied on you moving out the way of enemy fire, and never penalised your accuracy for it. Here it's slower, and dare I say, a bit clumsier, because, well, it's just not a straight-up shooter. It doesn't seem to be designed like an FPS, put simply. Basically, if Deus Ex were only a FPS, it would not compare that well to the classic PC shooters- Doom/Quake/Duke Nukem etc. As it stands though, it's a fantastic game, with intricate level design that allows multiple angles of attack, as well as multiple tools and skills that allow you to choose your approach, and by extension, how you choose to play the game, without seeming like you're forced onto one track, the mentallity of "I put points in lockpicking, so I have to keep picking my way through doors each time.". Nope- perfecly feasible to look around for a code if you feel like it. It's a fantastic example of level and gameplay design, Deus Ex. Thoroughly recommend.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												*EDIT* Now that i fully finished the game, i get why it's constantly in the top spot or contending for it on all list of top games, it's purely art. 16 years later with what's now considered crappy visuals, laughable voice acting, ugly combat, it still tops out. There's something magical about it, the story, the constant acts of betrayal, down to the choices you have to make, it was a thrilling and enjoyable ride that i would definetely reccomend to anyone interested in rpgs, fps, or just general story telling. A must own game.Only 5 hours into the game and holy♥♥♥♥♥♥i'm overwhelmed. I kind of regret never playing it before. This game offers pretty much everything you want in a tactical fps whether you want to go head-on combat (Which isn't encouraged by your higher officers) or a full on stealth gameplay with lockpicking, hacking, finding new paths by exploration, negotiating with people, reading notes and so many other ways. Even for a 2000 game in my opinion it still looks nice, the enviroment is well done, the music is great, lots of variety in weapons and items with almost everything having a use. Well, can't wait to see what else this game has to offer, to be updated.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Is DEUS EX the greatest game ever?It might be. Seldom, if ever, has a game blended so well elements of first person shooters, stealth, assassin and puzzle games, all into an RPG with great combat, minigames, and a self-driven narrative. While it is stylistically dated--shades of the MATRIX show throughout--the story is a rich one, and the game has remarkable replay value. Rarely is it ever the same game twice. Play it now, play it again, and live the perfect Cyberpunk RPG. 15 years after it hit shelves, it's still a treasure for gamers everywhere.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Holy christ, I just saw this game on sale for one dollar and seventy-four cents. $1.74. Get it. This game is an absolute gem and a legend within the cyberpunk genre. An early rpg/fps entry that oozes nostalgia and exudes genius. I'm not the best at reviewing games, but there are those hidden amongst Steam that I feel are too amazing not to promote... this is one of them.You play as agent JC Denton, a shiny new nano-augmented agent (successor to mechanically-augmented agents) in a counter-terrorist organization dubbed UNATCO. The secretive politicking and social banter you'll be exposed to can be overheard from enemies mid-conversation, read through security terminals throughout the gameworld, deluged via e-mails sent to your character (as well as other non-player characters, provided you can gain access to their accounts...) will influence how you want to play your character. Do you blindly obey the higher-ups in your organization, or lean toward the ideals of UNATCO's enemy--a 'terrorist' organization calling themselves the NSF.Between the conspiracy theories, feeding homeless kids for intel, jumping on rats, getting turnt on zyme, breaking into storage rooms for bags of soy nuts... there's intelligent humor and timeless music to help you immerse yourself in Ion Storm's take on a futuristic dystopian United States of America.OH AND NOT TO MENTION: REVISION. It's a breathtaking graphical overhaul of the game, provided as a free DLC through Steam. Deus Ex is given a facelift for the 21st century (which goes deeper than mere graphics, mind you) and you're also given the option to play the game with two of it's most famous mods-Biomod and Shifter.Again, I'm no good at reviewing but by all that is holy, you need to pick up this classic masterpiece in PC gaming. $1.74, I still can't believe it!!!Welcome to the coalition, JC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15
												I thought my hours were low in this game until i browsed through the reviews. This game should have won the Test of Time Award last year. 17 years after release the vanilla game is still getting 92% positive reviews. You can't beat it. Then to top the icing on the cake. Say you've beat the game 5+ times (me), and you would like to play it but want a twist on it. Easy. There's tons of fan missions, backstory missions, Graphical upgrades for those of you who don't like the early 2000s graphics. I actually like the graphics myself, but I am going to download the GMDX mod, so it can be a little different this playthrough. Next time, I will do the modded missions. I just don't see myself getting bored with this one any time soon.If you don't own this game and don't mind older graphics, you need this game.If you don't own this game and hate old graphics, you need this game and GMDX.There are other graphics mods but they don't look as polished and GMDX isn't even out of beta yet. Also, GMDX is an entire overhaul for the game, not just the graphics.The gameplay style isn't just your typical FPS. Far from it. You are limited on ammo, you have to find upgrades and there are lots of secret passages. My description is not doing the game justice though. To kill or to incapacitate? Either are very viable choices. The changes that are made are usually very minor. Although you can make a few choices in the game that will cause different outcomes for people.I usually play lethal in this game. I have done non lethal for one or two of my playthroughs.$7. 105 hours and counting. Lots of mods. It's well worth your money. You could probably catch it on sale at some points too, but its more than worth it at full price.BTW, my favorite weapon is the Dragon's Tooth. Once you get it, you will know what I mean.And no, I didn't play the game when it first came out. The first Deus Ex that I played was a demo of Invisible War, then many years later I saw this game had outstanding reviews and it was on sale, so I bought it. This was around 2009 or so.  At first, it was too difficult so I uninstalled after about 30 minutes. Then I gave it another try about a year later.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2011
												A very atmospheric and immersive for a game that was made in 2000, it certainly doesn't show its age, sans the graphics, which look great for Unreal Engine 1.  This game has a vibe kind of like Blade, The Matrix, at least that is how I feel.  The music is absolutely "unreal" and the voice acting is top notch for a game made in 2000.  The game can be played in many different ways and has tons of unlockables.  Very rewarding, I cannot stress that enough.  If you enjoy old school FPS games where the maps were non linear, sidequests were there for fun, and secrets were scattered, this game is most certainly for you and is worth every penny.  Truly an experience like none other.  In other words, BUY IT.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												Deus Ex...wow... Deus Ex, for the uninitiated is one of the best PC games of all time. And, I do mean taht literally, there are only a couple that are better. First things first, every PC gamer needs to play this. So, what is DX? Deus Ex is a stealth RPG from teh late 90s. It (obviously) looks absolutely terrible, but it even looked bad on release. The plot is hokey, featuring the illuminati, nanomachines being used to augment humans into supersoldiers, and artificial plauges. But, for some reason, everyone absolutely adores it. Gamers are universally overcome with nostalgia, and Deus Ex has so much content and "emergent gameplay" (putting things in teh game you don't even know how people will use it or if they can) that like so ew titles these days can have multiple pllathroughs that share nothing more than cutscenes and dialouge. The gameplay an stealth is actually kind of tough, and you will learn to love the quicsave adn quickload buttons. The sound is comically bad in many places too. However, there are some mods, like Deus Exe, HDTP, New vision adn teh upcoming Revision that hep it look acceptable. Seriously, go play it, or maybe watchthe totalbiscuit video on it at least. 11/10

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												This game is the best game of all time. The story is deep and draws from major conspiracy theories (Ex. Illuminate,Chupucabra, The Mothman). As you progress through the game you will gather skill points. All skills have 4 levels:UntrainedTrainedAdvancedMasterThe game is very balanced, until you get a master skill in weapons. You see as you progress in weapons the changes are noticeable but not tremendously game changing, but... once you hit master in a weapons category.... you are GOD. My pistol (as long as I am aiming at somebody) can't miss. I have put 4 accuracy mods (each pumping up the accuracy by 2% I think) and all I have to do is aim above the torso and everybody DIES. There are many skills to talk about, such as lockpicking and bypassing electronics. You can open any door and bypass any alarm as long as you have enough multitools (electronic lockpicks) and enough lockpicks (well um... not-electronic lockpick). But a person who is not trained in the lockpicking and elctronics skills will leave more broken lockpicks and shorted out multitools than a minecrafter leaves behind broken pickaxes and shovels. So investing in those skills is not necessary but it really helps (but a word to the wise NEVER INVEST IN SWIMMING THERE WILL NEVER BE A TIME WHERE SWIMMING IS REQUIRED TO GET TO A OBJECTIVE! IT IS A VERY STUPID IDEA!) However by far the best part about this game is that it has more freedom of choice than any other game out there. There are literally hundreds of ways to solve a objective. Let's say you need to recover sensitive data about your organization.What do you want to do? Do you want to equip your trusty plasma rifle (heavy weapons) and go in guns blazing, or do you want to sneak in and quietly neutralisethe guards, or how about you hack that computer you didn't even know about and flood the entire building with lethal amounts of radiation then equip a hazmat suit and grab the data without ever pulling the trigger, or maybe you bribe that terrorist guard you didn't even know had dialouge and have him gat the data for you. Well what do you choose, I mean you don't have to, you can find your own way in (THAT DOESN'T INVOLVE SWIMMING NICK!) because there are definetly more options that I haven't found yet. Okay you got the data and you ar eleaving the area WHEN SUDDENLY! The terrorist leader appears! As far as you know he is a very bad guy! He has killed friends of yours before and he will probably do so again! He asks for the data and he will kill your brother if you don't give it to him! Now it appears that there are only two options, BUT WHAT YOU DIDN'T KNOW EAS THAT AFTER YOU MAKE YOUR DECISION IN THAT BRIEF TIME THAT HE WAS HEADING TO HIS CAR... you could put a bullet straight through the back of his head. You know the dozen armed men that he broght with him will be SUPER♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥if you did that, but hey you are super badass JC Denton you probably have a way out of this predicament already... or maybe you never got into that situation at all.....

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												"If god did not exist, it would be necessary to invent him" Judging by the fact that you are reading this, you have most likely glanced at the game of which this review is about. And you may have noticed the fact the title is partnered with the ostentatious declaration of "game of the year edition". One of my biggest problems with this game is that it does not deserve such a title. A more appropriate accolade would probably have to simply be "Deus Ex: Game of century edition".Yes, that's right, I found a game that's better than Half-life 2, deal with it 2012 me!This is the part where one usually describes what the game is and a bit about the gameplay, but Deus ex has an exception. But, as a rule of thumb, most people classify it under the simple and undeserving title of "FPS", a name unworthy of such a masterpiece. This is due to the seamless blend of RPG elements, Stealth and, of course, First person gameplay of the shooting variety (and no, Fallout 3 is not a "better example" because Bethesda never quite grasped what the words "role-playing" mean, and give out skill points in as plentiful quantities as the loading time in their games due to the excessive consolization that plagues this industry like the Grey death). Of course, the game is much more complex than this, as you are not necessarily limited to sneaking around urban dystopia and secret laboratories. One can simply go in guns blazing (but this usually results in immediate death) or, in contrast, can complete the entire game without killing a SINGLE person whatsoever. The amount of choice and the way it reacts to your decisions is frightenly high.But, nothing is perfect. The gunplay is fairly weak and the graphics and animations are fairly dodgy, due to it running of the already fairly dated unreal engine. The levels, whilst very expansive and well designed, are a bit boxy and bland, even within the context of a ruined 2052 cyberpunk setting. Its true strength, however, lies within its story. Without spoiling too much it revolves around the player, a "nano-augmented" agent (don't worry, it is kind of explained in-game) called JC Denton, who works for UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition), a group formed by the united nations in response to increasing global tensions, including a terrorist strike on the statue of liberty (the game was made in 2000, so it was still perfectly fine to discuss terrorist attacks on New York). But as the player fights the various organizations, he starts to realise there is something very wrong with his overlords, and finds himself a player in a secret war for world dominance. The themes, factions and events in the game are likely from a conspiracy theorist's nutty dream, but simply keeping up to date wiht the state of the world simply provides foreshadowing for the dystopia presented in this game! Whilst most of the exposition and dialogue is extremely well written, its delivery and voice acting is not as refined, simply watch any play through of Hong Kong or Paris to get the idea. But, I suppose there is some charm to hearing Asian triads debate about philosophy in silly accents!On the subject of sound, it is quite obvious that the music does an excellent job of making up for the questionable voice acting. When you first boot up a game and simply get chills from the title screen, you know you've got a gem in your hands! All the the levels have an apprpaite soundtrack that suits them, with seperate themes for ambient, combat, conversations and death. Ah Hong Kong, never again will I be able to go anywhere remotely Asian without feeling like stepping into Wan Chai market for the first time...My final word is that you should absolutely buy this game. It is very cheap ($1.74 in a sale!) and there is simply no excuse for not playing this. There is a well-known phrase that "Every time you mention Deus Ex, someone will reinstall it", but this is complete bullocks because no one in their right mind would ever uninstall it; it is the best 700mb on their hard drive! The point being, this is easily the best PC game, if not the best overall game, ever made. It is really quite sad how no game has ever been able to match it after 14 years in terms of complexity and competency.What a shame...

												i had just beaten the game. it was amazing, there is (with an exception of a few games) NOTHING that comes close to what this game has achieved. even with its faults, this is one of, if not the greatest games i have ever played. this game proves that even with faults, you can still achieve something so stellar.i am currently undergoing my second playthrough of the game on realistic difficulty with the mods New Vision (makes the games' environments look pretty) and Shifter (adds things that should have been in the game in the first place and fixes allot of bad things in the game), and by god, it is even better. i have currently already poured about 8 hours into the game on my second playthrough, and i am only on the THIRD MAIN MISSION. this game has so much to offer if you go looking for it.on top of that, every decision you make changes the game, from the big things, even to the tiniest detail. for example you can go into the girls bathroom and then get yelled at, and when you go meet up with your boss later on, he will tell you to be careful and stay out of the girls bathroom. but big things can even change what you will do in the next mission. every pretty much playstyle is available in this game. for example so far i haven't killed anyone, and i have mostly relied on melee weapons, but i also have a minicrossbow tranq gun with me. you can be the ruthless killer who kills with nothing but the objects in his hands, or you can be the guy with the silent gun. but you can also be the guy who just wants to go in guns blazing (but it wont be easy), or the guy who picks off enemies from a distance. be who ever you want, where ever you want, whenever you want. mind you, this is not an easy game.so go. go and buy this game. you will not regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Deus Ex is probably best described as a first-person RPG. Set in the near future, you take the role of JC Denton, a nanomachine-enhanced agent working for UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorism Coalition), and set out to foil terrorists and terrorism plots.  I'm not going to spoil the story, but I think in general it's compelling.The gameplay is sublime in that it offers you a variety of ways to approach your objectives, coupled with some of the best level design I've seen in any game. One way of breaking down the game is that you'll receive mission objectives: find this, kill this person, get into this building and so on, but you usually have multiple approaches as to how you tackle them. Deus Ex has you find and use the weapons and tools you find in the environment. In that respect it is familiar ground if you're used to old-school Doom/Quake/Duke Nukem-style first-person shooters. However, unlike those, that primarily focus on the shooting (of course), in Deus Ex it's generally an equally viable option to use stealth and incapacitation to acheive your goals  Or, you can be sneaky in an alternative way and take the cyber warfare route- hack computers to open doors for you if you don't want to look around for the door code, or if you don't have a lockpick to use on it. Your inventory has limited space (think of your items as shapes on a grid that you have to try and slot together as best you can), and the skill points system means that you'll place different emphases on different items. Some will be more useful to some players than others. The skills system is the most prominent RPG element. As you explore places and complete goals, you will earn skill points that can be invested into different skills in order to level them up. Do you want to upgrade your skill with rifles, so it's easier to kill them with a sniper or assault rifle, for instance? Maybe you could use the points to upgrade your hacking abilities instead. Maybe you can use them so that you can heal more health with medkits? Your choice, and in general, neither option is 'wrong'. There's a nice tradeoff between "Do I drop my rebreather so I can pick up the knife?", for instance, and "I've found an underwater passage- I wish I didn't drop my rebreather", if that makes sense. The level design is great, and complements the wide variety of options. For instance, you'll usually find a door code written down somewhere if you aren't able to hack it open. You can usually disable alarms that would attract enemies... Or you can shoot your way through them if you're feeling confident. There's a wide variety of options to access areas in most instances- it is pleasingly complex. Regarding shooting... it's a double-edged sword. Deus Ex has combat in it. It's certainly permissible to upgrade the different weapon types and kill enemies that way, but it's.... I'm trying to think of how to put it.... It's not that it's not a shooter, or you can't play it like a shooter, but it really is not like Doom, for instance, where it's not an option to avoid your enemies, really.The way the weapons work is that you keep your aim on the enemy for a few seconds in order to make the shot accurate. You can find in-game weapon mods that increase clip size, accuracy, add scopes and silencers for instance, but in general it means that if the game becomes a firefight with you and a bunch of terrorists, you will be likely to miss a lot if you keep moving around. This is in contrast to the likes of Doom, that relied on you moving out the way of enemy fire, and never penalised your accuracy for it. Here it's slower, and dare I say, a bit clumsier, because, well, it's just not a straight-up shooter. It doesn't seem to be designed like an FPS, put simply. Basically, if Deus Ex were only a FPS, it would not compare that well to the classic PC shooters- Doom/Quake/Duke Nukem etc. As it stands though, it's a fantastic game, with intricate level design that allows multiple angles of attack, as well as multiple tools and skills that allow you to choose your approach, and by extension, how you choose to play the game, without seeming like you're forced onto one track, the mentallity of "I put points in lockpicking, so I have to keep picking my way through doors each time.". Nope- perfecly feasible to look around for a code if you feel like it. It's a fantastic example of level and gameplay design, Deus Ex. Thoroughly recommend.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												Deus Ex is fun. I played through of this because I like Mankind Divided, then went back to play through Human Revolution, and the next step was naturally to play through the original game again, to see how it holds up.To begin with, on a modern machine (assuming you have an 1080p screen), get New Vision. It doesn't change anything when it comes to gameplay, but it makes sure that you can read the books as the scaling isn't really working with the original game. New vision also improves the textures, so the game looks slightly better. Otherwise you are stuck with low resolutions and some problems with the game being very dark.When it comes to narrative and storytelling, the first Deus Ex is still on pair / actually better than Human Revolution (Mankind Divided is worse). When it comes to choices, it is on pair with Human Revolution. When it comes to action, it is a hair better than Human Revolution and much better than Mankind Divided. The game is playable with stealth (althrough it is very difficult compared to the later installments), you can run around guns blazing, you can go non-lethal and you can go melee. There are a lot of options and choices. The game doesn't really moralizes too much on decisions (like Mankind Divided), so the player can do as it likes.I was actually surprised how good the game still is and how well it aged. Deus Ex is one of the best fps games ever made and I was suprised how well it still holds, after all these years.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												I remember when this game came out back in 2000.  It was around my birthday and I absolutely had to buy the game.  In fact I wouldn't leave my parents alone because PC Gamer, well to put it simply, they said I HAD TO GO BUY THE GAME RIGHT NOW!! haha.  So finally getting them to cave in, I bought the game, went home, and installed it and oh dear god, I lost myself in a world where everything just felt right.  The mechanics, the messages, the feel, the world, hell even the somewhat dated graphics felt good.  That game shed so much light on me on what a game should be.  Graphics were not everything.  Story.  Story was the soul for a game.  And sure I dont have very many hours in the steam version of this game, but if I could bring up my old save files and show you, I would have hundreds.  I think when I did finally stop playing the game for other games, I clocked in nearly 500 hours.  If not more.  I beat the game even on the hardest difficulty.  This game seduced me and sure there were some flaws (seriously which game doesnt have flaws in it) but stop reading this review and go play this game right now!!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14
												(Obviously doesn't represent my actual game time as i spent all of it on the non-steam retail copy)Deus Ex to me is the greatest game ever made.Now that's not to say that it doesn't have its fair share of flaws as no game is ever perfect and they all have their flaws. the graphics even at the time weren't great and were pretty blocky even then, the AI can be really stupid at times and a lot of the foreign voice acting is laughable at best but what makes Deus Ex so great isn't any individual aspect on it's own but the experience as a whole.From one of the most amazing and memorable soundtracks of all time, to one of the best storys in videogame history full of plot twists and memorable characters, to the wide open level design and the sheer variety of gameplay methods to tackle each mission, even to all the different conversation choices that can make a serious impact down the line.It's all these elements combined together that makes Deus Ex truly a one of a kind game that is unlike any other and even  if you are one of the people that can't get past dated graphics and some of the gameplay features, there are plenty of mods out there that can help make the game feel even better.Theres even tons of replay value as well with all the different choices and augmentations that you can take as well as all the secrets that you can find on each level if you look hard enough, i was still finding new secrets years after i finished the game for the first time. Bottom line is if you even have a slight interest in Action/Role Playing/Stealth or just terrific story telling in general then Deus Ex is a game that you must experience

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
												Absolutely fantastic game, one of the definitive titles that comes to mind with the words "Classic PC Gaming"While this game falls far short if you view it as either and FPS or an RPG, it shines when you strip it of a genre and see it for what it is, a unique amalgamation of the two combined with incredible level design, meaningful exploration, a compelling plot, one of the catchiest soundtracks around, and that special voice acting so bad it's charming.While the game feels rather clunky at first, especially if you don't understand how the RPG mechanics affect the combat, this is soon overcome, and JC(your meme-tastic protagonist), will be running at obscene speeds, leaping over giant robots, tanking bullets, breathing underwater, and shooting drones out of his arm. The game has fantastic replay value while taking you linearly through a series of large levels that can be completed in entirely different manners depending on your character build.Absolutely recommend for anyone who likes a quality video game, this one will take 20-30 hours depending on how you play it.

Posted: April 11, 2015
												Whoever excuses himself from playing this by saying that the game "aged badly", needs to rethink their life. Just like HL and SS2 did, DE changed how games were viewed by the public, giving the player a deep and rich story to be involved in, which went from real life politics to conspiracy theories, while revolutionizing with the new RPG FPS genre. Ion storm put all their effort and love into this game, which sadly didn't include all the features that were planned, but still turned out to be one of the best videogames to be released to date.  Whoever wants to know more about the DE universe, look up the Deus Ex bible.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2011
												There are three endings, in which your choice literally determines the fate of the world; it’s remarkable how the writers managed to concoct such a situation from which three very different outcomes could emerge. And it’s genuinely difficult to choose, when the time comes (and unlike a lot of games I could mention, the conditions for each ending are very clear-cut). I went with my gut feeling just as I did the first time I finished the game all those years ago, picking a kind of benevolent dictatorship, which meant turning my back on an old friend. And I felt genuinely bad for betraying him, for derailing his most worthy intentions. When a game can elicit that kind of emotion for a character who is a few lines of code, some sound files and a 3D model, that’s probably about when you’re hitting the magic criteria of art.

												I remember when this game came out back in 2000.  It was around my birthday and I absolutely had to buy the game.  In fact I wouldn't leave my parents alone because PC Gamer, well to put it simply, they said I HAD TO GO BUY THE GAME RIGHT NOW!! haha.  So finally getting them to cave in, I bought the game, went home, and installed it and oh dear god, I lost myself in a world where everything just felt right.  The mechanics, the messages, the feel, the world, hell even the somewhat dated graphics felt good.  That game shed so much light on me on what a game should be.  Graphics were not everything.  Story.  Story was the soul for a game.  And sure I dont have very many hours in the steam version of this game, but if I could bring up my old save files and show you, I would have hundreds.  I think when I did finally stop playing the game for other games, I clocked in nearly 500 hours.  If not more.  I beat the game even on the hardest difficulty.  This game seduced me and sure there were some flaws (seriously which game doesnt have flaws in it) but stop reading this review and go play this game right now!!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2012
												Deus Ex is a cyberpunk RPG with FPS elements... or is it the other way around? The game places you in the shoes of a nano-augmented U.N. super-soldier, fighting terrorism across the globe as you uncover conspiraces around you and secret underground bases literally everywhere. The story takes you through the dark alleyways of New York, the Paris catacombs, the cramped, neon quarters of Hong Kong and the white h- Oh, wait. The levels are huge, littered with bonus items and side-quests for the explorer, and even more context is added when you read the numerous newspapers, books and datacubes scattered around.It's all about freedom of choice. You can go through the entire game without killing anyone, sneaking through each area and pacifying targets with non-lethal means, but you can also play Rambo, running and gunning down enemies with a vast array of customizable futuristic weapons. On the other hand, you could stay perched atop a rooftop and pick off targets with a sniper rifle, or try to smooth talk your way into privileged information. You can also choose whether to enter an enemy base through the front door (probably not a good idea), find an alternate entrance through air ducts, or bypass a locked rear entrance by finding the code or hacking the keypad.The voice acting isn't great, the AI isn't terribly smart and some of the design choices were ill-advised (Swimming and environmental protection, anyone?), but they're easily overlooked. Graphically, it can seem a bit dated (It was made on the modified Unreal 1 engine, after all.), but this is easily remedied with the user-made HD texture pack, DirectX10 Renderer and ENB Series. Aesthetically though, it's gorgeous. It's a world of industrial decay, towering buildings, dark alleyways, a somber castle, an secret world under the city, a grayeard full of secrets, as well as some familiar settings (Hell's Kitchen, for instance, used a reference of the real-world location for its design)Add to that a vast plethora of mods and multiplayer deathmatch/team modes and you've got quite a bit of staying power. Oh, yeah, and the music is awesome.Upon release, this game received universal praise and earned top spots on countless "best games ever" lists, including PC Gamer's. To this day, whenever the game is mentioned, it's re-installed en masse. As revolutionary as Half-Life and highly influential, it's definitely worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: February 16
												First time I played this game, it was back in 2k02 on PS2, and I was clueless how to end this game (I didn't go further than Hell's Kitchen).Gameplay :This game was revolutionnary back in the days, because you could choose HOW to play the game (wants to play stealth, guns blazed, both mixed). And because of that, you always find new things. Even after 100 hours, you'll still find new areas and new histories. The developers put a lot of love in this game.Graphics :The graphics and physics are good for 2k, and it was full of glitches. But still, the gameplay was so good that you passed over the glitches and enjoyed the game.Sound/ambiance :This game has one of the best soundtrack I have ever heard in a video game. The main menu theme is just biblical (fall in love first time I heard it), and other sounds played in different areas of the game are pretty awesome, even scary sometimes.My advices if you want to play it :First levels are kind of easy, and it introduce you to the game. I would recommend to make sure you understand game mechanics before entering Hong Kong. After leaving the Boeing 747, the game's difficulty increase drastically (new enemies, etc...). So, if you feel like you missed something, replay the game at the beginning, and be prepare to go further.If it's your first playthrough, I would recommend this:- At the start of the game, upgrade your skills Computer/Lockpicking/Electronics at Trained. It'll help you to deal easily with most doors/security spots without wasting dozens of Lockpicks/Multitools.-  When Paul Denton give you the choice between 3 weapons at the start of the game, choose the GEP gun (a rocket-launcher very usefull against bots later in the game). You'll find on your way to the UNATCOHQ a mini-crossbow, and a NSF terrorist hold a Sniper Rifle near the main entrance of the Liberty Statue.- Make sure to check every areas to find some stuff : there is a lot of hidden places.- Through the game, I recommend to Master the Rifle skill, because you can OS every humans with an headshot and destroy turrets/cameras with one shoot. After that, upgrade Heavy skill to Advanced. It's necessary because holding the GEP gun make you extremely slow, and Advanced skill remove that slow. I would recommend then to upgrade Swimming/Medicine to Trained once it's done.- For the augmentations, it'll fits your gameplay path. But I recommend to pick these ones : Speed Enhancment for legs, Cloack and Radar Transparency for Subdermal, Regeneration(OP thing)/Aqualung/Synthetic Heart for torso, Spydrone for cranial, and Vision Enhancement for eyes(because your vision is augmented).I really recommend to purchase if you like challenging games.10/10

content:
Posted: September 11, 2011
												Total 'effin classic. Period.You have an epic conspiracy tale that draws heavily upon Cyberpunk themes , like a blend of the X-Files and William Gibson's Neuromancer. Crazy rogue A.I.s? Check. Illuminati style conspiracies with century old roots? Check. Alien Autopsies in the basement of top secret military installations? Check.It's an FPS primarily but with a heavy dose of RPG. You will be finding and unlocking upgrades for both your characters augmented abilities and your weapons. This allows you to enhance your character towards the prefered path you take through the game. Whether you hack, stay in the shadows, or go guns blazing you'll find an element of the levels to meet your needs. Choice is the word, and for the most part every choice is fleshed out very well. However, gunplay is a bit wonky without enhaning your aim abilities, but for those worried stealth is really well done and feels fair. Nothing beats hacking a turret into killing the guards for you though.
