number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Deus Ex is a classic of gaming, often considered the greatest PC game of all time. While I would give Thief II that honor, it's not hard to see why this game tops so many "best of" lists, and it's one of my personal favorites. This game may also be one of the best examples of why you shouldn't judge a book by it's cover, as it looks like absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ with freaky-looking human models, blocky levels, barf-inducing textures, and subpar voice acting. However, if you can get past all that, you'll quickly find that this game is something special. Deus Ex appears to be an FPS on the surface, but it's really an FPS-RPG. Throughout the game you acquire skill points that you can use to upgrade your skill with certain weapon types (pistol, rifle, heavy, etc.) You can use any weapon you find and have room for, but to be even remotely competent with them, you'll have to upgrade the respective skill, which increases damage and accuracy, and occasionally adds some other benefits. There are also other skills you can upgrade, such as Computer, which allows you to hack ATMs for money and security terminals to deactivate cameras and reprogram turrets, and Lockpicking, which decreases the amount of disposable lockpicks you need to open a door. The great thing about Deus Ex is that there is no one correct way to play the game. Every skill in the game, with the exception of Swimming and arguably Environmental Training, is useful, and there is a way to beat any mission with any skillset. You could use Multitools to bypass a security keypad to open a door, or you could hack a security terminal and open it from there, or you could lockpick your way into a drawer with a datacube containing the code, or you could just blow the door open with an explosive. There is always more than one way to solve a problem, something that is very, very rare in even the best games out there. The amount of depth this game has amazes me. Once I was in a high-rise apartment, and I decided to break the window and jump out, merely for the entertainment of seeing how far up I actually was. I instead landed on a balcony, lockpicking my way into a room with binoculars and a computer terminal containing interesting details about the lore of the game. My jaw was literally agape. I could not believe that such an obscure location would actually have something noteworthy in it. No matter how many times you play Deus Ex, you will always find something new, be it a new way to complete a mission or just a fun easter egg, and this makes the replay value extremely high. The game is massive, and I believe this to be in part due to the extremely low-budget graphics. Since so little time and money was spent on the look of the game, the mechanics could be polished to a mirror shine and the world expanded in a meaningful way, with things to find in every nook and cranny. I would also be remiss not to mention the game's fantastic story. It's a wonder the game managed to be so compelling despite the awful voice acting, and it speaks to the quality of the writing that this was achieved. The characters you encounter are lovable, and the overarching plot is both extremely complex and full of twists and turns, which is why, in the interest of avoiding spoilers and laziness, I won't be providing a plot summary. You'll just have to find out for yourself. Lastly, there is the music, which is phenomenal. Alexander Brandon's compositions are varied, memorable, and always fit the location and the themes of the story (edit: I derped, there are two other composers as well, named Michiel van den Bos and Daniel Gardopee). On top of that, the music isn't just nice to listen to: they also serve a gameplay purpose. During the missions, the music that plays will normally be very ambient and fade into the background, but when enemies are alerted of your prescense (this game has optional stealth), the music will become more intense, not only to change the mood from that of quiet sneaking to fast-paced gunplay, but also to let you know the enemies are on to you even if you're too far away to see or hear them. The rest of the sound design is solid, with satisfying gun noises that make shooting satisfying if you have to get into a fight. The only sound that isn't good is the sound of assault rifle bullets hitting a wall, which is utterly dreadful. It sounds more like rain hitting the ground than bullets colliding with solid steel, and it takes you out of the intensity of combat. Overall, Deus Ex's presentation has some problems, but the overall package is one of the deepest, most complex and most fun games ever made, and it also has the advantage of being utterly unique. No other game is quite like Deus Ex and few are as well-designed and compelling.10/10P.S. If you're a newbie and you want to play this game for the first time, I highly reccomend downloading this mod for the game:http://www.moddb.com/mods/biomodIt makes several balance changes to the game, ranging from small changes like buffing some of the melee weapon's damage, to massive overhauls, like replacing the useless Swimming skill with the very useful Atheltics skill, which increases speed and jump height on land as well as in water. There are also some new additions, like the ability to do a Thief-style wall mount if you upgrade your Athletics skill to Advanced, the ability to pickpocket keys from guards, and white phosphorus grenades. Additionally, the game runs smoother, saves take less time, the game autosaves when maps change, and overall it's a straight upgrade from the unmodded version. It'll help take the edge off some of the ways in which this game shows it's age. For special instructions on how to get mods working with the Steam version, click the link below: http://www.rpgcodex.net/forums/index.php?threads/deus-ex-mods-a-how-to-guide-by-jaesun.34834/

content:
Posted: March 24
												игрушка шикарная, затянула с первого уровня.упоротый сюжет по канонам рен-тв, но его развилки не в середине игры, как в последнем ведьмаке, например, а на последнем уровне. Действия влияют только на сложность прохождения. В отличие от Human Revolution, можно избежать битв с боссами - от некоторых можно убежать, пару можно взорвать без драки. Проходить можно разными способами и иногда даже не такими, которые предусмотрели разработчики. Финалы заставляют призадуматься о судьбе человечества (считаю правильной концовку, предложенную Трейсером Тонгом). Интересно, что первые уровни Human Revolution и некоторые пасхалки частично слизаны с этой игры.заметил особенность - атмосфера тайных лабораторий намного лучше передана в Half-Life, вышедшей на два года раньше. Может, в халве лучше дизайн или более подходящая музыка. В Deus Ex постоянное музыкальное сопровождение, тишины нет. Динамичная музыка, играющая во время сражения, должна предупреждать игрока о том, что его заметили, и в загадочных местах с неведомыми тварями она оказывается лишней. Понравилась музыка на рынке Гонконга, в штабе UNATCO и офисе Versalife.Пока игра нравится больше Human Revolution, которую я не осилил несколько лет назад.

												I don't want the hype to throw you back when playing Deus Ex. Already when it was release, there were complains about optimization (I think people where not aware of how much is handled in the background in this game), animations, "boss" battles, and some boredom you might get in the final levels. It is still the best game I have ever played (would it too much to have original Deus Ex with the engine of Mankind??? I doubt it but well see FF7). I mean, I played it two times and there were things I never thought of, like that famous killswitch!I dont like this version because I got used to gamepad nowadays, so it is a pity we cannot have the ps2 version. If you like deus ex HR and retro 3D games, if you love to reload a section just to see if you can pass it in a different way, if you like emerging gameplay, Deus Ex is your game.

Approximate hours spent since February 2001: 800-1500h+Nano-augmented agents will often encounter stress created by resentment among fellow agents, particularly those who have been mechanically augmented. In an effort to secure freedom and liberty for those under their protection, many UNATCO agents have chosen to sacrifice social acceptance for mission performance by surgically replacing limbs and organs with mechanically or electronically enhanced equivalents. But your nano-augmentations points the way to the future: thousands of microscopic, living, organic machines that exist in symbiosis with your body.Because such augmentations create only minimal disfigurement, they are likely to be a source of friction between you and other mechanically augmented agents -- but it is important to understand that UNATCO is an organization where individuals must act in concert. Each is important to the whole, and mutual understanding is essential to teams comprised of diverse human and augmentedagents. If you have any further questions or wish to discuss these issues, please feel free to send email to CarverEschells\\UNATCO.4352.768 to make an appointment.And welcome to UNATCO, agent.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2011
												This classic, formative RPG is a great deal of fun and should not be missed by any fans of the genre. Sure, everything about it is dated; this is to be expected, given that it was released in 2000. The game's appeal isn't to be found in the graphics or the sound, or whatever else you might find archaic about it, but rather in the brilliant, immersive story and the pure importance that the game held for the future of the genre. Buy it; you'll have a good time, provided that you manage to be patient through the first hour or so.

												It's too deep for a traditional review.This game is massive, it has more depth and complexity than any game nowadays could hope to produce under a AAA title because publishers or whomever expect all this shiny new graphics and need everything drenched in that hideous Hollywood syrupy formula.This game pulls no punches and unfortunately represents a failure in the industry because we will never return to this level of passion and drive, even its sequels, although good(great even) cannot stand up to it.IF you can get past the graphics and the uncanny valley character movements and the engine bugs then you will enjoy this game, if you like the setting I actually cannot see how you could not enjoy it.So lets just give it a thumbs up and leave it there eh?

content:
Posted: November 25, 2011
												For something released in 2000, this game is absolutely exceptional. From the moment you start playing, you get to choose your own playstyle. It doesn't matter if you prefer sniping enemies from far away, stealthily sneaking past people, or running around with guns blazing. You do what you want to do. The story and gameplay are great too. The only thing I must critique is the controls that span from 1-0 and F1-F12. You're gonna have to get used to sometimes taking your right hand off of your mouse and moving it back quickly to press a button. Anyhow, I feel this game is definitely worth more than $9.99.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2011
												Perhaps my second favourite game of all time (right behind Starcraft). Deus Ex is a superb mix of RPG and FPS that allows you to play how you want to play. Do you want to go in hot, with guns a-blazing? Then go right ahead. Do you want to skulk and strike from the shadows? Go for it. Do you just want to avoid any and all contact with enemies and live in peace as a pacifist? You can do that too. With nearly unlimited ways to play, and a 20-30 hour campaign with a very good story, Deus Ex is definitely worth the $9.99.

content:

												I played this for the first time in 2015, having played Human Revolution first (which I also really enjoyed). Not knowing much about Deus Ex other than its immense praise and notoriety around the internet and gaming world for being one of the "best games ever made", I decided to give it a go.I decided to install Kentie's launcher mod so I could make the game support higher resolutions and what not. (This is highly recommended for modern PCs)I started off the game not knowing exactly what I was doing, but continued onward. Writing this now, I am so happy I didn't drop the game. If you can get used to it and ignore the few kinks throughout the game, it is a fanstastic experience worth playing. I can't say its perfect, because it is obviously flawed. but for anybody who likes video games and can tolerate a few bugs and some difficult moments, this game is totally worth it. Just keep in mind its 15 years old.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												Here's an example of a great game that didn't age well. While nothing can take away its cult status and its place in the pantheon of gaming, actually playing it today is a pain. The interface is less than convenient. The upgrade system is cryptic, as you never know in advance which skills or augmentations you are going to use, and which are a waste of resources. The levels are huge, dark, labyrinthine, with lots of ladders and passages hidden in plain sight and no minimap or quest markers so you are guranteed to wander them for hours, not sure where exactly you are supposed to go. The gameplay is clunky, as the game isn't sure whether it wants to be an RPG, a shooter or a stealth action, making every play style equally hard to enjoy.However, all of this is worth enduring, especially if you are not just a regular gamer, but a game journalist, blogger or developer. Deus Ex provides a level of story detail that is rarely seen in a game even today, serving as an example of what this medium can achieve and provivding the hints on how to do it. The games tells a great, dark and mature story in a way that only this medium can: through your own actions, and the whole world around you. All the scattered books and newspapers, cracked emails, overheared dialogues create a grim world and a tight story like no linear medium, be it a book or a movie, ever could. The game is highly sensitive to your beavior too, providing feedback on tiniest of actions that sometimes echo through the story for far longer than you would expect. In the modern day this game might be hard to enjoy for those who play for pleasure, but if you want to understand how the videogames tick, it is an absolute must-play.

content:
Posted: April 1
												The popularly accepted theory that Jazz stemmed from a simple combination of African rhythms and European harmony is in need of a little revision. Both African and European rhythms were employed. African music supplied the strong underlying beat (absent in most European music), the use of polyrhythms, and the idea of playing the melody separate from or above the beat. European music provided formal dance rhythms. Combined, these rhythms give Jazz its' characteristic swing. Likewise, the harmonies and musical ideas of both continents are present, the blue notes derived from the pentatonic scale, "call and response" and unconventional instrumental timbres of African music together with "conventional" harmonies and, most important, the formal structure of European music. The multiplicity of ethnic, cultural and musical conditions needed to spawn Jazz was thus unique to the United States, and specifically to New Orleans. The necessary philosophical impetus for Jazz, i.e. , democracy and freedom of individual expression supported by group interaction, are also American institutions.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												Here's an example of a great game that didn't age well. While nothing can take away its cult status and its place in the pantheon of gaming, actually playing it today is a pain. The interface is less than convenient. The upgrade system is cryptic, as you never know in advance which skills or augmentations you are going to use, and which are a waste of resources. The levels are huge, dark, labyrinthine, with lots of ladders and passages hidden in plain sight and no minimap or quest markers so you are guranteed to wander them for hours, not sure where exactly you are supposed to go. The gameplay is clunky, as the game isn't sure whether it wants to be an RPG, a shooter or a stealth action, making every play style equally hard to enjoy.However, all of this is worth enduring, especially if you are not just a regular gamer, but a game journalist, blogger or developer. Deus Ex provides a level of story detail that is rarely seen in a game even today, serving as an example of what this medium can achieve and provivding the hints on how to do it. The games tells a great, dark and mature story in a way that only this medium can: through your own actions, and the whole world around you. All the scattered books and newspapers, cracked emails, overheared dialogues create a grim world and a tight story like no linear medium, be it a book or a movie, ever could. The game is highly sensitive to your beavior too, providing feedback on tiniest of actions that sometimes echo through the story for far longer than you would expect. In the modern day this game might be hard to enjoy for those who play for pleasure, but if you want to understand how the videogames tick, it is an absolute must-play.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition is an FPS RPG and was released in 2000. Although the graphics were even dated back then, the game is liked by its fans for the story and the great open maps. The game is set in an universe where all conspiracy theories are true...+ Multiple paths to choose. Depend on your skills, too. + skill and augmentation tree+ Unique soundtrack+ A lot of weapons to choose from.+ My boss told me to stay out of the ladies restroom.+ Good level design+ iconic game- Unmodded state is unplayable. Works well with the right mods though.- Although fans love the story, I didn't, really. It has just too many conspiracy theories.- The game felt a bit too long. Didn't help that some maps are not memorable.- The protagonist is a conspiracy theorist. Therefore, his dialogue is stupid.- Some of the worst voice acting I have ever seen.- Some skills and augmentations are useless.- Stealth is feasible, but hard. If you don't know the maps yet anyway. Overall, the stealth mechanics aren't well developped.- The AI is badI'd recommend playing this game if you have ever played older games before and want to know why the game is loved by many. Since the game is really old by now, it's only playable on modern hardware if you download and install the following things: the kentie.net exe, a directx 10 (or 9 if you want to) and texture mods like new vision and maybe HDTP.Replay value: Potentially high with multiple choices, paths, endings and changed dialogueRating: 8.0/10Recommendation: Yes

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Graphics: the graphics were okish for 2000 when the game released. To bring it this century, follow this guide: http://www.reddit.com/r/gaming/comments/ceuyh/step_by_step_moddingguide_deus_ex_i_spilled_my/Sound: nice voice overs, decent sound fx. Overall very atmospheric, if a bit low fidelity.Gameplay: good. The controls and interface are a bit clunky compared to what you may be used to but after 1-2 hours it stops getting in the way. The customization of your character is really meaningful with choices that are not just skin deep. However, there is no way to screw things up, the game can be completed without any items and with any build.Story: knocks your socks off. This game has real choice and consequence, plot twists, cospiracy theories melded together very smartly and, something that rarely happens nowadays: a great ending. Hard to explain without spoiling anything, but I think this is one of the best game stories of all time and it's the main reason you would want to play this game. There are usually about 3-5 ways to accomplish any objective and combat itself is optional (although sometimes combat is the easiest way to reach objectives).How to approach: the game doesn't have a compass/objective pointers, doesn't show your position on the map and generally does not hold your hand. Pay attentiona and have a faq at hand if you get stuck (but try to play on your own, it's more fun like that).

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Hark, listen to me well, for I have a harrowing tale from times long past, a story of man versus machine, a tale of tragedy, but above all, a parable for the modern age!The advent of the spinning jenny and the Jacquard loom spelt the end for a simple way of life, as well as the death of the working man; united under the banner of long lost King Ludd these men of industry attempted to retake their lives from the machines that had stolen them, but twas no hope for these souls! Alas, alas they lost! Weep for these lost souls, these many homeless, swept into the great dustbin of history!Deus Ex re-imagines the Luddite movement and brings it forward into a more modern context. In it, you play J.C. Denton, a man who finds himself leading the revolution against the neo-spinning jennys and the cyber-Jacquard looms, advanced textile machines that use cutting edge nanotechnology to greatly improve the output of the textile mills of Neo-England. Can you stop the so-called "God Machine" from kickstarting a second neo-cyber-Industrial Revolution after the Second Napoleonic War?

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												You know, I first played this game when I was 14, in 2001. I liked it a lot then, but thought the graphics looked a bit outdated. Even for the time it was released, it was by no means a graphical triumph. Believe me, when I say the graphics haven't aged well, you can take that as a bonafide fact. If you don't believe me, you'll see what I mean when you get it. However, as I said, the graphics were never particularly grand in the first place. It would be nice if resolutions were fixed for more modern systems, even though this would take some time. I'm not asking for a complete reboot or remake of the game, just make the higher resolutions actually WORK - which they don't. Again, though, graphics shouldn't be considered a selling point in a game from 15 years ago - it's just a minor gripe. Unlike the graphics from many games of this era like any of the games from the Quake, Unreal, or Half Life Series, they haven't aged well.I realize my playtime here on Steam is extremely low (though my playtime otherwise has been much higher), but feelings of Nostalgia came screaming back to me as I started it up. After just a few minutes of playtime, I remembered. You should never hit a TNT box with a crowbar, no matter how good of an idea it may seem at the time. Oh, the hilarity. I'm glad that a lot of gameplay elements I saw for the first time in Deus Ex have stayed with games into the modern era, and I believe that as one goes into this, if they've been a gamer for practically their whole lives, or even new gamers, should take a look at things that probably started with this game and continued. The actual implementation of stealth in this game is pretty good, albeit somewhat clunky and kind of clumsy - however, it has been taken and run with into modern games. I'm not saying this is the only game to have done this, certainly Metal Gear Solid for the Playstation console did a great job of it as well, but Deus Ex did it slightly differently. The combination of the two has endured. The game isn't very hard, but it's not easy either, and maybe it's my poor eyesight, but I did need to crank up the brighteness of the game a good bit to see what I was doing. The voice acting for the time period was great, and they caught that "Matrix" vibe that I liked about the game the first time I played. In short, I can understand why opinions are divided on this game and have been since it came out, I personally think it's great and enjoyable, and you get out of it what you put into it, but some people think it sucks. With Deus Ex, it comes down to either loving it or hating it - I haven't really seen anyone with an in-between opinion on it that's played it. It either rules or it sucks, take your pick. If you played it in the past and want Nostalgia, definitely check it out, but don't expect anything to be more brilliant or prettier than it was in the past, because that's just not how it is. My only major complaint? The screen resolutions don't work correctly. This is irritating and really the only detriment to playing the game again in order to feel like a kid while I'm not currently working. For 6.99? Certainly worth the price, even if you're just a completist. 8/10 for innovation, storyline, gameplay, and cyberpunk style-over-substance healthy dose of cool.5/10 for graphics. Fix the resolutions, other than that, it will never be a graphical triumph, but you'll be able to tolerate it if you like cyberpunk visuals.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Many people have lauded Deus Ex as one of the greatest games ever created, and by fockin' Bunne, they should! Ion Storm never had a "pristine rep", but what they did with Deus Ex wasn't just brilliant... it was DIVINE! Any game which lets players choose ENTIRELY how to play it is a game worthy of several bonus points in MY book! The stealth is a bit woinky and unreliable at times, in the sense that it's hard to know when someone's looking at you or not. But that's probably just part of the appeal. The weapon modding makes combat VERY interesting, as you can turn a simple 10mm pistol into a miniature sniper rifle, and you can turn a shotgun into an armour-wrecking monster of anti-bottery. Basically, it's hard to pin-point what exactly it is about Deus Ex that makes it such an amazingly brilliant game, without just going all broad and generic by saying "everything" and leaving it at that. But weirdly, that's probably the best answer you'll get outta anyone that's spent any amount o' time with it. 9.7/10

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												The story is fantastic and has strong ties to the real world. The feeling that what your doing actually matters for your story line (even if it is limited) makes it so great. Graphics are aesthetically pleasing. Sound work is great.But the gameplay is a bit lacking. AI are a bit stoogey like they tend to be in stealth games so that you can actually do stealth, but they also have trouble putting up a fight against a real human who can figure out how to take advantage of their weaknesses and its not very hard to do it. Once you realize you can bunny hop everywhere with the dragon sword and win just about every fight you realize the gameplay isn't incredibly strong here. But doing that is fairly fun and enjoyable, but considering how difficult guns can be to use in terms of accuracy and damage it almost seems to easy and a design oversight. Theres enough variance in enemies to keep it fresh and with some enemies the sword trick isn't really going to work and its a better idea to just avoid them altogether and there are points where the sword trick will not work at all but these are generally short lived and not common.GET THE SWORD, GET THE SWORD, AND OH RIGHT....GET THE ♥♥♥♥ING SWORD. Even if the the base gameplay design in terms of shootouts and weapons are good to decent you have alot of choices to take ranging from no kills to straight stealth.  You decide how to play the game and thats really rare and makes up for all the short comings.Its a great game and stands out from the crowd. Its a bit of a shame that if you want to go with a straight guns route that its not as rewarding and more work than just bunny hopping around with the sword and face stabbing people.Its still a great game though. Totally worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: January 5
												Deus Ex is a gameplay-driven story and it's probably the closest video games will ever come to being a movie without sacrificing the gameplay. Well, Deus Ex and Metal Gear Solid, too. You play as a guy named Deus. Deus likes wearing sunglasses indoors at night time because he's a pretentious prick who just wants to look cool. You'll grow to like him anyway though because he has funny one-liners and tells a stripper to get a real job. Deus works a globalist anti-terrorist organization. This seems cool and all, but remember: GLOBALIST!!!!!Your organization is being funded by George Soros, but it's the distant future where Hillary Clinton won and everyone hates George Soros by now, so he calls himself "Bob Page". George Soros has been making some kind of virus that makes people♥♥♥♥♥♥their intestines out, but he's also been manufacturing the cure and selling it to the elites. He's fabricating conflicts and and outbreaks in order to necessitate a reliance on the government and establish a Globalist society. Deus thinks George Soros is a pretty cool guy, but then Alex Jones blows up the Statue of Liberty and tells him that George Soros is the REAL TERRORIST!!!!!Deus still hasn't made up his mind at this point, but the story gets pretty crazy. I mean, George Soros hooks himself up to this machine thing and becomes this robot god with some blue stuff all over his body. Deus goes through a bunch of 90's SciFi movie sets while cool robot music plays in the background. Check it out.The gameplay isn't really about shooting things, it's more about sneaking around and using the environment to your advantage. It's not really a puzzle as much as it is a problem. You got multiple solutions to everything. You gotta use your brain and manipulate the mechanics to get to the next area. It's really a game you have to "understand" to actually play.Really fun, actually one of my all-time favorites. Only people who don't like it are SammyClassicSonicFan and the Globalists.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												I have 3 main problems with this game that make it borderline un playable.1.) Its to freaking dark! I can turn the brightness way up but then everthing just looks terrible. So I have a choice between not seeing anything and hurting my eyes or everything looking terrible.2.) The whole, your cursor has to stay over the enemy to increase your accruacy is just annoying. I do not like that mechanic in the slightest.3.) There is no point to stealth. I play a lot of stealth games and I love stealth. There really isnt any reason to here. You can blast someone away with rockets and space lasers and the guy standing 2 feet away wouldnt even notice.If you can get past that then there is a pretty good game here. It has quite a few ways to complete missions. Lots of stuff to explore and figure out. And you can kill just about anyone.This isn't a game where I can sit down and play through it in big chunks. Its going to be one of those I play an hour of it on the weekends until its over type deals.I still recomend the game if the issues above dont bother you or you can get it on sale. As far as bugs and such go, I have not seen any.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2011
UPDATE:If you purchase/obtain this game or own it on Steam without the patch, please download the free Deus Ex: REVISION mod available from Steam. It upgrades the graphics, makes the textures MUCH higher-resolution, fixes bugs, and generally and specifically in other ways makes Deus Ex a much more modern experience without removing the charm of the original game. Even old-timers like me appreciate the improvements and those younger gamers who can't stomach the old graphics or controls of the original game will find DX:REVISION much more palatable. Yeah, there's still text to read. Yeah, there are still more ways to complete each level than you're probably thought of yet. Yeah, this depicts a future time when all conspiracy theories are part of reality, just like the original DX did. The only thing that would make it better without a complete rewrite is the original fold-out paper pack-ins from the boxed game.ORIGINAL REVIEW:Some people in 2011 have a problem with DX from 2000 because it used the Unreal 1 engine and the sky/ground textures are low-resolution. I didn't have a problem with that because, if I were playing as if I were JC Denton, I wouldn't waste time looking at distant city lights mapped onto the skybox. Having them visible at all was a bonus.I thought it was awesome; I've played through it many, many times since the first release. I still hear the Hong Kong music in my head when I think about it because I've spent so many hours over the years running back and forth through that portion of the game. Heh. After I got a 3DFX card and was able to see the 3D-accelerated version's enhanced effects (Ooh! Shiny floors at UNATCO HQ, and I can play in a higher res than 320x240 / 512x384!), replaying was just that much more fun! Choosing different paths, favoring different factions, playing to the different endings, etc., gave DX a LOT of replayability, and the game is never too long!

												This is an old review for the game that I first played 10 years ago and I lost count how many times I have complete it since after.For a 10 year old game, the graphic certainly don't stand up, however the level design, the attention to detail is more advanced than any current game in existence.The story and the narrative are terrifying depressing... and more terrifying is that they are becoming real, this game came out before 9/11, before the era of terrorism, before the rise of China, before the mass inequality, before the mass surveillance of the world today... but yet... all of those themes were very heavy in the world of Deus Ex, and everything is slowly becoming real.The only thing that is lacking in today's world which the game have is the conspiracy stuff... but how knows, maybe that is real as well and we just don't know it. (Illuminati if you are really out there, please don't kill me or publish my browser history)For people that never played this game, I would recommend download some HD mods for this game, and have patience to at least get out of New York level, if you can do that, you will get use to the game play, and rest of the game magic will do it self.

I do not like that mechanic in the slightest.3.) There is no point to stealth. I play a lot of stealth games and I love stealth. There really isnt any reason to here. You can blast someone away with rockets and space lasers and the guy standing 2 feet away wouldnt even notice.If you can get past that then there is a pretty good game here. It has quite a few ways to complete missions. Lots of stuff to explore and figure out. And you can kill just about anyone.This isn't a game where I can sit down and play through it in big chunks. Its going to be one of those I play an hour of it on the weekends until its over type deals.I still recomend the game if the issues above dont bother you or you can get it on sale. As far as bugs and such go, I have not seen any.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2016
												I think Deus Ex is a good game, overall. Your charachter is highly customizable gameplay-wise, allowing you to get past your enemies in whatever fasion you desire (usualy). You can become a walking tank with maxed out weapons skills and biceps full of combat nanites, a silent assassin who is deadly with blade and pistol and can turn invisible, or just about anything else you think up. The storyline is fairly decent, and has some deep overarching themes. However, Deus Ex isn't some sinless saint. The game feels too long, especialy for one where there are so many methods to try out. I lost intrest about 3 missions away from the ending. There are also encounters with other augumented people which always seemed one-directional to me. They're immune to everything non-lethal, and they soak up bullets without missing a step. The only way I found to kill them was to just blow them up. Explosives in this game seem a bit overpowered too, since they basicly kill everything within 30 feet that has line of sight. Despite these flaws, Deus Ex is most definately worth 7 bucks. I know a few  tripple-A games with the same quality going for $60.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												Deus Ex was one of the very few games I went into without knowing a THING about it.When i first got into it I really didn't think i would've gotten myself immersed into right away due to the age, but holy jesus was I wrong!  Deus Ex was made by a company known as Ion Storm ,Yes the same people who made Daikatana, and to come from that to this beauty of a game is amazing, The graphics are dated sure, but the audio design and music REALLY keep it up to today's standards. Coming from a game made in 2000 the voice acting is really good, even down right hilarious at times when the jokes pop up and the music, GOODNESS the music! its something that really takes my 1st place surpassing that of Doom.The mixture of Techno and classical is a beautiful combonation that everyone should listen too! from the high-tech offices of UNATCO to the desolate streets of a worn-down Paris, it all sounds so pleasing to your ears. Now, down to the real meat of this game, the Story (no spoilers) and Gameplay.  Deus Ex's story is handsdown one of the best I have experienced in a long time, rivaling that of Half-Life 2. the Multi-Choice endings are perfect on how it makes the player feel with the end result. the game can even let you kill off most of the story-important NPCS right off the bat and it seems like the whole story shifts around your actions. Dont expect a short playthrough with this game either, it took me a good 24 hours to beat it while looking in all of the corners of the maps to find secrets and hidden areas.  Gameplay wise, Deus Ex is a great experience, the combat system is totally unique and intuitive and the Inventory system is done really well and the Nano-augs you can get really shift on how you build your character and progress through the game.  the Skills system is a bit basic sure, but it will make you choose which you feel is more important, and trust me putting it all into Pistols and Rifles is something you DO NOT want to do first thing with each level offering on how efficient your character uses said items. It's always best to put points into the skills that help you rack up more ammo and supplies.In ConclusionDeus Ex is a down right masterpiece and it down right deserves to be called the "Greatest PC game of all time" in my books, everything about this game is done so right and if one can mod it so it works with modern machines, your in for one heck of a good time!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Just one of those games that truly defines the PC gaming platform.Deus Ex raised the bar for many standards on how games should be. With it's nonlinear style of gameplay allowing you to finish missions in many different ways, to it's vast customization, amazing story and various gameplay elements, Deus Ex is simply a masterpiece. Looking at it today, if you can get past the hilarious voice acting and it's bad graphics (there are mods that fix the graphical issues), you'll find one of the best games ever made. If you've never played the game before, imagine yourself in the year 2000, most of the games you've played past this point probably don't exist. Then after you're finished, you'll realize how large of an impact Deus Ex has made in modern gaming. That's how I feel this game should be experienced. This game might not make as huge of an impression to today's gamers who mainly play modern games so I feel that they do decide to play this, that's the way it should be done.9.5/10, an absolute classic and one of my personal favorites.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												Well, its a FPS with RPG elements, but that isn't really its main appeal. Its main appeal in my opinion is simply in the ways you can interact with people in the game. For example there is a part where you are ordered to kill someone and you have 3 choices. You can kill the person you were ordered to, you can kill the person ordering you to kill, or you can choose to kill neither. You can even go about dealing with enemies however you want. You can kill every enemy with bullets or explosions, you can avoid enemies using stealth, or you can non lethally take them all down. The game likes to give you a lot of options like that, so that every playthrough will feel a little different.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Most of the positives and negatives of this game have been posted for years, but for me, what makes the original Deus Ex stand up against most is the way the narrative is handled. Not only is there conspiracies and plot twists, but the underlying thread of AI and cyberpunk philosophy still speaks to some of our uncertainities as it did in 2000. Sure the graphics look horrid, even with mods and the voice acting is very spooty, but the gameplay still holds up for me. Even now there's always 1-2 things I find in playthroughs that I missed before.Really love this game and would still recommend it for people that love narrative-driven RPGs.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Probably the finest game ever created.  Deus Ex is a conspiracy-driven, atmospheric first-person RPG title with remarkable story across a stunning array of locations from New York to Hong Kong. You play JC Denton; an American Special Agent stuck in a corrupt world of terrorists, disease and economic carnage. The game introduces itself in Liberty Island, New York where the city has been infected by a man-made virus set to wipe out the underclasses. Terrorists have hijacked a shipment of highly sought-after vaccine which has sent Manhattan into meltdown as people drop dead as they surrender their lives to the virus. As you begin your quest to restore order; you have to find the people who were behind the attack but also determine who and what caused the disease and more importantly why... 13 years on; this game outshines even the most ambitious modern day titles. The script is phenomenal, the characters are memorable and intriguing and the music is some of the best seen in a videogame. This is not a linear title either; you have considerable control in your actions with many various ways to complete objectives and affect outcomes.  This concept is largely unseen in today's bland offerings. The inventory system is simple but smart and ensures tough decisions on what you can carry. The XP points and augmentations can improve your character's abilities from hacking computers to general combat and movement. The RPG elements are extremely well implemented in this game and the interface is very user friendly.  The combat mechanics may feel a little ropey and dated but the positives outweigh anything negative you may notice.At any price; this game is worth getting as it stands tall against even the most elite games of this generation.  One of the finest titles in living memory and Deus Ex will live on for decades to come.

content:
Posted: March 4
												Deus Ex plays quite well after 17 years. The majority of games cannot lay claim to this feat. I would like to see JC Denton era of Deus Ex come to life. However, Square Enix would have to hone very close to the bone in order for it to be genuine. Such a game would have to capture the original Deus Ex ambience precisely while bringing something new. Not a lot new but something. Neat trick if they could pull it off. So, here is to the hope that they neatly wrap up Adam Jensen's era and start up JC Denton and Paul in a prequel game. Or even a game wherein JC regects the final scenarios of Deus Ex and bring about his own version. In any event, Deus Ex is one of the few games which deserves to be called "classic." Yes, that is almost cliche but for Deus Ex it is true. It is a "classic" video game. Never duplicated. So, it can be called unigue.

content:
Posted: February 3
												I find myself amidst this Deus Ex conundrum.I have no nostalgia for this game, I didn't play it when it was new or recent, not even once - I had only heard about it and its legendary status. I finally got to play it in 2013 and despite the decade of immense hype I loved it. I must have played through the whole game about 3 or 4 times in a row in different playstyles and difficulties. Had I not picked it up again today I would have given it a glowing recommendation, praising its atmosphere, incredible length and size but inbetween 2013 and now I have also played about 100 hours of Deus Ex Human Revolution and despite its flaws I find it to be a much better game in almost every aspect. Deus Ex was a landmark title in gaming but replaying it now it feels so terribly clunky.On a technical level it's laughable even for its time which personally I don't mind as much because I grew up in the nineties but new players will definitely have a hard time getting accustomed to the graphics which do a big disservice to the UT engine. The voice acting is also comical, which I don't mind as much either, it's just something I need to mention in an honest recommendation.The game is sizeable but it definitely runs out of steam in the middle and while the story is pretty good it isn't anything you haven't heard before if you've played a game or read a book in the cyberpunk genre. Expect X-Files type conspiracy theories, AIs, a mysterious disease and allies of questionable allegiance. There are however some great dialogue scenes that really stuck with me. It's not high literature but it's admittedly a lot smarter and adult than most cyberpunk games.I also think that the wealth of choices you have in the story has been grossly exaggerated. It's mostly details like being called out on going into the lady's bathroom or a few lines of dialogue changing because you killed an ally because he would become a boss fight later on. There's no branching storyline to speak of but in the end you can choose different endings, albeit not as clumsily as in Human Revolution where you literally got 4 buttons to choose an ending from. My main gripe are the gameplay mechanics. Even when you know what you are doing and which augmentations and skills to upgrade, both gunplay and stealth mechanics feel quite clunky and unbalanced, and I found them highly frustrating on my most recent attempt at a playthrough. Those accustomed to newer entries in the series or other stealth games will probably demand more fluency and variety. You can always choose a slightly different route in the levels which takes the edge of these flaws a little bit but they remain much too noticeable to ignore.There's also the myriad of technical issues and bugs I've encountered with the steam port so far, which I don't recall from the retail version, which admittedly had its own unique bugs I could exploit. I liked how I never had to upgrade lockpicking because opening the inventory while using a lockpick would only drain one item no matter which level the lock had. Deus Ex is still an important milestone in gaming that everyone should have played through at least once, but I think it's starting to show its age quite badly. I was really looking forward to a replay but the first hour felt much too tedious I think I'm going to pass. It's not a bad game, if you have a lot of patience you might love it the way I first did but it has always been flawed. I treasure my memories of first playing it though.

												Stream Version might not work on your rig. this is why...Had to refund because it could not play on my pc. I could not walk, my character ran at like 1000%+ normal speed, the converstations lasted all of a few mili seconds, and could not even get pass the starting area. Looked up ways to fix it, but was unplayable. I7-2600k, 16 gig ram, gt 960 rig, could not get any help from support on this there for got a full refund for it. Playing it on console ie a ps2, would be a lot more stable, just have to go dust them off first. There was no frame issues, edited the settings in game and in the installer, just wasn't able to get it to slow down.As for the game over all:I owned this game when it came out in the 2000's .I beat all 3 endings. The story was one of the bests from all the games I played while in high school, I got it as a gift from an school friend of mine. It was engaging, it was hard,  I got stuck a lot, but it was worth it. The newer games in this series to me don't have the same feel as this BUT, I think it was due, like many others, your first game experence is normally the best. This and a few other games made me go 'wow' and 'wtf' at the end of it, and made me rethink things in life as a kid, to open up my mind for things etc.OVERALL for buying it on steam:There is a chance you might but this and it could possibly not work, which makes you have to get a refund on it, I tried for 30 mins to play the game, it was unplay able and at the start of this I put down what my set up is, one would assume, yea, system if powerful enough to have it work, but, I have no idea why the seed is so fast. I press forward and I move so fast I can cross a room in a blink rather then taking 1 step. To me that means it is not worth playing. Buy it but make sure to test it asap and if it works for you GREAT ... if not, stop playing it, research a fix but don't keep the game launched so you don't go over the 'refund time' limit.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												Sacrilegious as it may be to say but I don't like Deus Ex (Original). While I have already the ire of many devoted fans, let me preface this review with some info:-I love the idea of DX games, and I like Human Revolution and Mankind Divided. I appreciate the importance of DX but that doesn't mean it's perfect. -A game from the early 2000s is going to ask more from the player. Some of these aspects I like, such as the lack of handholding, while others I detest because they are aggravating or pointless.-The only mod I used is a launcher to use modern resolutions and FOV.-I have finished this game once after three restarts to better understand the gameplay. What convinced me to give this a negative review is that the game's quality worsens after you arrive in Hong Kong. Talking about its impact became more interesting than playing it.-My specific issue is how the game becomes more viable to use exploits like your sword than your tools. The lethal playstyles have never won me over with subpar FPS mechanics.And before anyone suggests I should have installed an overhaul, I like to play old games as true-to-form as possible. The only exception I'll accept is adding free-aiming to DOOM. I enjoy understanding each game's strengths and weaknesses, and when it comes to DX I find the weaknesses can only be accepted if the game scratches your niche.You're Going To Need a BackscratcherIf you like to go into games blind to enjoy learning as you go, I would suggest you avoid that habit. If you want to ignore my advice, then play the first few missions over until you find what works best; however, don't plan playing non-lethally for your first run.DX expects you to know what skills you should invest into and where you can find augment-canisters to get your abilities quick. What makes it particularly more annoying than other games is how the mechanics are constrained by your skills. Aim-reticules take far longer to line up if you move or are not trained in a specific weapon, which some of them are not as obvious without reading their details (ex. handling pistols improves crossbows.) As for the other skills, all they do is improve the efficiency of a certain skill either by decreasing the time spent or by improving how many tools you need to use for an obstacle. There is a common joke how you should never invest into Swimming; the same could be said for many other skills: Hacking and Health beyond untrained, and you forgoing Explosives and Environmental Training. This is because certain augments provide the same bonuses without items to take up your limited inventory space. Unfortunately, augmentations have an annoying issue: You have to play "red-light-green-light" with them, which is far too cumbersome to manage for what are passive buffs like combat strength. (They should still use energy but only when in context.)The worst problem is how it hampers non-lethal playstyles by the game's inconsistency. As much as I enjoy the versatile items from pepper-sprays to stun-rods to tranq-darts, it's obviously not as balanced in the late-game. For example, tranq-darts are not an automatic knock-out to the head; it's based on what skill-level you are for pistols, and for some enemies they are immune to your whole arsenal. Your only option is to avoid them. This wouldn't be a problem if the stealth system wasn't as simple as it is in this game, so you will be save-scumming far too often as compared to pulling out your sword (regardless of your skill) for a one-or-two-kill.  Trying to go guns-blazing also has its own problems. As mentioned beforehand, the augments have to enabled/disabled manually, which is defaulted to all F-number keys. Even if you rebound the keys the fighting would be too cumbersome to move, turn augments on-and-off, and aim properly, and the AI doesn't account for that amount of time. And choosing to use the pause menu to enable/disable breaks the pace. There is simply too much going on for action to make it a viable means with guns--but running around a sword is a sure-win tactic. I emphasize that sword's importance because it's one of the many game-breaking aspects fans come to love about the game. I don't enjoy breaking a game's balance so it irritates me more than others. The point of this is that by the time I got to the end all I needed was a sniper with a silencer, a sword, a shotgun for robotic spiders, and grenades and other consumables. (Some are too specific like fire extinguishers.) The extraneous tools quickly became forgotten because they were less efficient, and seeing how many tools I passed over made me aware of how often the amount of diverging paths are also illusions of choice."When Stanley Came to a Set of Two Open Doors..."There is a section that best illustrates however mechanically diverse the game handles situations it's often an illusion of choice. During the third mission from UNACTO of finding Ambrosia, you sneak into the tunnels and stop at an impasse. To the right you can use a lock-pick to access the valve, and to the left you can use a multitools to turn off the lasers. (Or you can make a stair-case of mines to hop over the lasers.) Every option will lead to the same room.That moment epitomizes various things. For one, the only differences between using a multitool and a lock pick is how many of each item do you have and what skill-level are you. Second, whenever the game offers you a choice—to spare or to kill, to choose one side or action over another, etc.—it will always bottleneck to the plot. Third, once you see past the facade it's evident how the game is a linear set of missions with variables to play with. For the time, DX is impressive and should be noted for its innovation. My issue isn't that the game lies to you about the impact of your choices; it's how the mechanics are superficial paths with no challenge. Perhaps it's because I enjoyed the hacking mini-game of MD so much that the loading bar for hacking in DX made me longing for mechanical complexity with my tools.I don't even mind the endings because they have never mattered in DX games; what matters are the effects of the accumulation of your moment-to-moment choices. This quality is still in the original, but the effect I find lacks the impact of other games where there was more variety in how going about an objective changed the game. Let Me Repeat Myself: It's Not a Bad Game; It's Flawed Of all the things that disappointed me the most is the storytelling. This isn't to say the writing quality is bad; in fact, it's good in spite of the more glaring issue, the voice-actors. I normally enjoy hammy actors but the dialogue is so monotone that I couldn't even enjoy the sillier elements like the Illuminati factoids. (Jensen is no Shakespearean actor but he's more lively than Stonewall Denton.) I felt more attached to reading the emails to give more background on characters than listening to them.I don't hear many people bring up that issue of immersion for such a serious game of prophetic visions of the future. Maybe I could have felt more attached to the storyline had I been exposed to this game at a younger age when 9/11 was more relevant, but I will say the themes underlying the story are still terrifyingly relatable. That quality is timeless.  All of these criticisms are not to disillusion fans but to illustrate the flaws that are in this "perfect" game. As for those who say I don't get it, I don't think it's healthy to ignore issues with a beloved classic and then lambaste the modern takes for having unobtainable goals. All DX games have their flaws, some have a greater fall than others, but we can all cherish the core of DX.If that doesn't extinguish any flame-wars, just remember one thing: "What good's an honest soldier if he can be ordered to behave like a terrorist?"

number of helpful: 6 of 26 people (23%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												It makes me sad that I cannot in good faith recommend purchasing this game, because it is one of those incredibly important games in videogame history. Much like Wolfenstein/Doom, Thief, Half-Life, etc., the original Deus Ex figuratively "broke ground" in gaming by using elements from all of the aforementioned titles to create a game where stealth, ranged combat, NPC interactions, multiple paths to an objective, and a pretty impressive amount of lore and story elements, combining all of these to make a jaw-dropping (for the time) experience. It's still amazing to look back on this game and forever respect it for the road it has paved to inspire other games such as Deus Ex Human Revolution and its sequel, Mankind Divided, as well as Vampire - The Masquerade: Bloodlines and Dishonored and Dishonored 2.Why then, do I not recommend that you buy this game? Well, because this is one hideous game to look at, and feels painfully "clunky" with a lot that simply has not aged well. The sky in the outdoors areas feels faker than the original and much older Doom's skies (I am not me exaggerating), and much of the map feels painfully open with very long distances with nothing to interact with. You can run several hundred feet (100 yards or so) with virtually nothing to do on the first map of the game, in various parts of the level. You won't be picking up items, talking to people, killing or KO-ing anything, learning story, or even experiencing atmosphere. The game's first map is shamefully guilty of this, though it improves as the game goes on. Picking up and throwing objects has the most awkward and "heavy" physics I've seen in a game, and this title encourages save-scumming (quick saving and quick loading all the time) more than most games, because attacks that should be one-hit kills, like a trained skill level headshot from three feet away in stealth with a pistol, may take 2-3 shots to a head that's bare or wearing a ski mask, resulting in enemies hearing him scream, ruining your stealth. Same goes for lockpicking and multitools (hacking things that aren't computer consoles). "I only have a handful of lockpicks. Is opening this case worth it?" *lockpicks it and it contains terrible items* "Wasn't worth it!" Time to quick load. The newer games just handle this better, having risky hacking where you can be seen by humans or cameras, and can get cheeky/inventive by putting vending machines in the way comically so you won't be spotted. Speaking of which, my own complaints aside, many of which are undoubtedly personal preference, the fact of the matter is that the newer Deus Ex games are simply better in virtually every way. I'm in my 30s at present and was playing Space Quest III when it was brand spankin' new, so this isn't a situation of being too young to appreciate the original Deus Ex, and I played the original DX in the early 2000s, so I'm not just now coming into this game with Human Revolution and such already existing before I tried it. The problem is that while yes, this game broke incredible ground and deserves the respect it has, it unfortunately has been outdone by its sequels and most of the other games of its genre. You can get more Deus Ex from the (currently) two more recent titles in the franchise, and all the features have been carried over and improved in so many ways since then. While a game like VtM Bloodlines is very outdated compared to Mankind Divided, at least it can be argued that no other games exist in that universe that are in the Deus Ex "genre," so there are reasons other than nostalgia for someone to play it. Since Deus Ex has been outdone by its sequels, there is no reason to go back, other than nostalgia, and chances are, people with DX nostalgia already own it, so there is no cause for recommending the game to them. In closing...it was a game that did fantastic things I will always respect it for, but it's clunky and outdated with a lead character who does not seem to care with comically bad line delivery and the better parts of its plot are in newspapers and books you just read in-game, reiterating that instead of playing this game, you could play a newer one and/or read about this game's story/lore online.

number of helpful: 7 of 33 people (21%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												I don't see what's so great about Deus Ex.To get the game to run on modern PCs various mods are needed. Alt Tabing out of the game or using the steam overlay causes a spectacular crash either way. Without the relavant mods the game has absolutely attrocious framerate issues.As a shooter the game is esoteric; aiming has nothing to do with actually trying to hit the target, it's determined by how long the player is willing to stand still doing nothing until the crosshairs decide to reach their smallest size allowing a projectile to land anywhere near the intended target; this, alongside the game's awkward default controls leads me to think that this game wasn't meant to be played using a mouse at all.As a stealth game Deus Ex is laughably bad, enemies can't see the player even if he was standing directly in front of them as long as he was a sufficent distance from them. Don't bother with the tranquilizer darts as enemies will spas out shooting at the player and running to the nearest alarm; which would be the exact oposite of tranquil. The only purpose it serves is being able to knock out Men In Black to take their ammunition as a opposed to them exploding for no reason after death.As an RPG the game holds very little options at all. What I do admire is that the game doesn't award skill points for killing enemies, which encourages going for the quiet approach. Skill points can be spent on the game's various skills, which include such wonderous options like Swimming. Honestly there's very little reason to spend points on any skill past rank 2 aside to fix the god-awful accuracy of all the guns in the game by leveling a weapon skill, since leveling lockpicking or engineering will see the player rarely ever run out of lockpicks or multitools. Yes, that's run out of, as in, it doesn't actually improve the player's ability; in the words of Spaceballs: "Even in the future nothing works!" since absolutely everything you use, lockpicks, multitools, armor, invisibility, will break and vanish after using it once and their relavant skills determine how long you can actually use it after activating it or determine the percentage a lockpick or multitool will knock off the lock.The game has a focus on Augmentation, to get them the player must gather augmentation canisters and upgrades. Each canister has two options for the player to implant, and the choice is permanent. Really the only useful ones are Regeneration(medkits and the medicine skill became close to useless after that), Speed(the levels are way too large and way too empty to take things slowly), and Power Regulation, as everything else is too wildly situational and expensive in bioenergy to be useful, even when I did use other augmentations they seems to have absolutely no effect. Despite claiming that his vision was augmented the default light augmentation only makes the player glow like a Christmas tree instead of granting nightvision, which is soon made rather pointless anyways.Comically, the game is hilariously easy for a simple reason, the weapons used by both the player and the enemy switch between useless and over-powered. About a quarter into the game the player is granted the Dragon Tooth, basically a lightsaber that kills absolutely everything that is human in one hit(even 'boss' enemies die to two or three hits with this thing, usually to only one if it hits the head); say goodbye to useless pistols and rifles that JC can't aim to save his life; yes, just sit there until your cataracts stop acting up JC, eventually you have to hit him! Really, there is absolutely no reason to use anything else except for it and the GEP gun. Speaking of the GEP gun, at the very start of the game the player is granted the options of getting a crossbow, a sniper rifle, or a GEP gun. Only mere meters away from the person who gives it to you is a free crossbow anyways. The GEP gun can kill anything is that is -or is not- human in one shot, it even comes with a lock-on feature to any target in the game! So there's the Dream Team: The Dragon Tooth and the GEP gun! Both available right at the start of the game! Incidentally the enemy also has access to such weapons, whom are virtually harmless as it takes them entire seconds to register that the player is a threat, that is if they actually see the player as their field of vision is about 5 meters far. Believe me I wanted to use the Plasma Rifle instead, but that thing is a peice of trash that deals no damage, takes too long to load, has an effective range about as big as its splash radious, the ammo is practically non-existent, and anything worth shooting at with it has an energy shield. All the other guns in this game suck for one reason or another actually, usually for their terrible damage and accuracy.The game features a little economy which is close to pointless as there are very few shops that sell things the player actually needs, so if the player has been hacking ATMs since the start it would be best to buy absolutely everything they find that isn't food as they will have few chances to buy anything else unless they're fans of hoarding Soylent Green chocolate bars.The story starts out rather predicably, the player plays as JC Dention, who they can actually give a 'real' name to which in true RPG fashion is mentioned only in text files on very few of the game's PCs. They work for the big bad gov'ment and have to stop the terrorists from stealing the useless vaccine for the plague, and I'm sure you already see where this is going. Mere hours(apparently a day, but I can't tell since there's no sun in this game) after joining the force JC betrays the gov'ment and fights for the terrorists and it turns out that the plague is man-made and the terrorists can make a cure! So with the help of some Artificial Intelligences and a bunch of useless jerks JC singlehandedly kills all the bad guys, launches some nukes, and destroys some bases before he reaches the final base that needs to explode and the game suddenly decides that it wouldn't be an RPG if there weren't final choices! Which feels rather token considering that game had no meaningful choices before that point, and it certainly didn't start there, since the only thing this choice does is grant a minute long cutscene and a quote from some moron from the 17th century before cuting to the credits.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Please note: this first-impression review is heavily biased by two factors:- I suck at action games.- I play in my living room (with a Steam Link and Steam Controller).If neither of these apply to you, you should probably ignore this review.I had great hopes for this game, based on the many positivew reviews I read. Unfortunately, things did not work out well for me, I was hit right off the bat by two things:1) At the start of the game, I had no idea what to do. The controls are complicated and not obvious, and the Steam version of the game does not come with a manual. After repeatedly looking at the Settings>Controls menu, and lots of experimentation, I finally was able to figure out enough to complete the rather simplistic tutorial (after several attempts). 2) The entire UI is designed with a fixed size in pixels. The result is that, in a living room context, most of the text is not readable at any resolution higher than about 1024x720. Other annoyances:- Switching to another window often does really bad things, resulting in a need to hard-abort and restart. When using a Steam Link, this is a game-killer.- It always runs full screen, so things are distored at any aspect ratio (e.g. 4:3 used for lower resolutions) that does not match the monitor (e.g. 16:9).- This is an OLD game. The graphics were probably impressive at the time, but they are now quite dated.I may try again after I've finished my backlog of great games that don't have these problems (e.g. Deus Ex: Human Revolution).

												Deus Ex is a game that one only reads positive things about. I had high expectations ... and I got disappointed big time.The game starts out alright. content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												This is ... not a good game.It would have been okay when it originally released in 2000, but the interesting story and characters are severely hampered by bad gameplay. The controls feel like steering a shopping cart, the UI is bad, and the foes are all bullet sponges (even the unarmored and unaugmented humans) in a world that hordes ammo like it was the zombie apocalypse.I really like everything about this game EXCEPT PLAYING IT. Interesting characters, complex conspiracies (poorly executed, but if they were doing it well you'd probably miss it), a dystopian future that is distressingly more plausible every day, choices and consequences, multiple options for resolving tactical challenges, lots of exploration and rewards for doing so, a strong emphasis on story, and the ability to alter the fate of the game world. Unfortunately, playing it is a tedious chore that is sometimes actually painful, and never fun.Great ideas, and the writing is good, but the only reason this gets praise still is nostalgia. People played it as children, loved it when they had nothing better to compare it to, and still remember it fondly. Stay away.If you want to play in this universe, Human Revolution is nearly as solid a story and has significantly better gameplay.Edit:Clarification about why I say the gameplay is bad.I sat down to play DX, and discovered that I could barely interact with the world, that the control scheme was just bad.So, I did my research. I learned that it used the same engine and similar features as System Shock 2 (another beloved classic). So, I tracked down SS2 and started playing.SS2 is violent, twitchy, and unforgiving. It also has an interesting discovery-based narrative (the story happened before you show up) that I found compelling. I put in the work, adjusted the controls, tweaked my upgrades to match my prefered play style, and beat SS2. I even had a lot of fun doing it.With all my training, I came back to DX. I adjusted the button layout to match my trained reflexes, put on my patience hat, and settled in to enjoy DX.Deus Ex still controlled terribly.System Shock 2 is older, less ambitious, and less well regarded than Deus Ex. SS2 also has smoother, more responsive gameplay, a more useful UI, and does a much better job of making the protagonist feel like an augmeted badass (regardless of playstyle).That's why I say DX has terrible controls. Because an older game, using the same engine, did it better.

number of helpful: 43 of 129 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												I’ll start off with saying I have no nostalgia for this game. I have never played any Deus Ex game before writing this review. I do, however, understand that this game was very well regarded back when it came out. And I can definitely see that. It introduced many ways to complete an objective and gave the player a sense of freedom. It also has an interesting augmentation upgrade system. So…I see where all the positive reviews are coming from. However, I couldn’t get into this game and had to stop playing after 4 hours.Deus Ex is clearly going for more of a stealth based game rather than combat. But the stealth mechanics (or lack thereof) make it extremely difficult to do so. The wide open maps don’t cater to a stealth approach. You are given stealth-like weapons but they all felt very underpowered and useless, so I wasn’t inclined to use them. I found it was easier to run up to enemies with the crowbar and whack them until they died. The default mapping of buttons is a bizarre choice by the developers. You can change most aspects of the controls in the options, however.Uninteresting story that I never got into. The bad voice acting didn’t help either. Although I think robotic sounding voices are intentional for the nano-augmented characters and mech characters. The enemy AI is also very bad. Sometimes they’ll run around and never shoot or they’ll stand there and fight. The damage the enemy inflicts on you is pretty big, even on medium difficulty. I also couldn’t figure out how I died a lot of times. There is a health meter per body part, but I couldn’t figure out what was important or how it related to when I died. On a positive note, there is a lot of story here. Many books, newspaper clippings and emails to read. As well as many NPC’s to talk to. There are side missions too. It’s a lot of content, which is great, but only if the gameplay makes me want to continue, which in this case it did not. Autosave doesn't exist so you have to quick save or save manually. You'll be quick saving and quick loading a lot.To get 60fps, use a different launcherDeus Ex runs at a very low framerate. Do a google search for “kentie launcher”. Install that and you’ll be able to get 60fps as well as have some more graphical options. Pros+Lots of extra story and Deus Ex world lore to uncover+Multiple ways to complete a level+Nice augmentation system for its time.+Inventory system is okCons+Story is uninteresting+Voice acting is subpar+Stealth mechanics lacking+Combat system is clunky+AI is lackingDeus Ex is a stealth based game with FPS elements but provides the mechanics and tools for neither. A game that was undoubtedly great in its time, but falls flat today.4/10 Below average

number of helpful: 10 of 48 people (21%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Let me start off with this: I really, REALLY wanted to like this game. But I just can't get into it. Human Revolution (One of my top three favorite games of all time) sucked me in as soon as I saw the first cutscene and was hooked once I finished the tutorial. I have bought the it twice for the 360 (one regular copy. one director's cut copy), and I will most likely get another copy for PC. I am also super excited for Mankind Divided and will definitely buy it, once there are enough reviews to confirm that it’s good.. But this game. I just can't get into it. The tutorial was torture, the controls are funky, the voice acting seems bland (Human Revolution even had some bland voice acting at points but it did not turn me off from the game at all),  and the first mission just felt like a chore. The community that loves this game promised me things like “Trust me you will love this game”, “Best game that money can buy”, and “As soon as you finish the first mission you will fall in love with this game”. And the hype that the community has build up just shattered to pieces as I played it. I am not just hating on this game because I can't appreciate a good story, or don't appreciate the older classic games. I am hating on this game because the community that plays it have built up so much hype and everyone had me ready to play one of the greatest games of all time and I'm left just disappointed. The first thought I had after a 40 minute session with this game was "Whoa, that was disappointing". I don't hate this game and contrary to my review, I don't not recommend this game. I just don't know exactly who to recommend it to. Maybe I’m just spoiled by the graphics, controls, or features of modern games. Maybe I’m playing it wrong. Or maybe I’m not old enough to feel nostalgia for this game or how revolutionary it was at the time. I do know one thing about this game though. It did not nearly live up to my expectations that the community had built up for it. And before you yell at me for not even playing an hour of this game, It’s because I will be asking steam for a refund, because it’s unlikely that what I have seen from it so far will get any better by my standards. I’m sorry that I’m not able to appreciate what a masterpiece this was for its time, but I just can’t bring myself to like it. No matter how much I wanted to before I bought it and played it.
